{"uri": "8183045367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "06:36:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T06:36:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T06:35:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.ladbible.com/news/uk-news/sir-ian-mckellen-update-fell-off-stage-735860-20240618", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen update released as star was rushed to hospital after falling off stage", "body": "A spokesperson for Sir Ian McKellen has released an update on the actor after he was rushed to hospital due to falling off stage.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was performing in a production of Player Kings at London's Noel Coward theatre last night (17 June) when he lost his footing during a fight scene and subsequently fell from the stage.\n\nFollowing the incident, the audience was evacuated from the theatre and the performance was cancelled, as the Lord of the Rings actor was taken to hospital.\n\nTonight's performance has also been cancelled.\n\nA spokesperson for McKellen has since issued an update on the actor's condition via the theatre, reassuring fans that the actor will make a 'full recovery'.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production his made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\n\"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nIt's expected that McKellen will return to the production for a matinee performance on Wednesday, 19 June.\n\nMcKellen, best known for his role as Gandalf in the J.R.R Tolkein adaption and Magneto in X-Men, was playing the role of John Falstaff in the West End adaption of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Parts One and Two. The production was in the middle of a 12-week run which started in April.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley revealed to PA that McKellen appeared to 'trip' as he moved across the stage.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" he said.\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\"\n\nAccording to a report from the BBC, McKellen was performing in a fight scene with Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell from the front of the stage. {"uri": "8183296031", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:25:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:25:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:24:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/culture/stage/2024/06/18/ian-mckellen-to-make-a-speedy-and-full-recovery-after-london-theatre-stage-fall/", "title": "Ian McKellen to 'make a speedy and full recovery' after London theatre stage fall", "body": "Lord of the Rings star lost footing and fell off stage during performance at Noel Coward Theatre\n\nIan McKellen is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during a West End performance, a theatre representative has confirmed.\n\nThe Lord Of The Rings actor (85) who is playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" an official for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18th so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nMcKellen is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\n[ Ian McKellen: From Gandalf to goose ]\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front-of-house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Ian could be treated in privacy.\n\n\"An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front-of-house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service has declined to comment.\n\n[ Ian McKellen as Hamlet: Is ageism the last great barrier in the arts industry? ]\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nMcKellen's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards. - PA Wire", "source": Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account on Thursday said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three He lost his footing during a fight scene, AFP reported.\n\nIt was during this scene that McKellen reportedly fell off stage and audience members heard him \"crying in pain\".\n\nThe lights quickly came up and theatre staff and medical personnel were on hand to help. The actor before he was rushed to hospital, Express reported.\n\nThe audience was evacuated from the theatre as a result, with the rest of the show cancelled and tickets refunded.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS (National Health Service) team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" a theatre spokesperson said on Tuesday.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nHe is expected to return to the stage on Wednesday.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" the spokesperson said.\n\nMcKellen, who also played Magneto in the X-Men films, is one of Britain's most recognised actors, having won many awards during a 60-year career on stage and screen.\n\nPlayer Kings is a return to Shakespeare for McKellen; combining two of the Bard's history plays The incident led to the evacuation of the theatre, and upcoming performances were canceled to allow McKellen time to rest.London, Jun 18 (AP) Actor Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after he toppled off a London stage Monday during a fight scene and was hospitaliSed, a spokesperson said. McKellen, 85, was in \"good spirits\" after doctors said a scan showed he was expected to fully recover from the fall, a spokesperson for the Noel Coward Theatre said.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran known for playing Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films and many stage roles over a six decade career cried out in pain after the fall, according to a BBC journalist at the theatre.\n\nMcKellen was playing John Falstaff in \"Player Kings\", a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nHe lost his footing and fell off the stage in a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy. {"uri": "8183812436", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "14:56:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T14:56:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T14:50:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/entertainment/2749926/", "title": "British actor Ian McKellen hospitalized after stage fall in London - ExBulletin", "body": "The 85-year-old actor is expected to make a full and speedy recovery after falling off stage during a performance of Player Kings in London.\n\nBritish actor Sir Ian McKellen was taken to hospital after falling off stage during a fight scene while performing in London's West End last night.\n\nMcKellen played John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nSome in the audience reportedly thought it was part of the act, while others gasped when the 85-year-old lost his footing and fell off the stage during a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy.\n\nDoctors say McKellen is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to make a full recovery.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran known for playing Gandalf in the the Lord of the Rings film and many stage roles over a six-decade career screamed in pain after the fall, according to a BBC reporter at the theater.\n\nSir Ian appeared to trip as he got off stage to take a more active part in the scene, audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. He gained momentum as he got off the stage, causing him to fall off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, a spokesman for Noel Coward said.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play canceled. Tuesday's production was also canceled to give McKellen time to rest and recover.\n\nMcKellen's career includes playing Magneto in the X-Men films and several Shakespearean characters including {"uri": "8182662114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:47:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:47:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:46:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/lifestyle/ian-mckellen-85-rushed-to-hospital-after-falling-off-stage-during-performance/article_3e03071d-8465-54b2-8b06-e4b13e54176f.html", "title": "Ian McKellen, 85, Rushed to Hospital After Falling Off Stage During Performance", "body": "Samuel Edward-Cook, Richard Coyle, Sir Ian McKellen, Toheeb Jimoh and Clare Perkins bow at the curtain call during the press night performance of 'Player Kings' at the Noel Coward Theatre on April 11, 2024, in London, England.\n\nSir Ian McKellen, 85, was rushed to a hospital after falling off the stage during a performance of Player Kings.\n\nOn Monday, June 17, McKellen performed a fight scene from the play at No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London, England, when he lost his balance and tumbled off the stage, multiple outlets reported.\n\nReportedly, the actor fell off the front of the stage and screamed in pain as he landed, per BBC. Theater staff quickly responded to him before McKellen was rushed to a nearby hospital. The play was cancelled at that point, according to the publication, and the audience was evacuated from the building.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" a statement from No\u00ebl Coward Theatre, via McKellen's rep, read.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the statement continued. \"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nFurthermore, the Tuesday, June 18 performance of Player Kings was cancelled \"so Ian can rest.\"\n\nAn audience member, Sandro Trapani, told BBC the accident was \"very shocking.\"\n\n\"I really hope that he is going to be alright,\" Trapani said. \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nMcKellen has played John Falstaff in the production since April, and the show's last date was supposed to be on June 22.\n\nThe actor is most well-known for portraying Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit trilogies and Magneto in the X-Men films. Additionally, McKellen had notable roles in Beauty and the Beast (2017), The Da Vinci Code and Mr. Holmes, among many other projects.\n\nIn an interview published in The Times of London on June 7, McKellen said he was open to reprising his role as Gandalf \"if I'm alive.\" He clarified, \"But there is no script, there is no offer, there is no plan.\"\n\nNext: 10 Reasons You Should Be Following McKellen reportedly cried out in pain after his fall, prompting staff to rush over and assist him. The report said the theater was \"evacuated\" and Tuesday night's performance was also canceled.\n\nMcKellen is expected to make a full recovery.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of 'Player Kings,'\" a statement from the theater said.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" it said. \"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. The tumble startled theatergoers.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, the spokesperson said.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play was canceled. The production for Tuesday was also canceled to give McKellen time to rest.\n\nMcKellen's career includes playing Magneto in the X-Men films and several Shakespearean characters including Richard II, {"uri": "8187069769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:01:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:01:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:00:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/entertainment/11681061/sir-ian-mckellen-update-after-falling-off-stage/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen shares update saying he will not reappear in play after fall", "body": "SIR Ian McKellen has shared an update after his fall as it's confirmed his understudy will take over his role in Player Kings for its final London dates.\n\nThe veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nSir Ian said he is having \"physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home\" after three nights in hospital.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account today said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nAfter his fall, Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.", "source": {"uri": "the-sun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-06-393002627", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "05:28:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T05:28:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T18:59:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.wkyc.com/article/entertainment/entertainment-tonight/sir-ian-mckellen-rushed-to-hospital-after-falling-off-stage-during-london-performance/603-e6120613-a3a5-4ba0-8e4a-31034e30d862", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen Rushed to Hospital After Falling Off Stage During London Performance", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen was rushed to the hospital on Monday when the beloved actor accidentally fell off stage during a performance.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was performing in a production of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London, and amid a fight scene, he lost his footing and fell. The BBC was the first to report.\n\nIt was not immediately clear what injuries, if any, McKellen sustained in the fall. However, the theater was evacuated and the production was canceled for the evening.\n\nPlayer Kings is an adaptation of Parts 1 and 2 of Henry IV, with McKellen in the leading role as John Falstaff. His run on the show has been received with universal critical acclaim.\n\nAccording to the BBC, the incident occurred as McKellen's Falstaff was circling a battle involving his co-lead, Toheeb Jimoh (playing Henry Percy), and he fell off the front of the stage and cried out for help.\n\nThe production team behind Player Kings tells ET of Sir Ian McKellen's on-stage fall at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre, \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance.\"\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the statement continued. \"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nOne audience member told the BBC that the incident was \"very shocking\" and recounted, \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nJournalist Charlie Johnson, who was in attendance at the event, took to Twitter to detail what he had seen.\n\n\"Just witnessed Ian Mckellan severely injure himself after falling off stage at Noel Coward Theatre. Sir Ian could be heard screaming in pain as ushers rushed to his aid,\" he wrote. \"Show cancelled as he is treated by ambulance crews. Wish him all the best.\"\n\nThe production is scheduled to tour a series of London theaters through July 27. The fall surprised spectators.\n\n\"Sir Ian appeared to trip as he came down from the stage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it {"uri": "2024-06-392820234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "00:03:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T00:03:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:44:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/actor-ian-mckellen-85-is-in-good-spirits-and-expected-to-recover-from-fall-off/article_bdbb5ae3-bd1e-5935-94d7-e49e2a6ad20d.html", "title": "Actor Ian McKellen, 85, is in 'good spirits' and expected to recover from fall off stage in London", "body": "FILE - British actor Ian McKellen poses in front of beach huts, on the Deauville promenade during the 41st American Film Festival, Thursday, Sept. 10, 2015, in Deauville, western France. McKellen has been hospitalized Monday, June 17, 2024, after toppling off a London stage during a fight scene in a play. The 85-year-old actor known for playing Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films and his many stage roles was playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nLONDON (AP) -- Actor Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after he toppled off a London stage Monday during a fight scene and was hospitalized, a spokesperson said.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was in \"good spirits\" after doctors said a scan showed he was expected to fully recover from the fall, a spokesperson for the Noel Coward Theatre said.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran known for playing Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films and many stage roles over a six decade career cried out in pain after the fall, according to a BBC journalist at the theater.\n\nMcKellen was playing John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nHe lost his footing and fell off the stage in a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy. The tumble startled theatergoers.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, the spokesperson said.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play was canceled. The production for Tuesday was also canceled to give McKellen time to rest.\n\nMcKellen's career includes playing Magneto in the X-Men films and several Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth and King Lear.\n\nHe has won a Tony Award for \"Amadeus,\" several Laurence Olivier Awards and has been nominated for two Oscars and several BAFTA awards.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8182655511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:41:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:41:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:36:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13540421/Sir-Ian-McKellen-make-speedy-recovery-theatre-stage-fall.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen to 'make a speedy and full recovery\u00b4 after theatre...", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during a West End performance, a theatre spokesperson has confirmed.\n\nThe Lord Of The Rings actor, 85, who is currently playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" a spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency.\n\nSir Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery following the incident (Matt Crossick/PA)\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nSir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nSir Ian McKellen appeared to lose his footing during a fight scene (Isabel Infantes/PA)\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\n\n\"An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nSir Ian McKellen (Matt Crossick/PA)\n\nLondon Ambulance Service has declined to comment.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Those inside were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nThankfully, it was announced tonight that Sir Ian is expected to make a swift recovery and is in \"good spirits\".\n\nA theatre spokesperson said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nAudience members took to social media to say they were 'shocked' and left 'in tears' as they posted well-wishes for the actor. Pictures were shared to X of huge crowds outside the venue after the show was postponed.\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he then fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to 'cry out in pain' as staff rushed to help. Audience members said they were 'shocked' and left 'in tears' by the incident on social media.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nREAD MORE Dario G star Paul Spencer dies aged 53 after devastating cancer diagnosis\n\nAfter the incident, members of the audience who were evacuated from the theatre took to social media to issue well wishes to McKellen.\n\nUser @paulnero1 wrote: \"Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage tonight at Noel Coward Theatre. who plays John Falstaff in the production - was amid a fight scene when the incident occurred.\n\nThe veteran actor cried out in pain after he fell off stage and theatre staff rushed to help him.\n\nOne audience member told the BBC that the incident was \"very shocking\".\n\nSandro Trapani added: \"I really hope that he is going to be alright. As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\n'Player Kings' began its 12-week West End run in April, and McKellen previously admitted that he was relishing the opportunity.\n\nHe told the BBC earlier this year: \"Actors who have taken on the role say it is verbally very challenging - it seems that the role was written for a particular actor and comedian in The tumble startled theatergoers.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, the spokesperson said.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play was canceled. The production for Tuesday was also canceled to give McKellen time to rest.\n\nMcKellen's career includes playing Magneto in the X-Men films and several Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Per Variety, McKellen is a frequent Shakespeare actor with stage roles including Macbeth, King Lear, Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago and Richard III. Just this year, he portrayed Hamlet in a film adaptation from director Sean Mathias. {"uri": "8183327944", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:45:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:45:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:44:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.thepinknews.com/2024/06/18/ian-mckellen-health-update-player-kings-hospital/", "title": "Ian McKellen gets health update after falling off West End stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen to make 'full and speedy recovery' after fall (Getty Images)\n\nSir Ian McKellen is reportedly set to make a \"speedy and full recovery\" after falling off stage during a performance of Player Kings in the West End.\n\nMcKellen was hospitalised after falling off stage during a performance of Player Kings - an adaptation of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Parts One and Two - last night (June 17), at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre.\n\nThe 85-year-old actor, who was playing John Falstaff in the production, reportedly \"cried out in pain as staff rushed to help.\"\n\nThe show was cancelled and the audience was asked to leave, but according to The Independent, the gay icon will return to performances on Wednesday (June 19), with Tuesday's (June 18) performance also cancelled.\n\nIn a statement to the publication, a representative for Player Kings, which also star's Richard Coyle and Ted Lasso's Toheeb Jimoh, confirmed that McKellen will have a \"speedy and full recovery\" after the fall.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" they said.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\n\"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nAs reported by BBC, Sir Ian McKellen had been \"circling a battle scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when... [he fell] off the front of the stage.\"\n\nNo stranger to the stage, McKellen recently starred in gay love story Frank & Percy in 2023, but also has a slew of Shakespeare titles under his belt - McKellen, 85, was in \"good spirits\" after doctors said a scan showed he was expected to fully recover from the fall, a spokesperson for the Noel Coward Theatre said.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran known for playing Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings films and many stage roles over a six decade career cried out in pain after the fall, according to a BBC journalist at the theater. McKellen was playing John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, at the Noel Coward Theatre. He lost his footing and fell off the stage in a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy. The tumble startled theatergoers.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"Staff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, the spokesperson said. The theater was evacuated and the play was canceled. The production for Tuesday was also canceled to give McKellen time to rest.\n\nMcKellen's career includes playing Magneto in the X-Men films and several Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth and King Lear. He has won a Tony Award for Amadeus, several Laurence Olivier Awards and has been nominated for two Oscars and several BAFTA awards.\n\nExcept for the headline, this story has not been edited by DNA {"uri": "8186929281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:37:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:37:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:35:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/28619224/sir-ian-mckellen-update-after-falling-off-stage/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen update as Player Kings confirms he will not reappear in play", "body": "Sir Ian lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage\n\nSIR Ian McKellen's understudy will perform in the play Player Kings for its final London dates while he recuperates following a fall on Monday.\n\nThe veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account today said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nAfter his fall, Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": A statement was posted on the play's X (formerly Twitter) account on June 18.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during yesterday evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the statement reads.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible today,\" it continues. \"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nOriginal story (06/17/2024):\n\nSir Ian McKellen has been hospitalized after falling off of a stage during a performance of the play Player Kings in London's No\u00ebl Coward theater. It's not yet known if the Lord of the Rings actor sustained injuries from the accident.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was performing a fight scene when he lost balance and fell off the stage, according to BBC. McKellen plays John Falstaff in the play, which is made up of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Parts One and Two. McKellen was reportedly circling the fight scene involving two other players when he fell off the stage. The house lights came up and McKellen reportedly called out for help. The evening performance was canceled and the audience was evacuated from the theater.\n\nAn audience member told BBC that, \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\" They said the moment was \"very shocking.\"\n\nPlayer Kings opened in April in the West End and is set for a 12-week run. A performance once had to be canceled after McKellen injured his leg during a fall as he tried to catch a train. He participated in an audience Q&A instead of performing the show that day for the sake of the audience.\n\nMcKellen is best known for playing Gandalf in Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit trilogies, as well as playing Magneto in the X-Men franchise and his prolific stage career. He's a two-time Oscar nominee, having received his first nomination for Best Actor in 1999's Gods and Monsters and his second for Best Supporting Actor in 2002's The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring. Theater staff quickly responded to him before McKellen was rushed to a nearby hospital. The play was cancelled at that point, according to the publication, and the audience was evacuated from the building.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" a statement from No\u00ebl Coward Theatre, via McKellen's rep, read.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the statement continued. \"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\n\"I really hope that he is going to be alright,\" Trapani said. \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nMcKellen has played John Falstaff in the production since April, and the show's last date was supposed to be on June 22.\n\nThe actor is most well-known for portraying Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit trilogies and Magneto in the X-Men films. he lost his footing during a fight scene.\n\nThe rest of the night's performance was cancelled after McKellen's fall.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS (National Health Service) team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" a theatre spokesperson said on Tuesday.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on {"uri": "2024-06-393916330", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:19:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:19:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:48:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/actor-ian-mckellen-85-is-looking-forward-to-returning-to-work-after-his-fall-off/article_bdbb5ae3-bd1e-5935-94d7-e49e2a6ad20d.html", "title": "Actor Ian McKellen, 85, is looking forward to returning to work after his fall off a London stage", "body": "FILE - British actor Ian McKellen poses in front of beach huts, on the Deauville promenade during the 41st American Film Festival, Thursday, Sept. 10, 2015, in Deauville, western France. McKellen has been hospitalized Monday, June 17, 2024, after toppling off a London stage during a fight scene in a play. The 85-year-old actor known for playing Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films and his many stage roles was playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nLONDON (AP) -- Actor Ian McKellen said Tuesday he is looking forward to returning to work after he toppled off a London stage mid-performance and was hospitalized.\n\nMcKellen, 85, said he was \"hugely indebted\" to medics who treated him after the tumble on Monday night during a performance of \"Player Kings\" at London's Noel Coward Theatre.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work,\" he said on the social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter.\n\nPerformances on Tuesday and Wednesday were canceled after the accident and are scheduled to resume on Thursday.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran, who played Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films, cried out in pain after the fall, according to a BBC journalist at the theater. McKellen was playing the roguish John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" an adaptation of William Shakespeare's two \"Henry IV\" history plays, directed by Robert Icke.\n\nTheatergoers were startled when McKellen lost his footing and fell off the stage in a fight scene involving Toheeb Jimoh's Prince Hal and Henry Percy, played by Samuel Edward-Cook.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the actor, the theater said in a statement. The theater was evacuated and the performance was canceled.\n\nMcKellen played Magneto in the \"X-Men\" films and is one of Britain's most acclaimed Shakespearean actors, with roles including Richard III, Macbeth and King Lear.\n\nHe has won a Tony Award -- for \"Amadeus\" -- several Olivier Awards, and has been nominated for two Academy Awards, five Emmys and several BAFTA awards.", "source": {"uri": "8186900997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:19:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:19:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:18:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/entertainment/sir-ian-mckellen-to-miss-remainder-of-player-kings-london-dates-following-fall-XISSWG3FERMGBMFCFBAW2ES5FY/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen to miss remainder of Player Kings' London dates following fall", "body": "The veteran actor was playing Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre when he fell from the stage.\n\nSir Ian McKellen's understudy will perform in the play Player Kings for its final London dates while he recuperates following a fall from the stage on Monday.\n\nThe veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account on Thursday said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nAfter his fall, Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits. The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nThe incident occurred during a fight scene when portraying John Falstaff, lost his footing and fell off the front of the stage. The audience was promptly evacuated, and the evening performance was cancelled.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, began its 12-week West End run in April. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\nThank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\n\nMcKellen, known for his roles as Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings trilogy and Magneto in the X-Men films, was in the midst of a performance of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward theater when he lost his footing and fell during a fight scene, the BBC reported. According to the BBC, the theater was evacuated afterwards and the audience was informed the evening show was canceled.\n\n\"I really hope that he is going to be alright,\" audience member Sandro Trapani told the BBC. \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nWriter and broadcaster Paul Nero wrote on X/Twitter earlier today, \"Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage tonight at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.\"\n\nMcKellen plays John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of Shakespeare's Henry IV Parts I and II. {"uri": "8183773131", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "14:26:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T14:26:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T14:24:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/story/sir-ian-mckellen-is-in-good-spirits-after-falling-off-a-west-end-stage", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen Is in \"Good Spirits\" After Falling Off a West End Stage", "body": "Performances of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London were canceled after the 85-year-old actor fell off the front of the stage during a fight scene.\n\nSir Ian McKellen may have taken a tumble, but he's not staying down for long. On Monday, the 85-year-old actor fell off the stage during a performance at the No\u00ebl Coward theater in London -- but now says that he's in \"good spirits\" and plans to return to the show.\n\nMcKellen is currently starring as the rotund and bombastic Jon Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of William Shakespeare's Henry IV, Parts One and Two, directed by Robert Icke. According to BBC journalist Aleks Phillips, the Lord of the Rings actor fell off the front of the stage during a fight scene between Falstaff, the Prince of Wales, and Henry IV. Per Phillips, the accident happened after McKellen seemingly lost his footing.\n\n\"It happened so quickly that at first it appeared to be part of the performance,\" wrote Phillips. \"But the actor cried out and staff rushed to help.\"\n\nAfter McKellen's fall, the octogenarian was rushed to the hospital, and the audience left the theater. The following night's performance of Player Kings was subsequently cancelled. According to a statement by the producers, McKellen received a scan from doctors at Britain's National Health Service who said that the actor would \"make a speedy and full recovery.\" A spokesperson for the theatre said that \"Ian is in good spirits,\" and is expected to return to performances for the Wednesday matinee.\n\nOver the course of his illustrious six-decade acting career, McKellen has been nominated for two Academy Awards, five BAFTA awards, and has won a Tony, a Golden Globe and six Olivier Awards. He is perhaps best known for portraying Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings trilogy and Hobbit films, as well as Magneto in the original X-Men films. In recent years, McKellen has been a fixture on the London stage, starring as King Lear and an elderly Hamlet, a role he's set to reprise in a new film adaptation directed by Sean Mathias.", "source": {"uri": "8183112927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "07:25:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T07:25:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T07:23:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.westmeathindependent.ie/2024/06/18/ian-mckellen-to-make-a-speedy-and-full-recovery-after-theatre-stage-fall/", "title": "Ian McKellen to 'make a speedy and full recovery' after theatre stage fall | Westmeath Independent", "body": "Ian McKellen to 'make a speedy and full recovery' after theatre stage fall RSS Syndicated Content Published: Tue 18 Jun 2024, 8:04 AM Last updated: Tue 18 Jun 2024, 8:21 AM\n\nBy PA Reporters\n\nSir Ian McKellen is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during a West End performance, a theatre spokesperson has confirmed.\n\nThe Lord Of The Rings actor, 85, who is currently playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" a spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nMcKellen is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled, and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\n\n\"An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service has declined to comment.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nMcKellen's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen, he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters, including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Tue 18 Jun 2024, 8:04 AM Last updated: Tue 18 Jun 2024, 8:21 AM", {"uri": "2024-06-395893681", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:26:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:26:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:26:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.celebitchy.com/877023/ian_mckellen_is_expected_to_make_a_full_recovery_after_on_stage_fall_hospitalization/", "title": "Cele|bitchy | Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after on stage fall, hospitalization", "body": "Ian McKellen is mostly credited in articles as the Lord of the Rings or X-Men star, but throughout his career, both before and after those big film roles, he's always been a prolific stage actor. I think it's the work he loves the most. Here he is at a tender 85 years young, starring in Player Kings, an adaptation of Henry IV Parts 1 & 2 by Shakespeare. He's playing John Falstaff, a character he says he'd avoided until now, despite routinely treading the boards in Shakespearean roles. The play began its three-month run in April, with closing just around the corner on June 22. Unfortunately, McKellen suffered an accident at Monday's show, falling off the stage and into the audience. He was immediately hospitalized, and the goods news is he's expected to make a swift and complete recovery:\n\nIan McKellen is on the road to recovery after falling off stage mid-performance in London on Monday, June 17.\n\nThe actor, 85, was hospitalized after losing his footing during a fight scene in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, according to BBC News. The producers of the play told PEOPLE in a statement that the Lord of the Rings star has undergone a scan and is expected to make a \"full recovery\" following the fall.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" the statement began. \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS [National Health Service] team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest,\" the statement continued. \"Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nMcKellen later thanked everyone for their \"kind messages and support\" following the accident.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service,\" he said in a statement to Variety. \"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nThe audience was evacuated by theater staff following the incident, per BBC News. The outlet reported that McKellen, who plays the character of John Falstaff in the play, fell off the front of the stage and cried out in pain as crew members rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Charlie Johnson told ITV News, \"There were strobe lights and then it all went dark, at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out from the wings. And the way the stage works at the Noel Coward is there's sort of a step down just as the stage meets the audience.\"\n\n'I think what happened was he put his foot too far, sort of went off that initial step, at which point he lost his balance and pretty much just went head first into the audience,\" he added. \"And within seconds a blood-curdling scream arose from the actor. He was clearly in a lot of pain, he was screaming, 'Help me.'\"\n\nA source told PEOPLE that the English actor was \"fine\" immediately after the scare.\n\nIt's hoped the star, who is best known for playing Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings movie trilogy and Magneto in the X-Men films, will return to the stage on Wednesday, 19 June, for a matinee performance, per ITV.\n\n[From People]\n\nOof, the descriptions of the scream Ian let out gave me chills. He's a fairly spritely fellow -- I remember his Mr. Holmes costar Laura Linney commenting on a talk show about how insanely fit and energetic he was, but of course I'm not finding it now on the interwebs, and this was nearly 10 years ago. But still, any fall as an octogenarian has to be treated seriously. Ian wasn't at the Wednesday performance; instead the show was canceled with a similar statement that they hoped he could return on June 20. Without any disrespect to Sir Ian, is there not an understudy for him so that the show can, you know, go on? Or do the producers figure his name is such a big draw that the audience would be more upset with a replacement than a cancellation? It must be bittersweet for the whole team to have their show be derailed so close to the end of its run. A statement was posted on the play's X (formerly Twitter) account on June 18.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during yesterday evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the statement reads.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. It's not yet known if the Lord of the Rings actor sustained injuries from the accident.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was performing a fight scene when he lost balance and fell off the stage, according to BBC. McKellen plays John Falstaff in the play, which is made up of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Parts One and Two. McKellen was reportedly circling the fight scene involving two other players when he fell off the stage. The house lights came up and McKellen reportedly called out for help. The evening performance was canceled and the audience was evacuated from the theater.\n\nAn audience member told BBC that, \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\" They said the moment was \"very shocking.\"\n\nMore from this section Top 10 Greatest National Football Matches of All Time Final Fantasy 14 Dawntrail Official Launch Trailer Project Party Official Announcement Trailer\n\nPlayer Kings opened in April in the West End and is set for a 12-week run. According to the BBC, McKellen was rushed to a hospital, while the audience was evacuated from the venue, and the rest of the performance was cancelled.\n\nIn a statement (per IGN), McKellen's publicist commented that the veteran actor is expected to make a \"speedy and full recovery\". The full statement reads: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\n\"The production his made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday, 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nPerformances of Player Kings are expected to resume on Wednesday (June 19), and ticket holders for June 18 performances can expect news on refunds soon.\n\nMcKellen plays John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of Shakespeare's Henry IV Parts I and II. The play began its 12-week run on the West End in April, and is set to move through Bristol, Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle in July. Tickets are now on sale.\n\nEarlier this month, McKellen expressed interest in reprising his role as Gandalf in the upcoming Lord Of The Rings spinoff. {"uri": "2024-06-392814554", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:49:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:49:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T22:56:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/actor-ian-mckellen-85-hospitalized-225605695.html", "title": "Actor Ian McKellen, 85, is in 'good spirits' and expected to recover from fall off stage in London", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Actor Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after he toppled off a London stage Monday during a fight scene and was hospitalized, a spokesperson said.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was in \"good spirits\" after doctors said a scan showed he was expected to fully recover from the fall, a spokesperson for the Noel Coward Theatre said.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran known for playing Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films and many stage roles over a six decade career cried out in pain after the fall, according to a BBC journalist at the theater.\n\nMcKellen was playing John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nHe lost his footing and fell off the stage in a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy. The tumble startled theatergoers.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, the spokesperson said.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play was canceled. The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nREAD MORE:\n\nFirst look at Jenna Coleman's new BBC crime drama The Jetty\n\n'It wasn't an easy decision' - Nicola Bulley's family on new BBC documentary\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\". Sir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises. A BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help. Audience member Paul Critchley told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene. He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy. An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service has declined to comment. Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country. On screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear. {"uri": "8184206774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:09:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:09:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:57:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13544111/Sir-Ian-McKellen-looking-forward-returning-work-falling-stage.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen 'looking forward to returning to work\u00b4 after...", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen has said he is \"looking forward to returning to work\" as he thanked the NHS staff who cared for him after he fell from a West End stage earlier this week.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor, 85, was portraying John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, he said he is \"hugely indebted\" to the medical staff who have assured him his recovery will be \"complete and speedy\".\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" Sir Ian said in the statement posted to X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nSir Ian had been expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance, but it was announced on Tuesday that the show will now not return until Thursday.\n\nIn a statement posted to X, the show added: \"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement on Monday night that Sir Ian was in \"good spirits\" and thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nSir Ian was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nSir Ian McKellen fell from the stage during a performance of Player Kings at the theatre on Monday night (Aaron Chown/PA)\n\nThe Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk recalled how Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene before falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to end its run at the Noel Coward Theatre on Saturday.\n\nThe play will then move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July before being staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is best known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters
