{"uri": "8184354129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "22:35:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T22:35:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T22:33:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.etonline.com/player-kings-audience-members-recall-sir-ian-mckellen-screaming-for-help-after-falling-off-stage", "title": "Audience Members Recall Sir Ian McKellen 'Screaming' After Fall", "body": "Ian McKellen was injured on Monday while performing in 'Player Kings' at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London.\n\nSir Ian McKellen was rushed to the hospital on Monday when the beloved actor accidentally fell off stage during a performance.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was performing in a production of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London, and amid a fight scene, he lost his footing and fell. The BBC was the first to report.\n\nIt was not immediately clear what injuries, if any, McKellen sustained in the fall. However, the theater was evacuated and the production was canceled for the evening.\n\nPlayer Kings is an adaptation of Parts 1 and 2 of Henry IV, with McKellen in the leading role as John Falstaff. His run on the show has been received with universal critical acclaim.\n\nAccording to the BBC, the incident occurred as McKellen's Falstaff was circling a battle involving his co-lead, Toheeb Jimoh (playing Henry Percy), and he fell off the front of the stage and cried out for help.\n\nET spoke to Veronika Muzika, who was an audience member during the incident. Muzika said she at first thought McKellen's accident was part of the play.\n\n\"So he fell down the orchestra pit just in front of our eyes and he was screaming something like, 'Help,' and I thought it was part of the play because there were a lot of wounded people, like, you know, it's a war act, and yeah, it was quite shocking,\" she says. \"He seemed like he was moving pretty OK through the stage as normal. I didn't see any kind of tripping. Maybe there was some slippery sort of fabric or something and it must have been something really, really small because he was acting and walking naturally until the last step when he actually fell and that's why I thought it was staged.\"\n\nCharlie Johnson, who was also in attendance at the event, took to X (formerly Twitter) to detail what he had seen.\n\n\"Just witnessed Ian Mckellan severely injure himself after falling off stage at Noel Coward Theatre. Sir Ian could be heard screaming in pain as ushers rushed to his aid,\" he wrote. \"Show cancelled as he is treated by ambulance crews. Wish him all the best.\"\n\nET spoke with Johnson via video chat on Tuesday, and he detailed his experience at the performance.\n\n\"I was in the front row. I was probably about three or four meters from where Sir Ian fell off,\" Johnson shared, explaining that the fall happened \"during a battle scene -- so there were lights going on and off and it was quite dark.\"\n\n\"So I'm not sure if he slipped on a prop or he overstepped slightly and lost his balance,\" he continued. \"What I did see was Sir Ian pretty much diving head first into the audience and actually landed, from what I saw, on one of the members of the audience, and within seconds, you could hear Sir Ian screaming.\"\n\n\"He was shouting, 'Help me! Help me!' And the lights all went on and the curtain was drawn and within another five, ten seconds the ushers came over, members of the cast were looking to see if he was OK,\" Johnson recalled. \"As time went on, within a minute really, the whole of the auditorium was evacuated, so that Sir Ian could be treated with a bit of privacy.\"\n\n\"It was really frightening,\" Johnson said. \"I never really heard someone scream like that in pain, other than on the rugby pitch after someone smacked their wrist in half, so I immediately feared the worst -- especially because Sir Ian is 85 years old and a fall like that can be really bad for someone at that age.\"\n\nThe production team behind Player Kings tells ET of McKellen's on-stage fall at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre, \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance.\"\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the statement continued. \"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nThe production is scheduled to tour a series of London theaters through July {"uri": "8182695102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "00:31:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T00:31:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T00:29:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/entertainment/2749168/", "title": "Actor Ian McKellen, 85, hospitalized after falling off stage in London - The Journal - ExBulletin", "body": "LONDON (AP) Actor Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after falling from a London stage Monday during a fight scene and being hospitalized, a spokesman said.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was in good spirits after doctors said a scan showed he was expected to make a full recovery from his fall, a Noel Coward Theater spokesman said.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran known for playing Gandalf in the the Lord of the Rings film and many stage roles over a six-decade career screamed in pain after the fall, according to a BBC reporter at the theater.\n\nMcKellen played John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nHe lost his footing and fell off the stage during a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy. The fall surprised spectators.\n\nSir Ian appeared to trip as he got off stage to take a more active part in the scene, audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. He gained momentum as he got off the stage, causing him to fall off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, the spokesperson said.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play canceled. Tuesday's production was also canceled to give McKellen time to rest.\n\nMcKellen's career includes playing Magneto in the X-Men films and several Shakespearean characters, including Richard II, {"uri": "2024-06-395850217", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:52:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:52:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:15:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/style/celebrity/celebrity-news/sir-ian-mckellen-to-miss-remainder-of-player-kings-london-dates-following-fall/a1758582136.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen to miss remainder of Player Kings' London dates following fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen's understudy will perform in the play Player Kings for its final London dates while he recuperates following a fall from the stage on Monday.\n\nThe veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account on Thursday said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nHis understudy, Semark, trained at the Royal Academy Of Dramatic Art (Rada) and has credits in TV shows including EastEnders, Doctors, Law & Order UK and The Bill.\n\nAfter his fall, The Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", The actor is reportedly in \"good spirits.\"\n\nDue to the incident, Player Kings' performance on Tuesday (Jun. 18, 2024) has been canceled to allow McKellen to rest. {"uri": "8183219265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "08:37:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T08:37:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T08:36:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/showbiz/celebrity-news/ian-mckellen-rushed-hospital-after-33051527", "title": "Ian McKellen in hospital after falling off stage during London performance", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen was rushed to hospital after a dramatic tumble off stage during a performance of Player Kings at London's Noel Coward Theatre on Monday.\n\nThe acting legend, 85, lost his footing during an intense fight scene and took a fall off the stage. The audience was then swiftly evacuated from the theatre and informed that the evening's performance would be cancelled. A horrified audience member reportedly said he heard Sir Ian crying out: \"Help me, help me\" after the fall.\n\nThe actor then said 'My arms, my arms' and 'Help me, help me' again. Last night Sir Ian was said to be \"in good spirits\" and expected to make a swift recovery - thanks to the \"brilliant\" NHS. A spokesperson for the theatre said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits. The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Important Taylor Swift Dublin ticket update as resale and transfer dates confirmed by Ticketmaster\n\nREAD MORE: Covid Ireland: Symptoms of new FLiRT variant 'like a cold on steroids' as cases skyrocket\n\nSir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production. Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, began its 12-week West End run in April. On Tuesday morning, an eyewitness, Charlie Johnson, spoke to Good Morning Britain about the shock fall.\n\nHe explained: \"As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on and there were strobe light and then it all went dark, at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out the wings and the way the stage works at the Noel Coward, there's a step-down and where the stage meets the audience.\n\nCharlie said to Susanna Reid : \"I think what happened is he took his foot too far off that initial step and lost his balance and went head first into the audience. Within seconds, a blood curling stream arose from the actor and he was clearly in a lot of pain and screaming 'help me.'\"\n\nAudience members took to X, formerly known as Twitter after the incident to share their concern for the legendary actor as they described it as a \"really bad fall\".\n\nOne user shared: \"Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage tonight at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.\" Someone else replied: \"It was a really bad fall. I hope that he is OK.\" Another added: \"Shocking to watch, it was a terrible fall. Hoping he is not badly injured, he seemed to be in great pain.\"\n\nAnother audience member shared: \"Wasn't sure if it was part of the play. He sounded in a bad way. Hope he's ok.\" While another echoed: \"It was very shocking indeed. Praying he is OK.\"\n\nIn the role of John Falstaff, Sir Ian was involved in a battle scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage. As the house lights came up, the actor cried out in pain and staff rushed to his aid. The Mirror has contacted Ian's representatives for comment.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises. A BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage. The actor was heard crying out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley said it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall. Mr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene. He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy. An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service has declined to comment.\n\nPlayer Kings, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nLord Of The Rings icon Sir Ian had recently split from his boyfriend following a year-long romance. He fell for Oscar Conlon-Morrey, 30, when they worked together in a pantomime back in December 2022. In the show, Sir Ian played Mother Goose while Oscar, who is 54 years his junior, portrayed his son Jack.\n\nOscar was quick to tell the world of his joyous new relationship on New Year's Eve in 2023 when he gushed over his romance with the acting legend. \"I saw in 2023 at the house of the new love of my life,\" he wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter.\n\nAccording to insiders at the time of their relationship announcement, Ian was also smitten with the young actor. However, their relationship ended in February with the pair calling it quits on their whirlwind romance.\n\nIan's close friends have always doubted that the legendary actor would ever settle down. At the beginning of Ian and Oscar's romance, one well-known actor opened up about the doubts he harboured about Ian's relationship.\n\n\"Oscar has been telling friends and family of his big plans with McKellen. He's even said he thinks they'll get engaged,\" the unnamed actor told Mail Online at the time. \"McKellen hasn't had a boyfriend in 20 years. He is really not a marriage man.\n\n\"He doesn't want a man living in his home. He enjoys having someone when he is on tour. He gets infatuated; then as quickly as he is into them, he's fallen out with them. There is no way when he is out of the bubble of doing this panto that he is going to have this guy with him in East London, rattling around,\" he added.\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. {"uri": "8186901779", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:19:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:19:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:18:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/news/sir-ian-mckellen-to-miss-remainder-of-player-kings-london-dates-following-fall/a1322414097.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen to miss remainder of Player Kings' London dates following fall", "body": "The veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account on Thursday said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nAfter his fall, Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. {"uri": "8182957764", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "05:26:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T05:26:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T05:24:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/uk-news/statement-released-after-sir-ian-29372482", "title": "Statement released after Sir Ian McKellen badly injured in stage fall", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nSir Ian McKellen is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during a West End performance, a theatre spokesperson has confirmed. The Lord Of The Rings actor, 85, who is currently playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" a spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency. \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\". Sir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises. A BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help. Audience member Paul Critchley told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy. \"An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\" London Ambulance Service has declined to comment.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle. Sir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien. {"uri": "8187120325", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:31:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:31:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:31:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://comicbook.com/irl/news/ian-mckellen-cancels-final-theater-run-stage-fall/", "title": "Ian McKellen Cancels Final Theater Run Performance After Falling From Stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen is taking off the final three Player Kings performances while recuperating from a stage fall.\n\nSir Ian McKellen is taking some time off after falling off a stage earlier this week. The X-Men and The Lord of the Rings star had been performing in the West End production of the play Player Kings on Monday when he reportedly fell off the front of the stage during a fight sequence. The play was halted and the audience evacuated while McKellen was attended to, with the star eventually being hospitalized. The rest of Monday's Player Kings performances were canceled for the day. As for the rest of McKellen's scheduled appearances, those will no longer be happening.\n\nPlayer Kings announced on Thursday morning that David Semark will replace Ian McKellen as Sir John Falstaff in the final three performances, while McKellen recovers from his fall. On the bright side, McKellen is scheduled to return to the Players Kings national tour in Bristol on July 3rd.\n\n\"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June,\" the statement reads. \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nIan McKellen comments on stage performance fall\n\nOn Tuesday, Sir Ian McKellen took to social media to confirm that he is being treated for injuries sustained from his fall during a performance in Player Kings and that he will make a \"complete and speedy\" recovery.\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" McKellen's post on X (formerly Twitter) reads. \"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work. @dobbsCLD\"\n\nIs Ian McKellen Retiring?\n\nIn recent years, some have speculated that the 85-year-old McKellen will eventually retire, after already having a decades-long career on both the stage and screen. In a 2023 interview, McKellen flat-out debunked the possibility, arguing that he wants to \"carry on\" in the industry while he is still healthy and able to.\n\n\"Retire to do what?\" McKellen said at the time. \"I've never been out of work, but I'm aware that any minute now something could happen to me which could prevent me from ever working again. But while the knees hold up and the memory remains intact, why shouldn't I carry on? I really feel I'm quite good at this acting thing now.\"\n\nWill Ian McKellen Return to Lord of the Rings?\n\nEarlier this year, it was confirmed that a new Lord of the Rings movie is in the works, titled Lord of the Rings: The Hunt for Gollum. With Andy Serkis confirmed to direct and reprise his role as Gollum, speculation has swirled over whether or not some of the other Lord of the Rings or The Hobbit cast members would return for the movie as well. When asked about the possibility of reprising his role as Gandalf, McKellen indicated that he would if he's still \"alive.\"\n\n\"But here is no script, there is no offer, there is no plan.\" McKellen added.\n\nPhoto credit Joe Maher/WireImage via Getty", "source": {"uri": "comicbook.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Comicbook"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Audience members were ushered out of the theater and the two-time Oscar nominee was hospitalized. {"uri": "8182975600", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "05:38:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T05:38:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T05:38:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.mylondon.news/news/celebs/ian-mckellen-stage-fall-hospital-29372502", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen taken to hospital after falling off stage during West End show", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during a West End performance, a theatre spokesperson has confirmed. The Lord Of The Rings actor, 85, who is currently playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" a spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency. \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\" The statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\". Sir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nREAD MORE: Police hunt after 79-year-old left with life-changing injuries in Hounslow road rage attack\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises. A BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help. Audience member Paul Critchley told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy. \"An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\" London Ambulance Service has declined to comment.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle. Sir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien. On the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear. His many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.\n\nGet the biggest stories from around London straight to your inbox. Image: Gage Skidmore / Flickr\n\nMulti-award winning actor, gay icon and LGBTQI+ activist Sir Ian McKellen was rushed to hospital on Monday after falling from the stage at London's Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nThe 85 year old was taking part in a battle scene in modern Shakespeare adaptation Player Kings when he fell and cried out in pain.\n\nTwo doctors in the audience attended to him, whilst other theatre-goers were evacuated.\n\nWhile the fall reportedly startled theatregoers, the iconic actor is said to be in recovery and \"in good spirits\".\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\n\"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nAudience member Sandro Trapani told the BBC the incident was \"very shocking\".\n\n\"I really hope that he is going to be alright.\n\n\"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nMcKellen plays the character of John Falstaff in Player Kings, a modern adaptation of {"uri": "8183284713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:19:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:19:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:17:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2472275/ian-mckellen-hospitalized-after-stage-fall-during-london-play", "title": "Ian McKellen hospitalized after stage fall during London play", "body": "Legendary actor Ian McKellen suffered a fall off the stage during a fight scene in \"Player Kings\" at London's Noel Coward Theatre on Monday.\n\nDespite the scare, the 85-year-old actor is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to fully recover, according to theater spokespeople.\n\nMcKellen, renowned for his roles as Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" and numerous Shakespearean characters, was performing as John Falstaff in the adaptation of Henry IV, parts one and two, when he lost his footing.\n\nThe incident, which occurred in a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy, led to McKellen crying out in pain and ultimately being hospitalized.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley described the moment to the PA news agency: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" adding that McKellen \"picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nThe production was immediately halted, and the theater evacuated. Staff and two doctors who were in the audience assisted the ailing actor.\n\nFollowing the incident, the play was canceled for the night, and Tuesday's performance was also called off to allow McKellen time to rest.\n\nOver his six-decade career, McKellen has not only played iconic film roles but has also been a staple in theatre, winning a Tony Award for \"Amadeus\" and several Laurence Olivier Awards.\n\nHe has been nominated for two Oscars and multiple BAFTA awards.\n\nThe Noel Coward Theatre and the production team have not yet announced when the performances will resume.", {"uri": "8186948674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:48:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:48:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:48:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/style/celebrity/celebrity-news/i-look-forward-to-returning-ian-mckellen-to-miss-remainder-of-player-kings-london-dates-following-stage-fall/a777574692.html", "title": "'I look forward to returning' - Ian McKellen to miss remainder of Player Kings' London dates following stage fall", "body": "Ian McKellen's understudy will perform in the play Player Kings for its final London dates while he recuperates following a fall from the stage on Monday.\n\nThe veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account on Thursday said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nToday's News in 90 seconds - 20th June 2024\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nHis understudy, Semark, trained at the Royal Academy Of Dramatic Art (Rada) and has credits in TV shows including EastEnders, Doctors, Law & Order UK and The Bill.\n\nAfter his fall, The Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Mr McKellen thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nMr McKellen's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, {"uri": "8184026279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "17:20:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T17:20:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T17:19:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://popculture.com/celebrity/news/ian-mckellen-hospitalized-after-falling-off-stage-during-performance/", "title": "Ian McKellen Hospitalized After Falling off Stage During Performance", "body": "The actor was hospitalized, but he is expected to make a full recovery in time for Wednesday's matinee performance.\n\nSir Ian McKellen was hospitalized on Monday evening after falling off stage during a live performance. The 85-year-old actor was performing a fight scene at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre in London when he slipped and fell down to the floor level. According to a report by The Independent McKellen is expected to return to performing on Wednesday night.\n\nMcKellen is starring in a production of Player Kings, but things got out of hand on Monday, June 17 when he took a tumble off the stage. McKellen reported cried out in pain and staff rushed to help him. He was transported to the hospital and the audience was asked to leave, with the show left unfinished. McKellen was still in the hospital at the time of the latest update, but sources said he would be cleared in time for the matinee performance on Wednesday. Tuesday's scheduled show was called off altogether.\n\nMcKellen has been performing this show since April, and presumably rehearsing with the cast and crew much longer. Player Kings is a new take on Shakespeare's Henry IV, combining Part One and Part Two of the play for modern audiences. McKellen plays John Falstaff, co-starring with Richard Coyle and Toheeb Jimoh. The adaptation was written by Robert Icke.\n\nA representative for the play told reporters: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits. The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\n\"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support,\" they concluded.\"\n\nMcKellen has been in the headlines quite a bit recently, and has been joking about his age in discussions of the new Lord of the Rings projects. He told The Times that he would be open to reprising his role as Gandalf in another movie \"if I'm alive.\" On a more serious note, he said that he finds himself wondering if each job he takes on will be his last, considering his legacy. He said: \"If you want to know that you are mortal, you just have to look at your address book. And so when a script comes through, or the hint of an offer, you think, 'This might be my last job. No. I'm not doing that.'\"\n\nIf McKellen's speedy recovery from this fall is any indication, he does not need to worry about his health too much. At the time of this writing he is expected to return to the stage on Wednesday. stage during a fight scene and was hospitalized, producers said.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was in \"good spirits\" after doctors said a scan showed he was expected to fully recover from the fall on Monday night, a spokesperson for the production at the Noel Coward Theatre said.\n\nTuesday's performance was canceled but McKellen was expected to be back onstage Wednesday, producers said.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran, who played Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films, cried out in pain after the fall, according to a BBC journalist at the theater.\n\nMcKellen was playing the roguish John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" an adaptation of William Shakespeare's two \"Henry IV\" history plays, directed by Robert Icke.\n\nTheatergoers were startled when McKellen lost his footing and fell off the stage in a scene with Toheeb Jimoh's Prince Hal and Henry Percy, played by Samuel Edward-Cook.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff {"uri": "8187033903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:38:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:38:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:37:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/culture/article/2024/jun/20/ian-mckellen-understudy-final-london-dates-player-kings", "title": "Ian McKellen's understudy to perform in final London dates of Player Kings", "body": "David Semark takes over role of Falstaff for last three shows after veteran actor's fall from the stage on Monday\n\nSir Ian McKellen's understudy will perform in the play Player Kings for its final London dates while he recuperates after a fall from the stage on Monday.\n\nThe veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell off the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account on Thursday said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nSemark trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art and has credits in TV shows including EastEnders, Doctors, Law & Order: UK and The Bill.\n\nAfter McKellen's fall, the Lord Of the Rings star and Olivier award winner thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nHe wrote on X: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support. Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked two doctors, Rachel and Lee, who were \"on hand in the audience\" and the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said McKellen was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were told that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and were asked to leave the premises.\n\nOne audience member, Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nMcKellen's career has spanned more than six decades and he has performed at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is best known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy based on the books by JRR Tolkien. On the stage he has played numerous Shakespearean roles including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a wealth of accolades over the years, including {"uri": "8182663046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:49:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:49:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:48:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.bostonherald.com/2024/06/17/actor-ian-mckellen-85-is-in-good-spirits-and-expected-to-recover-from-fall-off-stage-in-london/", "title": "Actor Ian McKellen, 85, is in 'good spirits' and expected to recover from fall off stage in London", "body": "LONDON (AP) -- Actor Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after he toppled off a London stage Monday during a fight scene and was hospitalized, a spokesperson said.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was in \"good spirits\" after doctors said a scan showed he was expected to fully recover from the fall, a spokesperson for the Noel Coward Theatre said.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran known for playing Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films and many stage roles over a six decade career cried out in pain after the fall, according to a BBC journalist at the theater.\n\nMcKellen was playing John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nHe lost his footing and fell off the stage in a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy. The tumble startled theatergoers.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, the spokesperson said.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play was canceled. The production for Tuesday was also canceled to give McKellen time to rest.\n\nMcKellen's career includes playing Magneto in the X-Men films and several Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth and King Lear.\n\nHe has won a Tony Award for \"Amadeus,\" several Laurence Olivier Awards and has been nominated for two Oscars and several BAFTA awards.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8183330646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:47:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:47:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:46:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2472281/x-men-actor-ian-mckellen-on-his-way-to-recovery-after-falling-off-london-stage", "title": "'X-Men' actor Ian McKellen on his way to recovery", "body": "Veteran actor Sir Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after a dramatic fall from the stage during a performance at the Noel Coward Theatre in London, Arab News reported.\n\nThe incident occurred Monday night during a fight scene in the production of Player Kings, an adaptation of Henry IV, parts one and two, directed by Robert Icke. McKellen, 85, who was portraying John Falstaff, lost his footing and fell off the stage, startling the audience.\n\nAccording to a spokesperson for the theatre, McKellen is in \"good spirits\" following a medical scan that confirmed he is expected to fully recover from the fall. \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" said audience member Paul Critchley, who witnessed the fall. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nThe incident led to the immediate assistance of theatre staff and two doctors who were in attendance. The performance was halted, and the theater was evacuated as a precaution. Monday night's show was canceled, as well as the performance scheduled for Tuesday, to allow McKellen time to rest and recover.\n\nMcKellen's illustrious career spans over six decades, featuring iconic roles such as Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings films and Magneto in the X-Men series. He has also portrayed numerous Shakespearean characters, including Richard II, Macbeth, and King Lear. McKellen has been honored with a Tony Award for Amadeus, multiple Laurence Olivier Awards, and nominations for two Oscars and several BAFTA awards.\n\nDespite the alarming nature of the incident, fans {"uri": "2024-06-393772095", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "17:16:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T17:16:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T16:15:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/style/celebrity/celebrity-news/sir-ian-mckellens-west-end-play-cancelled-until-thursday-after-fall/a25910195.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen's West End play cancelled until Thursday after fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen is \"recovering well\" but his West End show will be cancelled on Wednesday after he fell from the stage earlier this week, the production has said.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor, 85, was portraying John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nSir Ian had been expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance, but the show has now been cancelled until Thursday.\n\nIn a statement posted to X, formerly Twitter, the show said they \"look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready\".\n\n\"The performance on Wednesday 19 June will be cancelled following Ian McKellen's fall during the performance of Player Kings on Monday (17 June)\", the statement said.\n\n\"Bookers for the affected performance will be contacted by their point of purchase directly. We look forward to welcoming audiences back to the Noel Coward Theatre on Thursday 20 June.\n\n\"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement on Monday night that Sir Ian was in \"good spirits\" and is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after receiving a scan at the hospital.\n\nThey also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nThe Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk recalled how Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene before falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to end its run at the Noel Coward Theatre on Saturday.\n\nThe play will then move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July before being staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is best known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.", {"uri": "8184218100", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:10:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:10:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:08:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.comicsands.com/ian-mckellen-falls-off-stage-2668541356.html", "title": "Ian McKellen Thanks Fans For Their 'Kind Words' After Scary Fall Off London Stage Mid-Performance", "body": "The 85-year-old actor was in the middle of a fight scene in 'Player Kings' on Monday night when he lost his footing and fell off the stage.\n\nConcerned fans sent their well wishes to Sir Ian McKellen, the legendary actor best known for playing Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings trilogy, after he lost his footing and fell off the stage while in the middle of a fight scene in Player Kings at London's No\u00ebl Coward Theatre.\n\nThe BBC reported that \"As the house lights came up, the actor cried out and staff rushed to help.\" An audience member described the moment the actor fell as \"very shocking\" but noted McKellen \"was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\" The actor was hospitalized and is expected to make a \"full recovery.\"\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS [National Health Service] team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nAnd McKellen himself took to X to thank fans and provide an update on his well-being.\n\nThe news of the accident quickly went viral, and the actor's devoted fans sent wishes for a speedy recovery.\n\nMcKellen is a seasoned Shakespearean actor, having played roles such as Macbeth, King Lear, Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago, and Richard III. This year, he also portrayed Hamlet in a film adaptation directed by Sean Mathias.\n\nThis isn't the first time McKellen has been injured while performing. In 2018, he had to cancel a matinee performance of King Lear after injuring his leg in a fall while running to catch a train. The tumble startled theatergoers.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play was canceled as medics treated the actor.\n\nFILE - Actor Sir Ian McKellen speaks during the press conference for the film \"Mr. Holmes\" at the 2015 Berlinale Film Festival in Berlin, Germany, Sunday, Feb. 8, 2015. The production is expected to continue running until later this month.\n\nThe Lord of the Rings and X-Men actor began a 12-week run in playwright Icke's adaptation of William Shakespeare's Henry IV Parts 1 and 2 in April, playing the iconic character Falstaff.\n\nMcKellen is a theatre icon, having won six Olivier Awards and a Tony Award. For his screenwork, the actor has been nominated for two Oscars and five BAFTA Awards.\n\nHe insisted last year he has no plans to retire from acting, saying he wants to keep going so long as \"the knees hold up and the memory remains intact\".\n\nYou Might Also Like", "source": {"uri": "ca.movies.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "8184220177", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:11:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:11:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:10:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/showbiz/celebrity-news/ian-mckellen-fall-west-end-33059221", "title": "Ian McKellen breaks silence as West End play cancelled after horror stage fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen has insisted he's \"looking forward to returning to work\" after his West End play was cancelled for several performances following a horror fall.\n\nThe actor, 85, suffered a fall on stage on Monday night and was rushed to hospital. Sir Ian lost his footing during a fight scene as he portrayed John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nSharing his support for the NHS on X, formerly known as Twitter, Sir Ian wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support. Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Sir Ian McKellen health update after 'really bad' fall in front of horrified audience\n\nREAD MORE: Sir Ian McKellen turned down \u00a31million to officiate at Facebook billionaire's wedding: 'Gandalf doesn't do weddings'\n\nFans of the legendary actor shared their support as one wrote: \"Wishing one of my favourite actors of all time a speedy recovery!\" Another commented: \"Fantastic news, be well Sir! #NationalTreasure.\"\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, the production shared a statement confirming the cancellation of Wednesday's performance. The remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances had already been cancelled to allow the actor to rest.\n\n\"The performance on Wednesday 19 June will be cancelled following Ian McKellen's fall during the performance of Player Kings on Monday (17 June),\" the statement read.\n\n\"Bookers for the affected performance will be contacted by their point of purchase directly. We look forward to welcoming audiences back to the Noel Coward Theatre on Thursday 20 June.\n\n\"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nUpdating fans on Sir Ian's health, a spokesperson for the London theatre said: \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\" The statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nAfter the fall on Monday, the audience were evacuated from the theatre and informed the show would be cancelled. Charlie Johnson, who witnessed the incident, spoke to Good Morning Britain about the impact of Sir Ian's fall. He explained: \"As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on and there were strobe lights and then it all went dark; at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out the wings. The way the stage works at the Noel Coward, there's a step down and that's where the stage meets the audience.\n\n\"I think what happened is he took his foot too far off that initial step and lost his balance and went headfirst into the audience. Within seconds, a blood-curdling stream arose from the actor and he was clearly in a lot of pain and screaming 'help me'.\"\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to end its run at the Noel Coward Theatre on Saturday. The play will then move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July before being staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on TikTok , Snapchat , Instagram , Twitter , Facebook , YouTube and Threads .\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. How is the actor now? Here is your answer.\n\nWhy was Ian McKellen hospitalized?\n\nSir Ian McKellen was hospitalized after he seemingly lost his footing and fell off stage while he was performing a fight scene as John Falstaff in the Player Kings production.\n\nThe actor screamed in pain after his fall, leading to West End theater staff members rushing to help him. Following the incident, the audience was sent away and informed that the evening's show had been canceled.\n\nHowever, as per a theater spokesperson, the 85-year-old actor is fine and \"in good spirits.\" The spokesperson further revealed that the actor had a scan and medics claimed that he would make a quick and full recovery. As per BBC, he is expected to return for Wednesday's performance.\n\nAccording to The Guardian, Tuesday evening's Player Kings performance was also canceled to allow The Lord of the Rings actor to rest. The play, which began its run in the West End theater in April, will move to Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSome audience members reacted to Ian McKellen's fall. Among those were Paul Critchley and Sandro Trapani, who both expressed their shock at witnessing it. Trapani also expressed her hope that he would be alright. The rest of the show was cancelled soon after.\n\nHis condition was not immediately known, but a rep told Deadline he was \"doing OK.\" He was expected to make a full recovery, according to the Hollywood Reporter.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of 'Player Kings,'\" a McKellen rep said in a statement. \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\nMcKellen, who played Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" and \"Hobbit\" movies and Magneto in several \"X-Men\" films, has been appearing in \"Player Kings\" since its West End run began in April. The show is scheduled for 12 weeks, but it's unclear if that will be extended or shortened because of McKellen's injuries.\n\nThe thespian frequently appears in productions in London and on Broadway.\n\nHe's won a Tony Award, six Olivier Awards, a Golden Globe Award, five BAFTA Awards and five Emmy Awards. He's also been nominated for two Oscars.\n\nHe was knighted by Queen Elizabeth in 1991.\n\nIn 2018, McKellen was forced to cancel a performance of \"King Lear\" after he hurt his leg while running for a train. {"uri": "8185875464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:47:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:47:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:45:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2472425/sir-ian-mckellen-recovering-after-fall", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen recovering after fall", "body": "Veteran actor Sir Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after a dramatic fall from the stage during a performance at the Noel Coward Theatre in London, Arab News reported. The incident occurred Monday night during a fight scene in the production of Player Kings, an adaptation of Henry IV, parts one and two, directed by Robert Icke. McKellen, 85, who was portraying John Falstaff, lost his footing and fell off the stage, startling the audience.\n\nAccording to a spokesperson for the theatre, McKellen is in \"good spirits\" following a medical scan that confirmed he is expected to fully recover from the fall. \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" said audience member Paul Critchley, who witnessed the fall. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nThe incident led to the immediate assistance of theatre staff and two doctors who were in attendance. The performance was halted, and the theatre was evacuated as a precaution. Monday night's show was cancelled, as well as the performance scheduled for Tuesday, to allow McKellen time to rest and recover.\n\nMcKellen's illustrious career spans over six decades, featuring iconic roles such as Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings films and Magneto in the X-Men series. He has also portrayed numerous Shakespearean characters, including Richard II, Macbeth, and King Lear. McKellen has been honoured with a Tony Award for Amadeus, multiple Laurence Olivier Awards, and nominations for two Oscars and several BAFTA awards.\n\nDespite the alarming nature of the incident, 85-year-old was performing in a production of Player Kings when about two hours into the show he fell off the stage.\n\nActor Ian McKellen has been rushed to hospital after falling off the stage during a West End production of Player Kings.\n\nThe 85-year-old was about two hours into the show in London when he fell, according to audience accounts.\n\nThe crowd was evacuated from the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre and the production was cancelled.\n\nWriter Paul Nero wrote on social media platform X the audience was shocked to witness the fall.\n\nJeremy Chance wrote on Facebook he heard McKellen calling out \"help me\".\n\n\"At first I thought it was some modern theatre theatrics, but apparently not,\" he wrote.\n\nFestival promoter AJ Maddah wrote on X that McKellen looked badly hurt.\n\n\"We are all in shock and tears,\" he said.\n\nA spokesperson for the show told The Stage they were grateful for wellwishes from the audience and public following the show.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the spokesperson told the publication. \"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday, June 18, so Ian can rest.\"\n\nPlayer Kings is an adaptation of Shakespeare's Henry IV by Robert Icke, in which McKellen plays the character Falstaff.", "source": {"uri": "8186917652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:30:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:30:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:28:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/uk-news/sir-ian-mckellen-health-update-29389914", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen health update as theatre company gives sad statement", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nSir Ian McKellen's understudy will perform in the play Player Kings for its final London dates while he recuperates following a fall from the stage on Monday. The veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest. A post on the Player Kings X account on Thursday said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. His understudy, Semark, trained at the Royal Academy Of Dramatic Art (Rada) and has credits in TV shows including EastEnders, Doctors, Law & Order UK and The Bill.\n\nAfter his fall, The Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support. On X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage. The actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises. Audience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said. Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country. On screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus and King Lear. His many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.", "source": {"uri": "walesonline.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "WalesOnline"}, {"uri": "8183275003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:12:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:12:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:11:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/entertainment/2749588/", "title": "Actor Ian McKellen, 85, is in 'good spirits' and expected to recover from London stage fall | National Entertainment - ExBulletin", "body": "LONDON (AP) Actor Ian McKellen is expected to make a full recovery after falling off a London stage during a fight scene and being hospitalized, producers said.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was in good spirits after doctors said a scan showed he was expected to make a full recovery from his fall Monday night, a spokesperson for the production at the Noel Coward Theater said.\n\nTuesday's performance was canceled but McKellen is expected to be back on stage Wednesday, producers said.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran, who played Gandalf in the the Lord of the Rings films, screamed in pain after the fall, according to a BBC journalist present at the theater.\n\nMcKellen played the role of the mischievous John Falstaff in Player Kings, an adaptation of William Shakespeare's two historical plays about Henry IV, directed by Robert Icke.\n\nAudiences were surprised when McKellen lost his footing and fell off the stage in a scene with Prince Hal and Toheeb Jimoh's Henry Percy, played by Samuel Edward-Cook.\n\nSir Ian appeared to trip as he got off stage to take a more active part in the scene, audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. He gained momentum as he got off the stage, causing him to fall off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the actor, the theater said in a statement.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the performance canceled.\n\nMcKellen played Magneto in the X-Men films and is one of Britain's most acclaimed Shakespearean actors, with roles including Richard III, Macbeth and King Lear.\n\nHe has won a Tony Award for Amadeus, several Olivier Awards and has been nominated for two Academy Awards, five Emmy Awards and several BAFTA Awards.", "source":
