{"uri": "8184072588", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "17:59:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T17:59:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T17:58:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/lord-of-the-ringss-gandalf-mckellen-in-hospital-after-near-fatal-stage-accident/articleshow/111092956.cms", "title": "'Lord of the Rings's 'Gandalf', McKellen in hospital after near fatal stage accident", "body": "Veteran British actor Ian McKellen, who played Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" film trilogy, was rushed to hospital late on Monday after falling from the stage during a London theatre performance. McKellen, who also played \"Magneto\" in the X-Men films, is one of Britain's most recognised actors, having won many awards during a 60-year career on stage and screen. London, Jun 18, 2024 -Veteran British actor Ian McKellen, who played Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" film trilogy, was rushed to hospital late on Monday after falling from the stage during a London theatre performance.\n\nThe 85-year-old actor was starring as John Falstaff in a production of \"Player Kings\" at the Noel Coward Theatre in London's West End when he lost his footing during a fight scene.\n\nThe rest of the night's performance was cancelled after McKellen's fall.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS (National Health Service) team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" a theatre spokesperson said on Tuesday.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nHe had been expected to return to the stage on Wednesday but the show has now been cancelled until Thursday, an updated statement read, adding that the star was \"recovering well\".\n\nMcKellen, who also played \"Magneto\" in the X-Men films, is one of Britain's most recognised actors, having won many awards during a 60-year career on stage and screen.\n\n\"Player Kings\" is a return to Shakespeare for McKellen, combining two of the Bard's history plays about King Henry IV.\n\njwp/phz/bc", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\nThank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\n\nMcKellen, known for his roles as Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings trilogy and Magneto in the X-Men films, was in the midst of a performance of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward theater when he lost his footing and fell during a fight scene, the BBC reported. According to the BBC, the theater was evacuated afterwards and the audience was informed the evening show was canceled.\n\n\"I really hope that he is going to be alright,\" audience member Sandro Trapani told the BBC. \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nWriter and broadcaster Paul Nero wrote on X/Twitter earlier today, \"Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage tonight at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.\"\n\nMcKellen plays John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of Shakespeare's Henry IV Parts I and II. It began its 12-week run on the West End in April, and is set to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July, reports The Guardian.\n\nIn addition to his famous film roles, McKellen has long been a stage actor, having played Shakespeare characters Macbeth, King Lear, Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago and Richard III in the past and winning several Olivier Awards. He also recently starred in a film version of Hamlet from director Sean Mathias.\n\nThumbnail credit: Dave Benett/Getty Images for The Wolseley Hospitality Group\n\nAlex Stedman is a Senior News Editor with IGN, overseeing entertainment reporting. {"uri": "2024-06-393944574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "21:02:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T21:02:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:30:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/style/celebrity/celebrity-news/sir-ian-mckellen-looking-forward-to-returning-to-work-after-falling-off-stage/a803590535.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen 'looking forward to returning to work' after falling off stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen has said he is \"looking forward to returning to work\" as he thanked the NHS staff who cared for him after he fell from a West End stage earlier this week.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor, 85, was portraying John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, he said he is \"hugely indebted\" to the medical staff who have assured him his recovery will be \"complete and speedy\".\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" Sir Ian said in the statement posted to X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nSir Ian had been expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance, but it was announced on Tuesday that the show will now not return until Thursday.\n\nIn a statement posted to X, the show added: \"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement on Monday night that Sir Ian was in \"good spirits\" and thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nSir Ian was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nThe Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk recalled how Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene before falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to end its run at the Noel Coward Theatre on Saturday.\n\nThe play will then move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July before being staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is best known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.meathchronicle.ie/2024/06/20/ian-mckellen-to-miss-remainder-of-player-kings-london-dates-following-fall/", "title": "Ian McKellen to miss remainder of Player Kings' London dates following fall | Meath Chronicle", "body": "Ian McKellen to miss remainder of Player Kings' London dates following fall RSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 20 Jun 2024, 12:36 PM Last updated: Thu 20 Jun 2024, 12:52 PM\n\nBy Hannah Roberts, PA Entertainment Reporter\n\nSir Ian McKellen's understudy will perform in the play Player Kings for its final London dates while he recuperates following a fall from the stage on Monday.\n\nThe veteran screen and stage actor, 85, was performing at the Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account on Thursday said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nHis understudy, Semark, trained at the Royal Academy Of Dramatic Art (Rada) and has credits in TV shows including EastEnders, Doctors, Law & Order UK and The Bill.\n\nAfter his fall, The Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner McKellen thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 20 Jun 2024, 12:36 PM fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nThe theatre cancelled the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances to allow him to rest.\n\nA post to the Player Kings X, formerly Twitter, According to the BBC, the theater was evacuated afterwards and the audience was informed the evening show was canceled.\n\nIGN has reached out to McKellen's rep for comment.\n\nIt's not immediately clear whether the beloved actor, known for his roles as Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings trilogy and Magneto in the X-Men films, sustained any injuries. The BBC reports that, \"as the house lights came up, the actor cried out and staff rushed to help.\" One audience member called the incident \"very shocking.\"\n\n\"I really hope that he is going to be alright,\" audience member Sandro Trapani told the BBC. \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nWriter and broadcaster Paul Nero wrote on X/Twitter earlier today, \"Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage tonight at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.\"\n\nMcKellen plays John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of Shakespeare's Henry IV Parts I and II. It began its 12-week run on the West End in April, and is set to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July, reports The Guardian.\n\nIn addition to his famous film roles, McKellen has long been a stage actor, having played Shakespeare characters Macbeth, King Lear, Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago and Richard III in the past and winning several Olivier Awards. A spokesperson for the London theatre expressed gratitude to the audience and general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during the performance of Player Kings.\n\nThey said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nSir Ian is anticipated to return for Wednesday's matinee performance of the production. Following the incident, the remainder of the evening performance was cancelled and audience members were evacuated from the premises.\n\nA BBC journalist who was present at the play reported that the esteemed stage and screen actor fell off the front of the stage during a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy. The actor was heard crying out in pain as staff hurried to his aid.\n\nPaul Critchley, an audience member, described the incident to as a \"shock\". Mr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, recounted: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene. He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy. An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called. It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service has not provided any comment on the incident.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is set to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian's career, spanning over six decades, has seen him perform in theatres nationwide. He is most recognised on screen for his roles as Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, adapted from JRR Tolkien's books. On stage, he has portrayed numerous Shakespearean characters such as Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear. {"uri": "2024-06-395908422", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:39:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:39:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:23:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/ian-mckellen-fall-age-london-player-kings-b2565911.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen will miss rest of London play's dates following fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen will miss the remainder of his dates in London play Player Kings to recover from a fall.\n\nEarlier this week, the 85-year-old Lord of the Rings star was hospitalised after he slipped and fell off the stage during a fight scene at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre. He cried out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nThe show was promptly cancelled and the audience was asked to leave but the veteran performer is expected to appear in Wednesday's matinee after the Tuesday performance was called off.\n\nSir Ian McKellen has said he is having \"physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home\" after three nights in hospital following the fall from the stage.\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" the actor said via his publicist, Clair Dobbs, on X/Twitter on Tuesday (18 June).\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\"\n\nPlayer Kings, which was adapted by Robert Icke, has been at the No\u00ebl Coward since April. Richard Coyle and Ted Lasso's Toheeb Jimoh also star.\n\nIn a statement to The Independent, a representative for the production said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\nThe BBC had earlier reported that one member of the audience described McKellen's fall as \"very shocking\".\n\nPaul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market who was in the audience, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene. He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\"\n\nPlayer Kings is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and McKellen was playing the roguish John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" an adaptation of William Shakespeare's two \"Henry IV\" history plays, directed by Robert Icke.\n\nTheatergoers were startled when McKellen lost his footing and fell off the stage in a fight scene involving Toheeb Jimoh's Prince Hal and Henry Percy, played by Samuel Edward-Cook.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the actor, the theater said in a statement. The theater was evacuated and the performance was canceled.\n\nMcKellen played Magneto in the \"X-Men\" films and is one of Britain's most acclaimed Shakespearean actors, with roles including Richard III, Macbeth and King Lear.\n\nHe has won a Tony Award -- for \"Amadeus\" -- several Olivier Awards, and has been nominated for two Academy Awards, five Emmys and several BAFTA awards.", "source": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/sir-ian-mckellen-looking-forward-to-returning-to-work-after-falling-off-stage-3119152", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen 'looking forward to returning to work' after falling off stage", "body": "The veteran stage and screen actor, 85, toppled off the stage yesterday evening at the Noel Coward Theatre in London's West End\n\nSir Ian McKellen has said he is \"looking forward to returning to work\" after falling off a stage in London's West End and told how he expects to make a \"complete\" and \"speedy\" recovery.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor, 85, toppled off the stage yesterday evening at the Noel Coward Theatre after losing his footing during a fight scene in a production of Player Kings.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, Sir Ian, who plays John Falstaff in the production, said he is \"hugely indebted\" to the medical staff who have assured him his recovery will be \"complete and speedy\".\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAfter the accident, the Lord of the Rings star was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nSir Ian had been expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance, but it was announced on Tuesday that the show will now not return until Thursday.\n\nThe play's London run ends on Saturday, and it will then go on tour to Bristol, Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian did not reveal in his statement what his injuries are and when he will return to work.\n\nIn a statement posted to X, the show added: \"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement on Monday night that Sir Ian was in \"good spirits\" and thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nSir Ian was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley said it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nThe Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk recalled how Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene before falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to end its run at the Noel Coward Theatre on Saturday.", {"uri": "8182658428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:41:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:41:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:40:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://ew.com/ian-mckellen-rushed-to-hospital-after-falling-off-stage-london-8665028", "title": "Ian McKellen rushed to hospital after falling off stage at London theater", "body": "Lauren Huff is a writer at Entertainment Weekly with over a decade of experience covering all facets of the entertainment industry. After graduating with honors from the University of Texas at Austin (Hook 'em, Horns!), Lauren wrote about film, television, awards season, music, and more for the likes of The Hollywood Reporter, Deadline Hollywood, Us Weekly, Awards Circuit, and others before landing at EW in May 2019.\n\nIan McKellen was taken to the hospital after falling off the stage during a performance of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London on Monday night.\n\nAccording to a statement from the theater provided to Entertainment Weekly, the 85-year-old actor is \"in good spirits\" and expected to make a full recovery.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" the statement said. \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\nThe statement added that Tuesday's performance of Player Kings would be canceled to allow McKellen time to rest. \"Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow,\" the theater said. \"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nAccording to the BBC, the incident occurred when McKellen was performing during a fight scene, lost his footing, and fell from the front of the stage. The show was then canceled and the audience evacuated.\n\nPlayer Kings started a planned 12-week run in April. In the production, which is a version of Shakespeare's Henry IV (parts 1 and 2) adapted by Robert Icke, McKellen stars as John Falstaff. The show includes a scene in which Falstaff circles a fight between Prince of Wales and Henry Percy, and it was at this point that McKellen is said to have fallen.\n\nAudience members reported on social media that the actor could be heard crying out in pain. Per the BBC, one audience member called the incident \"very shocking,\" and said they \"really hope that he is going to be all right,\" while noting that the actor \"was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nWant more movie news? Sign up for Entertainment Weekly's free newsletter to get the latest trailers, celebrity interviews, film reviews, and more.\n\nMcKellen is no stranger to Shakespeare, having played the likes of Macbeth, King Lear, Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago, and Richard III on stage. He has received rave reviews so far for his performance in Player Kings, with The Guardian calling his turn a richly complex portrayal.\"\n\nThe venerable actor, who has not been shy about having no desire to retire, recently opened up about his experience playing Falstaff in an interview with The Times of London. \"If you want to know that you are mortal you just have to look at your address book,\" he said. \"And so when a script comes through, or the hint of an offer, you think, 'This might be my last job. No. I'm not doing that.' So if Falstaff is my last job, I'd better get it right, hadn't I?\"", "source": {"uri": "ew.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Entertainment Weekly"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8182672187", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "00:02:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T00:02:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T00:01:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13540475/Sir-Ian-McKellen-screamed-West-End-stage.html", "title": "Ian McKellen screamed 'help me... my arms' after plunging off stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen screamed out in agony as he tripped over props and plunged off the stage during a West End performance last night - leaving shocked theatregoers in tears as the acting legend was rushed to hospital.\n\nAudience members told MailOnline the 85-year-old tumbled off the front of the stage in a 'belly flop fashion' and yelled 'help me... my arms' just before the intermission of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre in London.\n\nThe crowd were evacuated from the theatre at around 8pm while medics were called to the venue - and ticket holders were told the evening show had been cancelled.\n\nRepresentatives for the production confirmed that Sir Ian 'will make a speedy and full recovery' and is in 'good spirits' - but Tuesday's performance has also been cancelled so he can recover.\n\nSir Ian - who plays John Falstaff in the play - was circling a battle scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy, when he tripped and fell off the stage.\n\nAs the house lights came up, the actor best known for his portrayals of Gandalf in the Lord Of The Rings franchise and Magneto in X-Men, cried out in pain as ushers and two medics in the audience rushed to help him.\n\nKol Baker, who was watching the show from the second tier, told MailOnline that Sir Ian had been 'berating the villain and moving around', adding: 'Doing so, he had tripped over some rubble and began to fall across the stage and in almost a belly flop fashion fell off the stage.\n\n'Instantly he screamed and honestly the noises were bone-chilling. [He was shouting] 'help me, help me' followed by 'my arms, my arms' and 'help me, help me' again.\n\nSir Ian is seen performing in a scene of Player Kings, which is on the West End until June 22\n\nAudience members gather outside the Noel Coward theatre after having to evacuate\n\nAmbulances rushed to the West End to help Sir Ian, who is in 'good spirits' and recovering in hospital\n\n'The lights were on so quickly the curtains drawn and within seconds they asked to evacuate the whole auditorium. Whilst leaving the theatre within 10 minutes he was in the back of an ambulance speeding down Trafalgar Square.'\n\nRead More Sir Ian McKellen, 85, is rushed to hospital after falling off stage: Audience left 'in tears'\n\nDescribing how the acting great fell, the 23-year-old explained: 'The scene in question was a warzone so it was broken up bricks and daggers from the battle and the set was all torn up for that scene.'\n\nHe said there was 'so much concern and shock for Sir Ian', adding: 'Everyone I think is just such huge fans of his work and with his age just really empathetic and almost terrified that it could be life-threatening because of his age.'\n\nMr Baker said that Sir Ian had been 'performing amazingly with great vigour' before he fell.\n\nWhen asked how the audience reacted, the theatregoer added: 'Instantly people were standing up, the first two rows completely went to rush to go help Sir Ian and everyone was explaining 'oh my god' and 'that poor man'.\n\n'It was very sincere and so much concern for his well-being,' he added. 'He had made everyone laugh so much this evening.'\n\nA spokesperson for Player Kings told MailOnline: 'Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n'Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n'The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\n'Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.'\n\nSir Ian McKellen (centre) bows at the curtain call during the press night performance of 'Player Kings' at the Noel Coward Theatre on April 11\n\nLondon ambulances are seen rushing to the scene following the shock fall on the West End\n\nImages shared on social media showed people holding white boards as the Lord of the Rings star was moved into the ambulance outside the theatre\n\nThe audience stood outside the theatre after the venue was evacuated following Sir Ian's fall\n\nAn NHS incident response unit is pictured outside the Noel Coward Theatre\n\nSir Ian pictured above in his role as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings: The Two Towers\n\nSir Ian also played Magneto in the movie X-Men. He is pictured above during X2, the second movie he starred in in the franchise, in 2003\n\nAt least three London ambulances were pictured outside the theatre.\n\nPlayer Kings, which started its 12-week West End run in April, is a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two.\n\nMany in the audience shared their shock at the incident on social media last night.\n\nPaul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: 'Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n'He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n'The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\n\n'An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n'It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.'\n\nOthers expressed their horror online. One tweeted: 'Just witnessed an awful accident with Sir Ian McKellen tripping off the stage in London. He seems badly hurt. We are all in shock and tears.'\n\nSir Ian McKellen attends the National Youth Theatre's BIG Night Out after party at Soho House Greek Street on June 3\n\nA sign for Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London staring Sir Ian McKellen, who was taken to hospital after he fell from the stage during a West End performance\n\nRichard Coyle, Sir Ian McKellen and Toheeb Jimoh bow at the curtain call during the press night performance of 'Player Kings' at the Noel Coward Theatre on April 11, 2024 in London\n\nSir Ian McKellen is pictured above in his role as Falstaff in 'Player Kings', based on Shakespeare's Henry IV\n\nIan McKellen pictured as Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)\n\nSir Ian also reprised his role as Gandalf in The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies in 2014\n\nSir Ian, pictured in 2019, lost his footing and fell from the stage during a fight scene\n\nMarvel villain: The English actor has played Magneto in films based on Marvel Comics and is shown in the 2006 film X-Men: The Last Stand\n\nSir Ian McKellen (L) and Brian Cox attend the National Youth Theatre's BIG Night Out after party at Soho House Greek Street on June 03, 2024 in London\n\nAnother wrote: 'Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage tonight at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.'\n\nAnd a third said: 'Shocking to watch, it was a terrible fall. Hoping he is not badly injured, he seemed to be in great pain.'\n\nSandro Trapani told the BBC the incident was 'very shocking', adding: 'I really hope that he is going to be alright. As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.'\n\nSir Ian, who now lives in Limehouse, was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and his father Denis.\n\nHe has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: 'Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.'\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended. When at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Derek Jacobi, David Frost and Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nTV star: Sir Ian is shown with Marilyn Tayerson in a still from the 1972 TV show Country Matters\n\nSir Ian McKellen attends the press night after party for 'Player Kings' at St Martins Lane Hotel on April 11, 2024 in London\n\nIan McKellen (Edward II), James Laurenson (Piers Gaveston) in EDWARD II by Christopher Marlowe directed by Toby Robertson for the Prospect Theatre Company at the Piccadilly Theatre, London in 1970\n\nDonald Sutherland, Ian McKellen, Stockard Channing and Will Smith (right to left) in the film Six Degrees Of Separation in 1994\n\nSir Ian McKellen as David Masterman, and Susan Penhaligon, as Ianthe Forrest in the TV show Country Matters in 1972\n\nIan McKellen, Claire Sweeney and Paul O'Grady on The Paul O'Grady show in 2005\n\nPaul Eddington as Lyov and Sir Ian McKellen as Stefan in the ITV Sunday Night Theatre in 1972\n\nHe shot to international acclaim for his film work, receiving an Academy Award nomination in 1998 for Best Actor after he starred in Gods and Monsters.\n\nIn 2019, the actor topped the The Stage 100 list of most influential people in British Theatre following his UK Tour of Ian McKellen on Stage.\n\nSir Ian was knighted in 1991 for services to theatre and was later appointed a Companion of Honour for services to drama and equality by Queen Elizabeth II in 2008.\n\nSir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nOver the past six decades, Sir Ian has taken on the role of almost every Shakespeare male protagonist - but he was 'never attracted to' playing the character of Falstaff until he was persuaded to by director Robert Icke.\n\nAfter Player Kings' run at the Noel Coward theatre, the show will tour the country. It is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nThe play brings together Shakespeare's two history plays (Henry IV, parts 1 and 2) with the cast including Toheen Jimoh as Hal and Richard Coyle as King Henry IV.\n\nIn April, Sir Ian had to take drastic, and speedy, measures to ensure he made it across London in time for his daily performance of the show - riding on the back of a motorbike.\n\nOne source said at the time: 'Sir Ian tried getting picked up by a car provided by theatre bosses but it took so long to get across town it was pointless.\n\n'One night it took him 90 minutes to get from his home. After that, it was decided a motorbike was the only option.'\n\nIan McKellen starred opposite Martin Freeman in The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies in 2014\n\nIan McKellen (Percy) and Roger Allam (Frank) in the play Frank and Percy in 2023\n\nHalle Berry, Patrick Stewart, Hugh Jackman and Ian McKellen in X-Men: The Last Stand in 2006\n\nSir Ian McKellen starred in Hamlet at the Theatre Royal in Windsor in 2021\n\nRecorded in front of an audience at the Harold Pinter Theatre in January 2020, the production of Ian McKellen on Stage is available to stream online\n\nSir Ian McKellen is pictured above in Hamlet at the Theatre Royal in Windsor in 2021\n\nan McKellen (Sorin) and Frances Barber (Arkadina) in 'The Seagull' by The Royal Shakespeare Company in 2007\n\nMother Goose the pantomime starring Ian McKellen as Mother Goose and John Bishop as Vic Goose at the Theatre Royal Brighton in 2022\n\nHe has also previously had to pull out of performances due to injuries.\n\nIn 2018, he had to apologise to theatre-goers after a leg injury forced him to pull out of a performance of King Lear. Sir Ian had been rushing to catch the train and pulled his calf muscle.\n\nLast September, Sir Ian opened up about his life changing 'overnight' when he came out as gay 35 years ago. Very few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: 'I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.' Section 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: 'The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.'\n\nHe told Variety about coming out in 1988: 'Almost overnight everything in my life changed for the better - my relationships with people and my whole attitude toward acting changed.'\n\nSir Ian told how coming out actually had a huge impact on his acting work.\n\nHe explained: 'The kind of acting that I had been good at was all about disguise - adopting funny voices and odd walks.\n\nLast September, Sir Ian (pictured in 1978) opened up about his life changing 'overnight' when he came out as gay 35 years ago. Very few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents\n\nPeople demonstrate against Clause 28 of the Local Government Act 1988 which states that a local authority 'shall not intentionally promote homosexuality or publish material with the intention of promoting homosexuality', in February 1988, with Sir Ian and Michael Cashman in the front row\n\nIan McKellen and Sir Patrick Stewart kiss on the red carpet during the 'Star Trek Picard' UK Premiere at Odeon Luxe Leicester Square on January 15, 2020 in London\n\nMother Goose the pantomime starring Ian McKellen as Mother Goose and John Bishop as Vic Goose at the Theatre Royal Brighton in 2022\n\nIan McKellen is pictured above at the Clause 28 March in Manchester in February 1988\n\n'It was about lying to the world. I was no longer in the situation where I was running along beside the character explaining it to the audience. I just became the character.'\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: 'What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.'\n\nIan also said he felt that it was difficult for non-gay people to relate to his struggle.\n\nThe veteran actor said: 'People who are not gay just simply don't know how it damages you to be lying about what you are and ashamed of yourself.\n\n'I was brought up at a time when it was illegal for me to have sex with a man. And that was not that long ago,' he added.\n\nHe previously revealed how he had to 'swear he wasn't gay' in order to work on Broadway in the 1960s.\n\nJust last week, Sir Ian made headlines after he took a swipe at former US president Donald Trump - accusing him of being 'one of the worst public speakers there has ever been'.\n\nHe told The Times: 'Trump is an absolute bewilderment. I haven't seen him live. But he's one of the worst public speakers there has ever been. Whether he's reading a script or not, it's so patent what he is.'", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The tumble startled theatergoers.\n\n\"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene,\" audience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency, saying it was a shock. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\"\n\nStaff and two doctors in the audience helped the ailing actor, the spokesperson said.\n\nThe theater was evacuated and the play was canceled. The production for Tuesday was also canceled to give McKellen time to rest.\n\nMcKellen's career includes playing Magneto in the X-Men films and several Shakespearean characters including Richard II, {"uri": "8182642615", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:21:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:21:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:18:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/sir-ian-mckellen-speedy-full-231240459.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen to 'make a speedy and full recovery' after theatre stage fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during a West End performance, a theatre spokesperson has confirmed.\n\nThe Lord Of The Rings actor, 85, who is currently playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" a spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the veteran stage and screen actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\n\n\"An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nLondon Ambulance Service has declined to comment.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits The theater said those affected would be contacted about refunds or exchanges. McKellen is expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance.\n\nThe fall took place during a battle scene in the play. After McKellen fell off the stage, the performance was halted, and the audience was dismissed from the theater.\n\nThe acclaimed British actor has had a prolific career on stage and screen over 60 years. He is perhaps best known for his roles as Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings and Hobbit film series and as Magneto in the X-Men movies.\n\nMcKellen has frequently returned to the classical theater, playing leads like King Lear and Hamlet well into his 80s. {"uri": "8183463277", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:09:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:09:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.thesouthafrican.com/lifestyle/celeb-news/lord-of-the-rings-actor-hospitalised-after-falling-off-london-stage/", "title": "Lord of the Rings actor hospitalised after falling off London stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen recovering in hospital. Image by Wikimedia Commons\n\nSir Ian McKellen, who played Gandalf in the extremely popular Lord of the Rings movies, fell off a London stage during a fight scene in a play after tripping over stage props. The actor was hospitalised, but is recovering well.\n\nSir Ian McKellen, 85, screamed out in agony as he tripped over props and plunged off the stage during a West End performance on 17 June. A staff member rushed on stage to help him. Many of the shocked audience members were in tears as medics took the acting legend to hospital.\n\nMcKellen tumbled off the front of the stage in a 'belly flop fashion' just before the intermission of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre in London. Player Kings is a production of Shakespeare's Henry IV Parts One and Two. It started its 12-week West End run in April. At first, audience members thought it was part of the performance, until the actor screamed out.\n\nTheatre staff evacuated the audience members from the theatre at around 20:00 while medical personnel assisted the actor. Luckily, there were two doctors present in the audience who also assisted. The actor was hospitalised. The theatre consequently cancelled the show, according to Daily Mail. They also cancelled the next show, scheduled for 18 June.\n\nBBC reported that McKellen is in 'good spirits' after being hospitalised. A theatre spokesperson said that he had undergone a scan and medics said that they expect him to make a speedy and full recovery. If everything goes well, he will be back on stage on Wednesday, 19 June, for a matinee performance of the play.\n\nThe stage and screen veteran is one of Britain's most acclaimed Shakespearean actors, with roles including Richard III, Macbeth, and King Lear. However, his talents extent beyond Shakespearean roles. He is very well-known for his role as Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings movies and played Magneto in the X-Men movies. This shows how versatile he is as an actor.\n\nDefinitely a legend, McKellen has been in over 60 feature films in a career that spans seven decades. He has won a Tony Award for Amadeus as well as several Olivier Awards. It has been confirmed he will not appear when the run of Player Kings resumes on Thursday night, 20 June.\n\nMcKellen will be replaced by his understudy David Semark in the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances.\n\nSo what is McKellen doing in his recovery? We know The Lord of the Rings star has revealed he is doing physiotherapy, light exercise and taking lots of rest.\n\nHe said in a statement sent on his behalf by his publicist Clair Dobbs said: \"After three nights in hospital, the effects of my fall onstage have been fully analysed and I'm now having physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home.\n\n\"Meanwhile, my part in Player Kings is filled by the redoubtable David Semark supported by Robert Icke's amazing production and cast.\"\n\nMcKellen spent three nights in hospital falling the fall. Although the extent of his injuries are not known. He has now been discharged and is resting at home. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nWe don't know when McKellen will definitely be back on stage. The actor appeared conscious as he was assisted by staff, attendee Sandro Trapani told BBC News.\n\nAudience members, who were ushered out of the theater, were rattled by the incident, according to broadcaster Paul Nero. The night's performance was canceled.\n\nThe production also canceled Tuesday's performance so McKellen could rest, the theater told The Times. {"uri": "8187001978", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:20:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:20:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:19:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/entertainment/showbiz/2024/06/20/sir-ian-mckellen-having-physiotherapy-as-he-takes-break-from-play-after-fall/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen having physiotherapy as he takes break from play after fall", "body": "The veteran actor is recuperating following the accident on Monday.\n\nSir Ian McKellen has revealed he is having physiotherapy while he takes a break from performing following a fall from a West End stage on Monday.\n\nThe final London dates of the production, Player Kings, will see Sir Ian's understudy take on the role of Falstaff, while the veteran actor recuperates following the accident.\n\nA statement sent on his behalf by his publicist Clair Dobbs to the PA news agency said: \"After three nights in hospital, the effects of my fall onstage have been fully analysed and I'm now having physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home.\n\n\"Meanwhile, my part in Player Kings is filled by the redoubtable David Semark supported by Robert Icke's amazing production and cast. The many messages of love and support will, I am sure, aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me.\"\n\nThe screen and stage actor, 85, was taken to hospital on June 17 to receive treatment after he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nThe theatre cancelled the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances to allow him to rest.\n\nA post to the Player Kings X, formerly Twitter, account on Thursday said that actor David Semark would take his place for the remainder of the London dates.\n\nIt said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nSir Ian's understudy, Semark, trained at the Royal Academy Of Dramatic Art (Rada) and has credits in TV shows including EastEnders, Doctors, Law & Order UK and The Bill.\n\nAfter his fall, The Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.", "source": {"uri": "shropshirestar.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-06-396236351", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:35:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:35:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:14:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/world/globaltalk/ian-mckellen-stage-fall/2024/06/20/id/1169506/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen Won't Return to London Play Following Fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen will sit out the remaining dates of his London production, \"Player Kings,\" as he recovers from a fall he suffered on stage earlier this week.\n\nThe 85-year-old veteran actor was performing a fight scene when the incident occurred. He has been portraying John Falstaff in the staging of William Shakespeare's \"Henry IV\" parts one and two, at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nAccording to the Independent, McKellen slipped and fell from the stage. The outlet noted that he cried out in pain as crew members rushed to assist him.\n\nThe Tuesday show was canceled and audience members were asked to leave. McKellen was initially expected to make Wednesday's matinee but it has since been revealed that he will not feature in the final three performances of the production in the West End.\n\nThe Noel Coward Theatre released a statement to Deadline revealing that David Semark will replace McKellen as the actor \"recuperates.\" McKellen will return in two weeks when the production begins a national tour.\n\nMcKellen spent three nights in hospital and is having \"physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home,\" the Independent reported, citing the \"Lord of the Rings\" star.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work,\" he wrote in a statement on social media.\n\nA representative for the production released a statement addressing the incident to the Independent.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" it added.\n\nZoe Papadakis \u2709\n\nZoe Papadakis is a Newsmax writer based in South Africa with two decades of experience specializing in media and entertainment. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew,\" Paul Nero, a writer and broadcaster, wrote on X.\n\nSomeone else responded to his tweet, saying McKellen \"sounded in a bad way\".\n\nIn a statement shared with Page Six, representatives for McKellen thanked the \"audience and the general public for their well wishes\" and assured fans that he is on the mend.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the statement read.\n\nThey also thanked two doctors who were in the audience and sprung into action.\n\nHowever, producers \"made the decision to cancel the performance on June 18 so Ian can rest\".\n\nPlayer Kings -- a three-hour-plus adaptation of Shakespeare's Henry IV, Part I and Part II -- started its 12-week run in April 2024.\n\nAs of now, the play is expected to run until Saturday in the West End before going on tour throughout the United Kingdom until the end of July.\n\nThis is the actor's sixth stage role in the three years since theatres reopened following the Covid shutdown.\n\nMcKellen told the Times earlier this month that he looks at every role like it could be his last now that he is in his mid-80s.\n\n\"If you want to know that you are mortal you just have to look at your address book,\" he told the outlet.\n\n\"And so when a script comes through, or the hint of an offer, you think, 'This might be my last job. {"uri": "8182644844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:23:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:23:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:21:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/entertainment/2024/06/18/sir-ian-mckellen-to-make-a-speedy-and-full-recovery-after-theatre-stage-fall/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen to 'make a speedy and full recovery' after theatre stage fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen is in \"good spirits\" and is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during a West End performance, a theatre spokesperson has confirmed.\n\nThe Lord Of The Rings actor, 85, who is currently playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" a spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\n\n\"An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn
