{"uri": "8183073875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "06:58:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T06:58:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T06:56:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13541397/Sir-Ian-McKellen-Player-Kings-London-theatre-injured-witnesses.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen, 85, lost balance and went 'head first' into audience", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen lost his balance and went 'head first' into an audience before letting out a 'blood-curdling scream' during a West End performance last night.\n\nThe 85-year-old actor tumbled off the front of the stage just before the interval of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre in London and was taken to hospital.\n\nThe crowd were evacuated from the theatre at about 8pm while paramedics were called - and ticket holders were told the evening show had been cancelled.\n\nShow bosses said that Sir Ian 'will make a speedy and full recovery' and is in 'good spirits' - but tonight's performance has also been cancelled so he can rest.\n\nSir Ian - who plays John Falstaff in the play - was circling a battle scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy, when he tripped and fell off the stage.\n\nAs the house lights came up, the actor known for Lord Of The Rings and X-Men cried out in pain as ushers and two medics in the audience rushed to help him.\n\nCharlie Johnson, a journalist for the Kingston Courier who was in the audience, told ITV: 'As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on.\n\n'There were strobe lights and then it all went dark, at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out from the wings. And the way the stage works at the Noel Coward is there's sort of a step down just as the stage meets the audience.\n\n'I think what happened was he put his foot too far, sort of went off that initial step, at which point he lost his balance and pretty much just went head first into the audience.\n\n'And within seconds a blood-curdling scream arose from the actor. He was clearly in a lot of pain, he was screaming 'help me'.'\n\nSir Ian McKellen (centre) bows at the curtain call during the press night performance of 'Player Kings' at the Noel Coward Theatre on April 11\n\nSir Ian is seen performing in a scene of Player Kings, which is on the West End until June 22\n\nAudience members gather outside the Noel Coward theatre after having to evacuate\n\nAmbulances rushed to the West End to help Sir Ian, who is in 'good spirits' and recovering in hospital\n\nPictured is an interior shot of the theatre showing the stage Sir Ian fell from\n\nCharlie Johnson, a journalist for the Kingston Courier who was in the audience last night, told ITV that a 'blood-curdling scream arose from the actor'\n\nKol Baker, who was watching the show from the second tier, told MailOnline that Sir Ian had been 'berating the villain and moving around' during the scene when he 'tripped over' some props and fell off the stage 'in almost a belly flop fashion'.\n\n'Instantly he screamed and honestly the noises were bone-chilling,' the 23-year-old added - as he recalled Sir Ian yelling 'help me, help me' followed by 'my arms, my arms' and 'help me, help me' again.\n\n'The lights were on so quickly the curtains drawn and within seconds they asked to evacuate the whole auditorium. Whilst leaving the theatre within 10 minutes he was in the back of an ambulance speeding down Trafalgar Square.'\n\nRead More Sir Ian McKellen, 85, is rushed to hospital after falling off stage: Audience left 'in tears'\n\nDescribing what caused the actor to fall, he explained: 'The scene in question was a warzone so there was broken up bricks and daggers from the battle and the set which was all torn up for that scene.'\n\nHe said there was 'so much concern and shock for Sir Ian', adding: 'Everyone I think is just such huge fans of his work and with his age just really empathetic and almost terrified that it could be life-threatening because of his age.'\n\nMr Baker said that Sir Ian had been 'performing amazingly with great vigour' before he fell.\n\nWhen asked how the audience reacted, the theatregoer added: 'Instantly people were standing up, the first two rows completely went to rush to go help Sir Ian and everyone was explaining 'oh my god' and 'that poor man'.\n\n'It was very sincere and so much concern for his well-being,' he added. 'He had made everyone laugh so much this evening.'\n\nA spokesperson for Player Kings told MailOnline: 'Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n'Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n'The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\n'Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.'\n\nLondon ambulances are seen rushing to the scene following the shock fall on the West End\n\nImages shared on social media showed people holding white boards as the Lord of the Rings star was moved into the ambulance outside the theatre\n\nThe audience stood outside the theatre after the venue was evacuated following Sir Ian's fall\n\nAn NHS incident response unit is pictured outside the Noel Coward Theatre\n\nSir Ian pictured above in his role as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings: The Two Towers\n\nSir Ian also played Magneto in the movie X-Men. He is pictured above during X2, the second movie he starred in in the franchise, in 2003\n\nAt least three London ambulances were pictured outside the theatre.\n\nPlayer Kings, which started its 12-week West End run in April, is a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two.\n\nMany in the audience shared their shock at the incident on social media last night.\n\nPaul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: 'Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n'He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n'The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\n\n'An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n'It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.'\n\nOthers expressed their horror online. One tweeted: 'Just witnessed an awful accident with Sir Ian McKellen tripping off the stage in London. He seems badly hurt. We are all in shock and tears.'\n\nSir Ian McKellen attends the National Youth Theatre's BIG Night Out after party at Soho House Greek Street on June 3\n\nA sign for Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London staring Sir Ian McKellen, who was taken to hospital after he fell from the stage during a West End performance\n\nRichard Coyle, Sir Ian McKellen and Toheeb Jimoh bow at the curtain call during the press night performance of 'Player Kings' at the Noel Coward Theatre on April 11, 2024 in London\n\nSir Ian McKellen is pictured above in his role as Falstaff in 'Player Kings', based on Shakespeare's Henry IV\n\nIan McKellen pictured as Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)\n\nSir Ian also reprised his role as Gandalf in The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies in 2014\n\nSir Ian, pictured in 2019, lost his footing and fell from the stage during a fight scene\n\nMarvel villain: The English actor has played Magneto in films based on Marvel Comics and is shown in the 2006 film X-Men: The Last Stand\n\nSir Ian McKellen (L) and Brian Cox attend the National Youth Theatre's BIG Night Out after party at Soho House Greek Street on June 03, 2024 in London\n\nAnother wrote: 'Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage tonight at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.'\n\nAnd a third said: 'Shocking to watch, it was a terrible fall. Hoping he is not badly injured, he seemed to be in great pain.'\n\nSandro Trapani told the BBC the incident was 'very shocking', adding: 'I really hope that he is going to be alright. As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.'\n\nSir Ian, who now lives in Limehouse, was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and his father Denis.\n\nHe has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: 'Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.'\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended. When at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Derek Jacobi, David Frost and Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nTV star: Sir Ian is shown with Marilyn Tayerson in a still from the 1972 TV show Country Matters\n\nSir Ian McKellen attends the press night after party for 'Player Kings' at St Martins Lane Hotel on April 11, 2024 in London\n\nIan McKellen (Edward II), James Laurenson (Piers Gaveston) in EDWARD II by Christopher Marlowe directed by Toby Robertson for the Prospect Theatre Company at the Piccadilly Theatre, London in 1970\n\nDonald Sutherland, Ian McKellen, Stockard Channing and Will Smith (right to left) in the film Six Degrees Of Separation in 1994\n\nSir Ian McKellen as David Masterman, and Susan Penhaligon, as Ianthe Forrest in the TV show Country Matters in 1972\n\nIan McKellen, Claire Sweeney and Paul O'Grady on The Paul O'Grady show in 2005\n\nPaul Eddington as Lyov and Sir Ian McKellen as Stefan in the ITV Sunday Night Theatre in 1972\n\nHe shot to international acclaim for his film work, receiving an Academy Award nomination in 1998 for Best Actor after he starred in Gods and Monsters.\n\nIn 2019, the actor topped the The Stage 100 list of most influential people in British Theatre following his UK Tour of Ian McKellen on Stage.\n\nSir Ian was knighted in 1991 for services to theatre and was later appointed a Companion of Honour for services to drama and equality by Queen Elizabeth II in 2008.\n\nSir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nOver the past six decades, Sir Ian has taken on the role of almost every Shakespeare male protagonist - but he was 'never attracted to' playing the character of Falstaff until he was persuaded to by director Robert Icke.\n\nAfter Player Kings' run at the Noel Coward theatre, the show will tour the country. It is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nThe play brings together Shakespeare's two history plays (Henry IV, parts 1 and 2) with the cast including Toheen Jimoh as Hal and Richard Coyle as King Henry IV.\n\nIn April, Sir Ian had to take drastic, and speedy, measures to ensure he made it across London in time for his daily performance of the show - riding on the back of a motorbike.\n\nOne source said at the time: 'Sir Ian tried getting picked up by a car provided by theatre bosses but it took so long to get across town it was pointless.\n\n'One night it took him 90 minutes to get from his home. After that, it was decided a motorbike was the only option.'\n\nIan McKellen starred opposite Martin Freeman in The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies in 2014\n\nIan McKellen (Percy) and Roger Allam (Frank) in the play Frank and Percy in 2023\n\nHalle Berry, Patrick Stewart, Hugh Jackman and Ian McKellen in X-Men: The Last Stand in 2006\n\nSir Ian McKellen starred in Hamlet at the Theatre Royal in Windsor in 2021\n\nRecorded in front of an audience at the Harold Pinter Theatre in January 2020, the production of Ian McKellen on Stage is available to stream online\n\nSir Ian McKellen is pictured above in Hamlet at the Theatre Royal in Windsor in 2021\n\nan McKellen (Sorin) and Frances Barber (Arkadina) in 'The Seagull' by The Royal Shakespeare Company in 2007\n\nMother Goose the pantomime starring Ian McKellen as Mother Goose and John Bishop as Vic Goose at the Theatre Royal Brighton in 2022\n\nHe has also previously had to pull out of performances due to injuries.\n\nIn 2018, he had to apologise to theatre-goers after a leg injury forced him to pull out of a performance of King Lear. Sir Ian had been rushing to catch the train and pulled his calf muscle.\n\nLast September, Sir Ian opened up about his life changing 'overnight' when he came out as gay 35 years ago. Very few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: 'I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.' Section 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: 'The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.'\n\nHe told Variety about coming out in 1988: 'Almost overnight everything in my life changed for the better - my relationships with people and my whole attitude toward acting changed.'\n\nSir Ian told how coming out actually had a huge impact on his acting work.\n\nHe explained: 'The kind of acting that I had been good at was all about disguise - adopting funny voices and odd walks.\n\nLast September, Sir Ian (pictured in 1978) opened up about his life changing 'overnight' when he came out as gay 35 years ago. Very few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents\n\nPeople demonstrate against Clause 28 of the Local Government Act 1988 which states that a local authority 'shall not intentionally promote homosexuality or publish material with the intention of promoting homosexuality', in February 1988, with Sir Ian and Michael Cashman in the front row\n\nIan McKellen and Sir Patrick Stewart kiss on the red carpet during the 'Star Trek Picard' UK Premiere at Odeon Luxe Leicester Square on January 15, 2020 in London\n\nMother Goose the pantomime starring Ian McKellen as Mother Goose and John Bishop as Vic Goose at the Theatre Royal Brighton in 2022\n\nIan McKellen is pictured above at the Clause 28 March in Manchester in February 1988\n\n'It was about lying to the world. I was no longer in the situation where I was running along beside the character explaining it to the audience. I just became the character.'\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: 'What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.'\n\nIan also said he felt that it was difficult for non-gay people to relate to his struggle.\n\nThe veteran actor said: 'People who are not gay just simply don't know how it damages you to be lying about what you are and ashamed of yourself.\n\n'I was brought up at a time when it was illegal for me to have sex with a man. And that was not that long ago,' he added.\n\nHe previously revealed how he had to 'swear he wasn't gay' in order to work on Broadway in the 1960s.\n\nJust last week, Sir Ian made headlines after he took a swipe at former US president Donald Trump - accusing him of being 'one of the worst public speakers there has ever been'.\n\nHe told The Times: 'Trump is an absolute bewilderment. I haven't seen him live. But he's one of the worst public speakers there has ever been. Whether he's reading a script or not, it's so patent what he is.'", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-395938085", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:02:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:02:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:15:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/style/celebrity/celebrity-news/sir-ian-mckellen-having-physiotherapy-as-he-takes-break-from-play-after-fall/a363960341.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen having physiotherapy as he takes break from play after fall", "body": "The final London dates of the production, Player Kings, will see Sir Ian's understudy take on the role of Falstaff while the veteran actor recuperates following the accident.\n\nA statement sent on his behalf by his publicist Clair Dobbs to the PA news agency said: \"After three nights in hospital, the effects of my fall onstage have been fully analysed and I'm now having physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home.\n\n\"Meanwhile, my part in Player Kings is filled by the redoubtable David Semark supported by Robert Icke's amazing production and cast.\n\n\"The many messages of love and support will, I am sure, aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me.\"\n\nThe screen and stage actor, 85, was taken to hospital on June 17 to receive treatment after he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nThe remainder of the night's show was cancelled following the fall.\n\nSir Ian was expected to make a return for Wednesday's performance before it was announced on Tuesday that the show would not return until Thursday evening.\n\nA post to the Player Kings X, formerly Twitter, account on Thursday said that actor David Semark would take his place for the remainder of the London dates.\n\nIt said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nSir Ian's understudy, Semark, trained at the Royal Academy Of Dramatic Art (Rada) and has credits in TV shows including EastEnders, Doctors, Law & Order UK and The Bill.\n\nAfter his fall, The Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to PA: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", (Isabel Infantes/PA Wire via Zuma Press/TNS)\n\nIan McKellen is on the mend after falling off the stage during a performance at London's Noel Coward Theatre. The 85-year-old actor was taken to a hospital after the fall.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant (National Health Service) team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery, and Ian is in good spirits,\" according to a statement to the Los Angeles Times by the theater. There were no details on any injuries he may have suffered.\n\nThe \"Lord of the Rings\" and \"X-Men\" actor fell after losing his footing during a battle scene between two other actors in \"Player Kings,\" in which he portrays John Falstaff, according to BBC News.\n\nAfter toppling from the front of the stage, McKellen reportedly cried out as the lights came up in the venue. {"uri": "2024-06-395000593", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:20:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:20:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:47:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/thewire/ian-mckellen-stage-fall/2024/06/19/id/1169341/", "title": "Ian McKellen 'Looking Forward' to Working After Falling Off Stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen has shared a health update after falling off stage mid-performance at a London theater and then being rushed to hospital Monday.\n\nThe actor, 85, is currently portraying John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" a staging of William Shakespeare's \"Henry IV\" parts one and two, at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre. The production was adapted by Robert Icke and stars Richard Coyle and \"Ted Lasso\" actor Toheeb Jimoh, according to the Independent.\n\nMcKellen sustained injuries when, during a fight scene, he slipped and fell from the stage. Taking to social media Tuesday, McKellen said he was feeling positive about his recovery and \"looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work,\" he wrote in a statement.\n\nA representative for the production released a statement addressing the incident to the Independent.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" the statement read.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" it added.\n\nPerformances were canceled as McKellen recovers.\n\n\"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support,\" the statement added.\n\nSpeaking with the BBC shortly after the fall, a Methodist minister from Downham Market who was in the audience described how McKellen \"seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\"\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience,\" he said.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front-of-house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\"\n\n\"Player Kings\" is scheduled to transfer to the Bristol Hippodrome in July, with additional performances planned in Birmingham, Norwich, and Newcastle.\n\nZoe Papadakis \u2709\n\nZoe Papadakis is a Newsmax writer based in South Africa with two decades of experience specializing in media and entertainment. {"uri": "8185957683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:12:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:12:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:11:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.themarysue.com/get-better-soon-ian-mckellen-actor-takes-a-tumble-onstage/", "title": "We're Sending Every Good Vibe We Have to Ian McKellen After the Actor Takes a Tumble Onstage", "body": "Actor Sir Ian McKellen was hospitalized after falling off stage during a performance of Player Kings on Monday, June 17. The 85-year-old actor was performing the role of John Falstaff when the incident happened, resulting in the play being immediately stopped, the audience sent away, and McKellen rushed to hospital.\n\nThe accident occurred at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre during a battle scene between the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy in Robert Icke's modern adaptation of Henry IV. Audience members were noted to have seen McKellen trip near the front of the stage before he fell off the edge. The house lights immediately went up and staff rushed to help the actor as he reportedly cried out. According to The Guardian McKellen is recovering well and is \"in good spirits\" and expected to make \"a speedy and full recovery.\" Tuesday night's performance was also canceled in order to allow the actor to rest. He was initially expected to be back on the stage for Wednesday's matinee but that performance was also canceled.\n\nThe actor released a statement through his personal publicist Clair Dobbs which was reported by Deadline. The statement read,\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support. Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAccording to Deadline, McKellen has suffered a fractured wrist from his fall.\n\nAudience members were obviously shocked and concerned to witness the actor's accident. One audience member, Sandro Trapani, spoke to the BBC about the accident saying it was \"very shocking,\" adding \"I really hope that he is going to be all right. As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nMcKellen's career as an actor has spanned over 60 years, working across stage, television, and film. His most prominent roles on the silver screen include that of the complex antagonist Magneto in the X-Men franchise as well as his career-defining turn as the wizard Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit trilogy. On stage, McKellen has played some of the most famous characters in English theatre history including numerous Shakespearean roles such as King Lear, Coriolanus, Richard II, and Macbeth.\n\nThis isn't the first time an injury has interfered with the actor's work. Five years ago, he was forced to cancel a performance of King Lear after injuring his leg whilst running for the train. Rather than allow the audience to be left with nothing, he instead sat on the edge of the stage and opened up a Q&A session. {"uri": "8183256452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:01:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:01:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:00:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://faroutmagazine.co.uk/ian-mckellen-is-hospitalised-after-west-end-accident/", "title": "Ian McKellen is hospitalised after West End accident", "body": "Veteran actor Ian McKellen has been hospitalised after falling off the front of the stage while performing in a play on the West End.\n\nLuckily, McKellen is doing okay. A representative for the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre has stated that the star is set to make a \"speedy recovery.\" The incident occurred during a performance of Player Kings, a Shakespeare adaptation which includes Part One and Part Two of Henry IV. McKellen was starring as John Falstaff, a friend of the future King Henry V, also known as Prince Hal.\n\nUnfortunately, the 85-year-old actor slipped while participating in a battle scene and fell off the front of the stage. He reportedly cried out for help and screamed in pain as the audience watched on in horror. McKellen was assisted by several members of the theatre staff, who sent him to the hospital to be checked over.\n\nThe theatre's statement congratulated everyone who had sent McKellen kind messages. \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" they wrote, adding, \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\nThey have also notified those with tickets for the upcoming performance of Player Kings that it will not be going ahead: \"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe actor is no stranger to Shakespeare, having got his start as an actor by starring in the Bard's plays while at Cambridge University. One of his earliest notable roles was Justice Shallow in Henry IV.\n\nFrom there, he continued to star in many plays on the West End, eventually becoming a prominent member of the Royal Shakespeare Company. He has starred in everything from Romeo and Juliet to Macbeth and Othello.\n\nIn recent years, he has played Hamlet at the Theatre Royal in Windsor and King Lear at the Duke of York's Theatre. {"uri": "8182642614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:24:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:24:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:18:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/ian-mckellen-hospitalized-falling-off-231302905.html", "title": "Ian McKellen Hospitalized After Falling Off Stage in London", "body": "Ian McKellen, 85, was hospitalized in London after falling off the stage during a production of \"Player Kings\" at a West End Theatre. The actor lost his footing during a battle scene and fell off the front of the stage, the BBC reported on Monday.\n\nA member of the audience told the BBC that McKellen was conscious after his fall and cried out for help. The house lights came up and staff rushed to his side, with two doctors who were in the audience also providing aid, according to the show's producers.\n\nThe producers issued an encouraging update following McKellen's hospitalization, indicating that he was expected to quickly recover.\n\nThey wrote, \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow,\" the statement continued. \"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nPlaygoer Sandro Trapani told the BBC that the accident was \"very shocking\" and added, \"I really hope that he is going to be all right.\"\n\nMcKellen is playing John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" which is an adaptation by Robert Icke that combines both parts of Shakespeare's \"Henry IV\" plays.\n\nThe production launched its 12-week run at the Noel Coward Theatre in April and costars Toheeb Jimoh of \"Ted Lasso\" as Hal and Richard Coyle of \"The Chilling Adventures of Sabrina\" as King Henry IV.\n\nDuring McKellen's long career, he has played nearly every major Shakespearean lead, including King Lear, Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago, Richard III and Macbeth. He will also star as the title character in Sean Mathias' upcoming film adaptation \"Hamlet.\"\n\nThe actor, who was knighted in 1991, gained international fame as Gandalf in \"Lord of the Rings\" and Magneto in the \"X-Men\" films. He has been nominated for two Oscars, including a Supporting Actor nod for his role as Gandalf and as Best Actor in a Leading Role nomination for when he played James Whale in 1999's \"Gods and Monsters.\"\n\nOn the British stage, he has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his performances in \"Richard III,\" \"Pillars Of The Community,\" \"The Alchemist,\" \"Bent,\" \"Wild Honey\" and his one-man show \"Ian McKellen On Stage.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": recovering after falling off London stage", "body": "LONDON, June 18 (Reuters) - British actor Ian McKellen, 85, fell off a London stage mid-performance and is now recovering after being taken to hospital, a theatre statement said on Tuesday.\n\nMcKellen is starring as John Falstaff in \"Player Kings\", a production of William Shakespeare's \"Henry IV, Parts One and Two\", in the capital's West End theatre district.\n\nIn a fight scene during Monday evening's performance, McKellen lost his footing and fell off the front of the stage, crying out as staff rushed to help, media reported.\n\nThe show was cancelled and the actor was taken to hospital.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits,\" the theatre statement said.\n\nThe performance on Tuesday was cancelled to give McKellen a chance to rest and the play will resume on Wednesday, it added.\n\nMcKellen is best known for playing Gandalf in the film versions of \"Lord of the Rings\" and \"The Hobbit\" and was also Magneto in the \"X-Men\" movies.\n\nHis stage career stretches back to 1961, where his credits include {"uri": "8183193563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "08:19:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T08:19:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T08:18:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/entertainment/hollywood/ian-mckellen-injured-in-stage-fall-west-end-show-cancelled-for-recovery20240618134739/", "title": "Ian McKellen injured in stage fall, West End show cancelled for recovery", "body": "Washington [US], June 18 (ANI): 'The Lord of the Rings' actor Ian McKellen was hospitalized after a frightening accident during a performance of 'Player Kings' at the Noel Coward Theatre in London's West End.\n\nAccording to Variety, the 85 year-old-actor suffered a fall during a battle scene, prompting an immediate response from theatre staff and emergency services.\n\nThe incident occurred during a pivotal moment in the production of William Shakespeare's 'Henry IV, Parts One and Two,' where McKellen portrays the character John Falstaff.\n\nAccording to Variety, eyewitnesses described the scene as alarming, with McKellen reportedly losing his footing and falling off the front of the stage.\n\nAudience members were reportedly evacuated from the theatre, and the evening's performance was cancelled to focus on McKellen's well-being.\n\nA spokesperson for the Noel Coward Theatre assured the public that the actor is expected to recover fully and expressed gratitude for the outpouring of support.\n\nVariety obtained a statement released following the incident in which the spokesperson for the theatre conveyed, \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of 'Player Kings.' Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\nThe accident has sparked concern among fans and fellow actors, reflecting on McKellen's illustrious career both on stage and screen.\n\nApart from Shakespearean roles like Macbeth, King Lear, and Richard III, McKellen is internationally recognized for his iconic portrayals of Gandalf in 'The Lord of the Rings' trilogy and Magneto in the 'X-Men' series.\n\nThis incident is not the first time McKellen has faced challenges due to injuries during performances.\n\nVariety reported that in 2018, he cancelled a matinee show of 'King Lear' after sustaining a leg injury while rushing to catch a train, opting to engage with the audience through an impromptu Q and A session instead. {"uri": "8187123395", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:33:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:33:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:33:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/culture/2024/06/20/sir-ian-mckellen-to-miss-further-london-shows-after-stage-fall", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen to miss further London shows after stage fall", "body": "The 85-year-old actor will not be returning to the stage in London after his fall earlier this week. He is expected to make a full and speedy recovery.\n\nBritish veteran actor Sir Ian McKellen will not be returning to the stage when the run of \"Player Kings\" resumes in the West End tonight.\n\nThe actor, 85, who plays John Falstaff in the show directed by Robert Icke, was performing at London's Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing during a fight scene earlier this week.\n\nHe was heard crying out in pain as staff rushed to help. He was taken to hospital after falling off the stage and doctors stated that McKellen was in \"good sprits\" and expected to make a full recovery.\n\nMonday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest, and the Lord Of the Rings star and Olivier award winner thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nHe wrote on X: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support. Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\"\n\nWhile he said on Tuesday that he was \"looking forward to returning to work\", it has been confirmed that his understudy David Semark will go on instead for the final London performances tonight, Friday, and Saturday.\n\n\"After three nights in hospital, the effects of my fall onstage have been fully analysed and I'm now having physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home,\" said McKellen. \"Meanwhile my part in Player Kings is filled by the redoubtable David Semark supported by Robert Icke's amazing production and cast.\"\n\n\"The many messages of love and support will, I am sure, aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me.\"\n\nA post on the Player Kings X account today also confirmed the news: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\". Sir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nFollowing the shocking accident, the audience was swiftly evacuated from the theatre and informed that the evening's performance would be cancelled.\n\nAn eyewitness, Charlie Johnson, spoke to Good Morning Britain about the impact of Sir Ian's fall, revealing exactly what happened on the night. He explained: \"As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on and there were strobe lights and then it all went dark; at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out the wings. The way the stage works at the Noel Coward, there's a step down and that's where the stage meets the audience.\n\n\"I think what happened is he took his foot too far off that initial step and lost his balance and went headfirst into the audience. Within seconds, a blood-curdling scream arose from the actor and he was clearly in a lot of pain and screaming 'help me'.\"\n\nAudience members also took to X, formerly Twitter, with their recollection of the night. {"uri": "2024-06-392814225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:48:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:48:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T22:29:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/sir-ian-mckellen-aged-85-is-taken-to-the-hospital-after-stumbling-and-tumbling-off-the-stage-while-performing-in-player-kings-at-the-noel-coward-theatre-in-london/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen, aged 85, is taken to the hospital after stumbling and tumbling off the stage while performing in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen has been rushed to hospital after falling off stage during a West End performance in London tonight.\n\nThe 85-year-old acting legend was involved in a fight scene during a performance of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre when he lost his balance and tumbled off the front of the stage.\n\nThe audience were evacuated from the theatre while medics were called to the venue - and ticket holders were told the evening show has been cancelled.\n\nIt's understood Sir Ian - who plays John Falstaff in the play - was circling a battle scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy, when he tripped and fell off the stage.\n\nAs the house lights came up, the actor best known for his portrayals of Gandalf in the Lord Of The Rings franchise and Magneto in X-Men, is said to have cried out in pain as ushers rushed to help him.\n\nAudience members, some left in tears, told MailOnline that the star 'was screaming help me' and described the sounds as 'bone-chilling'.\n\nThe extent of the actor's injuries are not known at this stage - but at least three London ambulances were pictured outside the theatre.\n\nPlayer Kings, which started its 12-week West End run in April, is a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two.\n\nThose in the audience have shared their shock at the incident. One tweeted: 'Just witnessed an awful accident with Sir Ian McKellen tripping off the stage in London. He seems badly hurt. We are all in shock and tears.'\n\nAnother wrote: 'Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage tonight at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.'\n\nAnd a third said: 'Shocking to watch, it was a terrible fall. Hoping he is not badly injured, he seemed to be in great pain.'\n\nSandro Trapani told the BBC the incident was 'very shocking', adding: 'I really hope that he is going to be alright. As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.'\n\nSir Ian's representatives and the London Ambulance Service have been approached for comment.\n\nSir Ian, who was born in Burnley, Lancashire, is noted for his work with the Royal Shakespeare Company.\n\nHe shot to international acclaim for his film work, receiving an Academy Award nomination in 1998 for Best Actor after he starred in Gods and Monsters.\n\nIn 2019, the actor topped the The Stage 100 list of most influential people in British Theatre following his UK Tour of Ian McKellen on Stage.\n\nSir Ian was knighted in 1991 for services to theatre and was later appointed a Companion of Honour for services to drama and equality by Queen Elizabeth II in 2008.\n\nOver the past six decades, Sir Ian has taken on the role of almost every Shakespeare male protagonist - but he was 'never attracted to' playing the character of Falstaff until he was persuaded to by director Robert Icke.\n\nAfter Player Kings' run at the Noel Coward theatre, the show will tour the country. It is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nThe play brings together Shakespeare's two history plays (Henry IV, parts 1 and 2) with the cast including Toheen Jimoh as Hal and Richard Coyle as King Henry IV.\n\nIn April, Sir Ian had to take drastic, and speedy, measures to ensure he made it across London in time for his daily performance of the show - riding on the back of a motorbike.\n\nOne source said at the time: 'Sir Ian tried getting picked up by a car provided by theatre bosses but it took so long to get across town it was pointless.\n\n'One night it took him 90 minutes to get from his home. After that, it was decided a motorbike was the only option.'\n\nHe has also previously had to pull out of performances due to injuries. In 2018, he had to apologise to theatre-goers after a leg injury forced him to pull out of a performance of King Lear. Sir Ian had been rushing to catch the train and pulled his calf muscle.\n\nLast September, Sir Ian opened up about his life changing 'overnight' when he came out as gay in 1988.\n\nHe told Variety: 'Almost overnight everything in my life changed for the better - my relationships with people and my whole attitude toward acting changed.'\n\nSir Ian told how coming out actually had a huge impact on his acting work.\n\nHe explained: 'The kind of acting that I had been good at was all about disguise - adopting funny voices and odd walks.\n\n'It was about lying to the world. I was no longer in the situation where I was running along beside the character explaining it to the audience. I just became the character.'\n\nIan also said he felt that it was difficult for non-gay people to relate to his struggle.\n\nThe veteran actor said: 'People who are not gay just simply don't know how it damages you to be lying about what you are and ashamed of yourself.\n\n'I was brought up at a time when it was illegal for me to have sex with a man. And that was not that long ago,' he added.\n\nHe previously revealed how he had to 'swear he wasn't gay' in order to work on Broadway in the 1960s.\n\nJust last week, Sir Ian made headlines after he took a swipe at former US president Donald Trump - accusing him of being 'one of the worst public speakers there has ever been'.\n\nHe told The Times: 'Trump is an absolute bewilderment. I haven't seen him live. But he's one of the worst public speakers there has ever been. Whether he's reading a script or not, it's so patent what he is.'", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8183465261", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:10:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:10:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:10:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/06/18/arts/ian-mckellen-stage-fall.html", "title": "Ian McKellen Is in 'Good Spirits' After Falling Off the Stage During a Play", "body": "The actor Ian McKellen was hospitalized but expected to recover quickly after falling off the stage during a performance of \"Player Kings\" at a theater in the West End in London on Monday night, the producers of the play said.\n\nAfter a scan, doctors at Britain's National Health Service said that McKellen would \"make a speedy and full recovery, and Ian is in good spirits,\" according to a statement by the producers.\n\nMcKellen, 85, who has been nominated for two Academy Awards and has won a Tony, a Golden Globe and multiple Olivier Awards, is starring in the play, an adaptation of William Shakespeare's two \"Henry IV\" plays, directed by Robert Icke. McKellen plays John Falstaff, a fictional character who appears in four Shakespeare plays.\n\nThe fall took place during a battle scene, according to Aleks Phillips, a BBC journalist who was in the audience on Monday night and described what he saw in an article.\n\n\"It happened so quickly that at first it appeared to be part of the performance,\" Phillips wrote. \"But the actor cried out and staff rushed to help.\"\n\nAfter the fall, the performance was canceled and the audience left the theater. Tuesday night's show was also canceled, the producers said, but McKellen was expected to return to the stage for a matinee performance on Wednesday.\n\nMcKellen has often returned to the stage for Shakespeare plays throughout his six-decade career, including in recent years as King Lear and as an octogenarian Hamlet. {"uri": "8184209613", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:00:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:00:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:00:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/ian-mckellen-breaks-silence-west-33059201", "title": "Ian McKellen breaks silence as West End play cancelled after horror stage fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen has insisted he's \"looking forward to returning to work\" after his West End play was cancelled for several performances following a horror fall.\n\nThe actor, 85, suffered a fall on stage on Monday night and was rushed to hospital. Sir Ian lost his footing during a fight scene as he portrayed John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nSharing his support for the NHS on X, formerly known as Twitter, Sir Ian wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support. Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nFans of the legendary actor shared their support as one wrote: \"Wishing one of my favourite actors of all time a speedy recovery!\" Another commented: \"Fantastic news, be well Sir! #NationalTreasure.\"\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, the production shared a statement confirming the cancellation of Wednesday's performance. The remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances had already been cancelled to allow the actor to rest.\n\n\"The performance on Wednesday 19 June will be cancelled following Ian McKellen's fall during the performance of Player Kings on Monday (17 June)\", the statement read.\n\n\"Bookers for the affected performance will be contacted by their point of purchase directly. We look forward to welcoming audiences back to the Noel Coward Theatre on Thursday 20 June.\n\n\"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nUpdating fans on Sir Ian's health, a spokesperson for the London theatre said: \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\" The statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nAfter the fall on Monday, the audience were evacuated from the theatre and informed the show would be cancelled. Charlie Johnson, who witnessed the incident, spoke to Good Morning Britain about the impact of Sir Ian's fall. He explained: \"As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on and there were strobe lights and then it all went dark; at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out the wings. The way the stage works at the Noel Coward, there's a step down and that's where the stage meets the audience.\n\n\"I think what happened is he took his foot too far off that initial step and lost his balance and went headfirst into the audience. Within seconds, a blood curling stream arose from the actor and he was clearly in a lot of pain and screaming 'help me.'\"\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to end its run at the Noel Coward Theatre on Saturday. The play will then move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July before being staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on TikTok, Snapchat, Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, {"uri": "8183113539", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "07:24:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T07:24:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T07:23:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.examinerlive.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/sir-ian-mckellen-good-spirits-29372870", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen 'in good spirits' after stage fall sees him rushed to hospital", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nSir Ian McKellen, the esteemed actor known for his role in The Lord Of The Rings, is said to be in \"good spirits\" and on track for a \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after an unfortunate fall from the stage during a West End performance. The incident occurred during a fight scene in the production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, where the 85 year old actor is currently portraying John Falstaff.\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre expressed gratitude for the public's concern, stating: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" They further confirmed that, after a scan, the NHS team has assured them of Sir Ian's swift recovery.\n\nIn light of the incident, the Tuesday June 18 performance was cancelled to allow Sir Ian some rest. Ticket holders affected by this decision will be contacted as soon as possible.\n\nRead more: The shanty town few people know about with stunning beach and breathtaking views\n\nThe theatre's statement also extended thanks to doctors Rachel and Lee who were present in the audience, as well as the venue staff for their support. Sir Ian is expected to return to the stage for Wednesday's matinee performance.\n\nFollowing the incident, theatre-goers were informed that the rest of the evening's performance had been cancelled and they were promptly evacuated from the building. A BBC journalist who was in attendance reported that the seasoned actor was in a scene with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he tumbled off the front of the stage, reports Wales Online.\n\nThe actor could be heard crying out in pain as staff hurried to his aid. Audience member Paul Critchley described the fall as a \"shock\" to witness.\n\nGet all the latest What's On news straight to your inbox by signing up to our newsletter here.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister hailing from Downham Market, Norfolk, recounted: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene. \"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights were swiftly turned on as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy. \"An announcement was made by theatre management that the show had been cancelled, that Sir Ian was receiving treatment and an ambulance had been called.\n\n\"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. My thoughts are also with his fellow cast members, stage crew and front of house team at the Noel Coward Theatre.\"\n\nThe London Ambulance Service has chosen not to comment on the incident.\n\nPlayer Kings, a rendition of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is set to transfer to the Bristol Hippodrome in July. The production will also grace stages in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian, whose illustrious career spans over six decades, has performed in theatres nationwide.\n\nHe is perhaps best known for his on-screen roles as Magneto in the X-Men series and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's adaptation of JRR Tolkien's fantasy trilogy. His stage performances have seen him embody numerous Shakespearean characters such as Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis extensive acting portfolio has earned him several accolades, including multiple Olivier Awards.\n\nLike this story? {"uri": "8187711721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "21:09:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T21:09:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T21:09:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/ian-mckellen-cancels-final-player-kings-performances-after-fall/", "title": "Ian McKellen Cancels Final 'Player Kings' Performances After Falling Off Stage", "body": "Ian McKellen will sit out the final three performances of Player Kings as he recovers from falling off the stage during a show on June 17.\n\nMcKellen, 85, was performing a battle scene when he lost his footing, according to the BBC. He was rushed to the hospital as the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre canceled the remainder of the show. Performances remained on hold until Thursday, June 20, when the theater announced that David Semark would replace him for the end of the show's 12-week West End run.\n\n\"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theater in London while Ian McKellen recuperates from his fall on Monday 17 June,\" the theater's statement read. \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" he wrote. \"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nJournalist Charlie Johnson, who was at the performance the night of McKellen's fall, reported that the actor \"could be heard screaming in pain as ushers rushed to his aid\" and that it appeared he \"severely\" injured himself.\n\nMcKellen, who was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II in 1991, is a veteran of British theater. A six-time Olivier Award winner, he is known for his roles in revivals of Shakespeare plays. This isn't the first time one has led McKellen to injury, either. In 2018, he hurt his leg while running to catch a train en route to play King Lear at London's Duke of York Theatre.\n\nWhen his leg injury rendered him unable to perform, McKellen instead conducted a {"uri": "2024-06-393820808", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:11:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:11:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:00:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/sir-ian-mckellen-wednesday-performance-161602757.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen performance cancelled after fall from stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen will not appear in Wednesday's production of Player Kings after he fell from the stage while performing a fight scene on Monday night.\n\nA spokesman said the 85-year-od Lord of The Rings actor, who is playing John Falstaff at the Noel Coward Theatre in London, was recovering well but would not be back to performing as soon as initially hoped.\n\nAn update suggested Sir Ian was expected to appear in Wednesday's matinee performance, producers decided to cancel that on Tuesday afternoon \"so that Ian can rest\".\n\nShortly after Sir Ian had lost his footing and fallen from the stage, a theatre spokesman said the actor was \"in good spirits\" and \"will make a speedy and full recovery\".\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee, who were \"on hand in the audience\", and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nAfter the accident, audience members took to social media to express their concern for Sir Ian. \"Just witnessed an awful accident with Sir Ian McKellen tripping off the stage in London. He seems badly hurt. We are all in shock and tears,\" one wrote on X, formerly Twitter.\n\nCharlie Johnson, a journalist who was in the audience too, told ITV: \"The way the stage works at the Noel Coward is there's sort of a step down just as the stage meets the audience. I think what happened was he put his foot too far, sort of went off that initial step, at which point he lost his balance and pretty much just went head first into the audience.\"\n\nThe audience was evacuated from the premises as Sir Ian was taken to hospital, where he was given a scan.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is set to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nA spokesman for the Noel Coward Theatre said that Sir Ian was \"recovering well\" and they looked forward to him returning to the production \"as soon as he is ready.\"\n\nIn a statement, they said: \"We look forward to welcoming audiences back to the Noel Coward Theatre on Thursday 19 June. {"uri": "8184253721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:44:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:44:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T20:43:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://theblast.com/606093/ian-mckellen-breaks-silence-nasty-fall/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen Breaks Silence After Suffering A Nasty Fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen, who suffered an accident during a performance of the play \"Player Kings\" at the Noel Coward Theatre in London, has expressed gratitude for the outpouring of support he has received since the incident.\n\nMcKellen reportedly tripped and fell \"head first\" into the crowd as he performed a war scene of the play. The degree of injuries he suffered remains unknown; however, he shared a positive prognosis for his recovery.\n\nSince his fall, reports have revealed that the actor Sir Ian McKellen is in \"high spirits\" and on the road to a full recovery.\n\nThe \"Lord of the Rings\" actor took to his X account to share a rare update since suffering a health scare at his \"Player Kings\" performance last night. McKellen, who stars as John Falstaff in the play, was acting out a battle scene that involved the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he tripped and fell off the stage.\n\nIn his post, he explained that thanks to the expert care of the National Health Service (NHS), he's on track to make a speedy and complete recovery and is already looking forward to returning to the stage.\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" McKellen wrote. \"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists, and nurses working for the National Health Service.\"\n\nHe added, \"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nSeveral fans commented on his post to sympathize with him and wish him a quick recovery.\n\nA fan wrote, \"Wishing you a restful - if brief - time recovering and that you're back doing what you love as soon as possible!\"\n\n\"Excellent news! Well done to all those medical professionals. I hope you're soon fully fit and back at work. Rest up and take care. I'm glad the universe did as it was told,\" another penned.\n\n\"Wishing you a speedy & full recovery,\" a third person stated, adding that they \"had the incredible pleasure of seeing you in this play a couple of weeks, you were magnificent.\"\n\n\"Excellent news! Well done to all those medical professionals. I hope you're soon fully fit and back at work. Rest up and take care. I'm glad the universe did as it was told,\" another individual commented.\n\nThe 85-year-old actor's update comes after some show attendees recounted moments leading up to the fall.\n\nAccording to the Daily Mail, Charlie Johnson, a journalist for the Kingston Courier who attended the play, shared that McKellen tripped and fell \"head first\" into the audience during a West End performance last night.\n\n\"As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on,\" Johnson explained. \"There were strobe lights and then it all went dark, at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out from the wings. And the way the stage works at the Noel Coward is there's sort of a step down just as the stage meets the audience.\"\n\nHe continued, \"I think what happened was he put his foot too far, sort of went off that initial step, at which point he lost his balance and pretty much just went head first into the audience.\"\n\n\"And within seconds, a blood-curdling scream arose from the actor. He was clearly in a lot of pain, he was screaming 'Help me,'\" the journalist added.\n\nThe \"X-Men\" actor sparked a wave of concern from attendees who feared he might have suffered a great degree of injury as he yelled loudly after the fall.\n\nAccording to the news outlet, another eyewitness, Kol Baker, shared that McKellen had been \"berating the villain and moving around\" during the scene when he \"tripped over\" some props and fell off the stage \"in almost a belly-flop fashion.\"\n\n\"Instantly he screamed and honestly the noises were bone-chilling,\" Baker continued, adding that the \"Mr. Holmes\" actor yelled \"help me, help me\" followed by \"my arms, my arms\" and \"help me, help me\" again.\n\n\"The lights were on so quickly the curtains drawn and within seconds they asked to evacuate the whole auditorium. Whilst leaving the theatre within 10 minutes he was in the back of an ambulance speeding down Trafalgar Square,\" he added.\n\nThe show producer revealed that McKellen \"will make a speedy and full recovery\" and is in \"good spirits,\" further announcing that his performance has been canceled so he can rest.\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings,\" A spokesperson for Player Kings told the Daily Mail.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery, and Ian is in good spirits,\" they continued.\n\nIn their statement, the spokesperson for Player Kings further noted that they canceled the Tuesday show due to McKellen's unfortunate accident.\n\nThey said, \"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"", "source": {"uri": "theblast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Blast"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187004944", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:22:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:22:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:20:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/news/sir-ian-mckellen-having-physiotherapy-as-he-takes-break-from-play-after-fall/a934000548.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen having physiotherapy as he takes break from play after fall", "body": "The final London dates of the production, Player Kings, will see Sir Ian's understudy take on the role of Falstaff, while the veteran actor recuperates following the accident.\n\nA statement sent on his behalf by his publicist Clair Dobbs to the PA news agency said: \"After three nights in hospital, the effects of my fall onstage have been fully analysed and I'm now having physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home.\n\n\"Meanwhile, my part in Player Kings is filled by the redoubtable David Semark supported by Robert Icke's amazing production and cast. The many messages of love and support will, I am sure, aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me.\"\n\nThe screen and stage actor, 85, was taken to hospital on June 17 to receive treatment after he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nThe theatre cancelled the remainder of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday's performances to allow him to rest.\n\nA post to the Player Kings X, formerly Twitter, account on Thursday said that actor David Semark would take his place for the remainder of the London dates.\n\nIt said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday 17 June.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nThe final London performances are taking place on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.\n\nSir Ian's understudy, Semark, trained at the Royal Academy Of Dramatic Art (Rada) and has credits in TV shows including EastEnders, Doctors, Law & Order UK and The Bill.\n\nAfter his fall, The Lord Of The Rings star and Olivier Award-winner Sir Ian thanked everyone who had left messages of support.\n\nOn X he wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement to the PA news agency: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest.\"\n\nThe statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist who saw the play said the veteran actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nThe actor was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAfter the accident, audience members were informed that the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and they were evacuated from the premises.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident. We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy\", he said.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July.\n\nSir Ian's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is most known for playing Magneto in {"uri": "8184373707", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:01:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:01:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T22:59:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/entertainment/sir-ian-mckellen-looking-forward-to-returning-to-work-c-15068464", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen 'looking forward to returning to work'", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen 'looking forward to returning to work'Staff WritersAAPWed, 19 June 2024 6:57AM\n\nSir Ian McKellen is \"looking forward to returning to work\" after he fell from a stage in London and was rushed to hospital.\n\nThe 85-year-old actor lost his footing on Monday evening and fell off stage while he was performing in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre - but McKellen has taken to social media to reveal that he's on the road to recovery.\n\nHe wrote on X: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support. Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nThe veteran actor was taken to hospital after falling off stage, and the show was subsequently cancelled.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nOne audience member told the BBC that the incident was \"very shocking\".\n\nSandro Trapani added: \"I really hope that he is going to be alright. As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nMcKellen, who plays John Falstaff in the production, was in the midst of a fight scene when the incident occurred.\n\nThe acclaimed actor cried out in pain after he fell off stage and staff rushed to help him.\n\nMcKellen previously admitted he was relishing the opportunity to star in the production.\n\nHe told the BBC He has now provided a health update after hospitalisation.\n\nThe accident occurred on Monday at the Noel Coward Theatre during a performance of Player Kings, which adapts both parts of Shakespeare's Henry IV plays. McKellen stars as Falstaff, while Toheeb Jimoh plays Prince Hal, and Richard Coyle plays King Henry IV.\n\nMcKellen fell from the front of the stage mid-performance, leading him to be hospitalised in Paddington, London. The performances originally scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday night were cancelled to allow McKellen to rest and recover, with the show expected to return on Thursday, June 20th. The play was initially scheduled to end this week, on Saturday, June 22nd.\n\n\"We look forward to welcoming audiences back to the Noel Coward Theatre on Thursday 20 June,\" wrote the Player Kings account on X, \"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready.\" They assured audiences that they would be kept in the loop on the remaining performances.\n\nNow, McKellen has also posted a statement on X to provide an update on his health, suggesting that his recovery will be \"speedy\". He was taken to hospital and the play was cancelled.\n\nA theatre spokesperson later said Sir Ian had undergone a scan and medics said he would \"make a speedy and full recovery\".\n\nIn a message on X the day after his fall, Sir Ian said \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support.\"\n\n\"My injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. winning actor was forced to cancel a showing of King Lear at London's Duke of York theatre, after sustaining a leg injury while running to catch a train.\n\nHe ensured the audience was in for a good time, by sitting on stage and answering questions.\n\nPlayer Kings started its 12-week West End run in April, and the actor told the BBC at the time that he was \"finally playing the role he always The 85-year-old actor known for playing Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films and his many stage roles was playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the theater. Jacob Freedman/PA via Associated Press\n\nLONDON -- Actor Ian McKellen is resting, taking light exercise and undergoing physiotherapy after spending three nights in the hospital after he toppled off a London stage during a fight scene earlier this week.\n\nThe 85-year-old veteran actor thanked the public for their many messages of support following his fall at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday. An understudy, David Semark, will take his place in \"Player Kings'' during the production's final London dates, a statement sent on McKellen's behalf by his publicist Clair Dobbs said Thursday.\n\nThe play is an adaptation of William Shakespeare's two \"Henry IV\" history plays, directed by Robert Icke. Several performances were canceled after the incident.\n\n\"The many messages of love and support will, I am sure, aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me,\" the statement said.\n\nMcKellen, who played Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings,\" is one of Britain's most acclaimed Shakespearean actors, with roles including Richard III, Macbeth and King Lear.\n\nCopy the Story
