{"uri": "2024-06-393828416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:21:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:21:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:04:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/ian-mckellens-west-end-performance-canceled-after-he-fell-off-the-stage-health-update-provided/", "title": "Ian McKellen's West End performance canceled after he fell off the stage; health update provided - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen's West End show on Wednesday night has also been cancelled after the acting legend fell from the stage while performing on Monday, the production has announced.\n\nThe Lord Of The Rings actor, 85, who is currently playing John Falstaff in Player Kings, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and tumbled off the stage at the No\u00ebl Coward theatre in London.\n\nLast night, Player Kings released a positive update, revealing that Sir Ian was in 'good spirits' but that Tuesday night's performance would be cancelled so he could rest. They have now confirmed Wednesday night has also been axed.\n\nIn a statement posted to X, formerly Twitter, the production said he is 'recovering well' and that they 'look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready'.\n\n'The performance on Wednesday 19 June will be cancelled following Ian McKellen's fall during the performance of Player Kings on Monday (17 June)', the statement said.\n\n'Bookers for the affected performance will be contacted by their point of purchase directly. We look forward to welcoming audiences back to the Noel Coward Theatre on Thursday 20 June.\n\n'We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.'\n\nAudience members told MailOnline the star plunged off the front of the stage in a 'belly flop fashion' and yelled 'help me... my arms' just before the interval of Player Kings.\n\nThe crowd were evacuated from the theatre at around 8pm last night while medics were called to the venue - and ticket holders were told the evening show had been cancelled.\n\nSir Ian was circling a battle scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy, when he tripped and fell off the stage.\n\nAs the house lights came up, the actor known for Lord Of The Rings and X-Men cried out in pain as ushers and two medics in the audience rushed to help him.\n\nCharlie Johnson, a journalist for the Kingston Courier who was in the audience, told ITV: 'As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on.\n\n'There were strobe lights and then it all went dark, at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out from the wings. And the way the stage works at the Noel Coward is there's sort of a step down just as the stage meets the audience.\n\n'I think what happened was he put his foot too far, sort of went off that initial step, at which point he lost his balance and pretty much just went head first into the audience.\n\n'And within seconds a blood-curdling scream arose from the actor. He was clearly in a lot of pain, he was screaming 'help me'.'\n\nKol Baker, who was watching the show from the second tier, told MailOnline that Sir Ian had been 'berating the villain and moving around' during the scene when he 'tripped over' some props and fell off the stage 'in almost a belly flop fashion'.\n\n'Instantly he screamed and honestly the noises were bone-chilling,' the 23-year-old added - as he recalled Sir Ian yelling 'help me, help me' followed by 'my arms, my arms' and 'help me, help me' again.\n\n'The lights were on so quickly the curtains drawn and within seconds they asked to evacuate the whole auditorium. Whilst leaving the theatre within ten minutes he was in the back of an ambulance speeding down Trafalgar Square.'\n\nDescribing what caused the actor to fall, he explained: 'The scene in question was a warzone so there was broken up bricks and daggers from the battle and the set which was all torn up for that scene.'\n\nHe said there was 'so much concern and shock for Sir Ian', adding: 'Everyone I think is just such huge fans of his work and just really empathetic and almost terrified that it could be life-threatening because of his age.'\n\nMr Baker said that Sir Ian had been 'performing amazingly with great vigour' before he fell.\n\nWhen asked how the audience reacted, the theatregoer added: 'Instantly people were standing up, the first two rows completely went to rush to go help Sir Ian and everyone was explaining 'oh my god' and 'that poor man'.\n\n'It was very sincere and so much concern for his well-being,' he added. 'He had made everyone laugh so much this evening.'\n\nPlayer Kings, which started its 12-week West End run in April, is a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two.\n\nAfterwards, the show will tour the country. It is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian, who now lives in Limehouse, was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and his father Denis.\n\nHe has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: 'Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.'\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended. When at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Derek Jacobi, David Frost and Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nHe shot to international acclaim for his film work, receiving an Academy Award nomination in 1998 for Best Actor after he starred in Gods and Monsters.\n\nIn 2019, the actor topped the The Stage 100 list of most influential people in British Theatre following his UK Tour of Ian McKellen on Stage.\n\nSir Ian was knighted in 1991 for services to theatre and was later appointed a Companion of Honour for services to drama and equality by Queen Elizabeth II in 2008.\n\nSir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The 85-year-old actor known for playing Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings\" films and his many stage roles was playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the theater. Jacob Freedman/PA via Associated Press\n\nLONDON -- Actor Ian McKellen is resting, taking light exercise and undergoing physiotherapy after spending three nights in the hospital after he toppled off a London stage during a fight scene earlier this week.\n\nThe 85-year-old veteran actor thanked the public for their many messages of support following his fall at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday. An understudy, David Semark, will take his place in \"Player Kings'' during the production's final London dates, a statement sent on McKellen's behalf by his publicist Clair Dobbs said Thursday.\n\nThe play is an adaptation of William Shakespeare's two \"Henry IV\" history plays, directed by Robert Icke. Several performances were canceled after the incident.\n\n\"The many messages of love and support will, I am sure, aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me,\" the statement said.\n\nMcKellen, who played Gandalf in the \"Lord of the Rings,\" is one of Britain's most acclaimed Shakespearean actors, with roles including Richard III, Macbeth and King Lear.\n\nCopy the Story The audience was evacuated from the theater, and the evening show was canceled. The severity of McKellen's injuries is unclear.\n\nVariety has reached out to McKellen's representative.\n\nMcKellen plays John Falstaff in \"Player Kings,\" which is a production of William Shakespeare's \"Henry IV, Parts One and Two.\" It started its 12-week run on the West End in April. After circling a fight scene involving two other characters, McKellen apparently fell off the front of the stage. Per the BBC, \"As the house lights came up, the actor cried out and staff rushed to help.\"\n\nAn audience member speaking to the BBC called the incident \"very shocking,\" adding, \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nMcKellen is a frequent Shakespeare actor, with stage roles including Macbeth, King Lear, Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago and Richard III. {"uri": "8183411421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "10:36:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T10:36:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T10:36:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.bristolpost.co.uk/whats-on/whats-on-news/bristol-hippodrome-issues-update-sir-9349907", "title": "Bristol Hippodrome issues update on Sir Ian McKellen after stage fall", "body": "Bristol Hippodrome has issued an update on actor Sir Ian McKellen, who was rushed to hospital following a dramatic fall off stage during a performance of Player Kings. The 85-year-old acting legend, who is due to appear in Bristol next month, lost his footing during an intense fight scene and fell off the stage at London's Noel Coward Theatre on Monday (June 17).\n\nThe audience was quickly evacuated from the theatre and informed that the evening's performance would be cancelled. A shocked audience member reportedly heard Sir Ian cry out: \"Help me, help me\" after the fall.\n\nThe actor then repeated 'My arms, my arms' and 'Help me, help me'. Last night, it was reported that Sir Ian was \"in good spirits\" and expected to make a swift recovery - thanks to the \"brilliant\" NHS.\n\nREAD MORE: Everything you need to know as Kings of Leon perform in Bristol\n\nREAD MORE: Taylor Swift Eras tour: Fans start queuing at midnight ahead of Cardiff show\n\nPlayer Kings, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is set to take the stage at the Bristol Hippodrome from July 3-6. A spokesperson from the show said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits. The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nSir Ian is set to make his next appearance in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production. Player Kings, a rendition of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, kicked off its 12-week West End run in April.\n\nSign up to receive our What's On in Bristol newsletter for all the latest on things to do and places to eat.\n\nOn Tuesday morning, eyewitness Charlie Johnson shared his account of the shocking incident on Good Morning Britain. He said: \"As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on and there were strobe light and then it all went dark, at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out the wings and the way the stage works at the Noel Coward, there's a step-down and where the stage meets the audience.\n\n\"I think what happened is he took his foot too far off that initial step and lost his balance and went head first into the audience. Within seconds, a blood curling scream arose from the actor and he was clearly in a lot of pain and screaming 'help me'.\"\n\nLooking for places to visit and things to do in Bristol? They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy.\"\n\nSir Ian added: \"I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nThe set was reportedly littered with broken-up bricks and daggers for the battlefield scene.\n\nThe West End show was cancelled and the stunned audience ushered out of the theatre.\n\nTheatregoer Charlie Johnson told ITV: \"I think what happened was he put his foot too far.\n\n\"He lost his balance and pretty much just went head first into the audience.\"\n\nCharlie added: \"He was clearly in a lot of pain - he was screaming 'Help me!\"\n\nAudience members in the front two rows joined staff in rushing to help the stricken star.\n\nMany of the audience were said to be in tears after seeing the horror fall.\n\nOne person tweeted: \"Just witnessed an awful accident with Sir Ian McKellen tripping off the stage in London.\n\n\"He seems badly hurt. assistance.\"\n\nTheatregoer Paul Critchley said it was a \"shock\" to witness the horror incident.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, said: \"Sir Ian seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene.\n\n\"He picked up momentum as he moved downstage which resulted in him falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\n\"The house lights came up very quickly as the stage management and front of house team dealt with the incident.\n\n\"We were evacuated immediately so that Sir Ian could be treated in privacy.\n\n\"An The audience was evacuated from the show and told that the evening's performance was, therefore, cancelled.\n\nTonight's performance (Tuesday 18th June) has also been cancelled \"so Ian can rest\", according to the theatre spokesperson, who also confirmed that McKellen was expected to return to the stage for Wednesday's matinee.\n\nThe new production of the Shakespeare classic tales is in the midst of its 12-week West End run, having recently also confirmed a full UK tour that will take McKellen and the cast to Norwich, Bristol and Newcastle, to name a few cities.\n\nRead more:\n\nAt the time of the tour announcement, McKellen said: \"Player Kings is a version of Shakespeare's most English plays. Icke, best known for his play The Doctor as well as his adaptation of 1984, Mary Stuart and Oresteia.\n\nSpeaking of the cast being led by McKellen ahead of the show's first run, Icke said: \"It's a stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen will not appear when the run of Player Kings resumes in the West End on Thursday night after his fall from the stage.\n\nThe veteran actor, 85, was performing at London's Noel Coward Theatre when he lost his footing in a fight scene on Monday.\n\nHe was taken to hospital after the accident, with performances on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday all cancelled to give him time to rest.\n\nThe final London performances are on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday.\n\nWhile he said on Tuesday he is \"looking forward to returning to work\", he confirmed his understudy David Semark will go on instead.\n\n\"After three nights in hospital, the effects of my fall onstage have been fully analysed and I'm now having physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home,\" he said\n\n\"Meanwhile my part in Player Kings is filled by the redoubtable David Semark supported by Robert Icke's amazing production and cast.\n\n\"The many messages of love and support will, I am sure, aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me.\"\n\nThe show's X account also confirmed Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three performances.\n\nOrganisers added they look forward to Sir Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before stops in Birmingham, Norwich, and Newcastle.\n\nSir Ian was said to be in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell from the front of the stage.\n\nHe was heard crying out in pain as staff rushed to help, with the theatre later thanking doctors Rachel and Lee, who were in the audience at the time.\n\nAudience members were told the remainder of the evening performance had been cancelled and were {"uri": "8183906878", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "15:53:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T15:53:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T15:52:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/ian-mckellen-player-kings-battle-scene-hurt-155051524.html", "title": "The battle scene that Ian McKellen hurt himself in Player Kings is pivotal", "body": "Ian McKellen was rushed to hospital during Monday, 17 June's performance of Player Kings after losing his footing and falling off the stage during the first act.\n\nMcKellen is said to have become injured during a battle scene in the first act -- which adapts Henry IV Part 1 -- but luckily he is expected to \"make a speedy and full recovery\" after the incident. I watched the actor play Falstaff in The Player Kings in April, and the scene in question is one of the most pivotal parts of the production.\n\nI was beyond ecstatic when I was given tickets as a Christmas present, here was my chance to see McKellen play one of the most important roles in Shakespeare. Falstaff is one of the playwright's most beloved characters: a buffoonish, boastful, hilarious old man whose friendship with Prince Hal is the backbone of Henry IV Part 1 and 2.\n\nIt is a part that all actors interested in Shakespeare long to play when they get to the right stage of their life, and McKellen certainly didn't disappoint. His Falstaff is everything you want the character to be, a bumbling drunkard and sly-talker who you can't help but be drawn to whenever he is on stage.\n\nAudiences laugh with him, and they laugh at him. The character is a terrible influence on Prince Hal (played brilliantly by Toheeb Jimoh) but you also find their bond endearing. Their pseudo-toxic friendship is what makes Henry IV Part 1 so fun, and McKellen's brash, chaotic take only adds to the comedy.\n\nRead more: Sir Ian McKellen to 'make a speedy and full recovery' after theatre stage fall (PA Media, 3-min read)\n\nBut one of the most important parts of the play comes when the war between King Henry IV and rebels led by Henry \"Hotspur\" Percy breaks out, leading to the scene where McKellen is said to have fallen.\n\nThe Player Kings is a modern retelling of Shakespeare's plays and I was mesmerised as the battle, cast members in camouflage stormed the stage, explosions went off and rubble (no doubt made of rubber) was scattered across the boards to make the scene feel realistic.\n\nAfter the first half mostly bounced back and forth between taverns and the royal court, it felt like a nice change of pace, and what made it all the more interesting is, of course, the part that Falstaff plays in the battle.\n\nThe knight finds himself lifted in station to battalion leader, but when the Battle of Shrewsbury reaches its peak he fakes his death to avoid attack. He witnesses Hal and Hotspur's duel, and when Hotspur is slain decides to have his moment of glory by stabbing Hotspur and taking credit for killing him.\n\nRead more: Ian McKellen will return for new Lord of the Rings movie if he's alive (Digital Spy, 2-min read)\n\nThe scene is one of the most important of the production, and McKellen delivers a powerful monologue that encompasses everything you love about -- and get frustrated by -- Falstaff. Here is an actor who commands the stage, who can hold the audience's attention with his every word.\n\nI was utterly captivated by McKellen as he gave the speech, making his way across the stage to deliver the \"final\" blow to Hotspur. It's funny and emotional, and represents everything that I love best about seeing McKellen on stage, and it has to be seen to be believed.\n\nPlayer Kings will be performed at the Noel Coward Theatre until Saturday, 22 June, it will then go on tour in Bristol, Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": [], In a state of shock, he shouted \"Help me! My hands!\", which scared the audience.\n\nThis happened at a time when Ian McKellen, in the role of John Falstaff, was engaged in a battle with the heroes Prince of Wales and Henry Percy in the theater production of Player Kings. According to the Daily Mail, the man was examined. The doctors concluded that he was fine and would make a \"full and speedy recovery.\" The actor will return to the theater on Wednesday, June 19.\n\nWhen the star stumbled and fell face first off the stage, the audience was shocked, and some were even brought to tears. One of them, Kol Baker, said that Ian McKellen was \"scolding the villain and moving around\" on stage when he suddenly tripped over some props and fell \"almost on his stomach.\"\n\n\"He instantly screamed, and to be honest, the sounds were bone-chilling,\" he added.\n\nWhat scared people was the fact that the actor is 85 years old, and such incidents can be very dangerous for his life:, \"Everyone, I think, is just such a huge fan of his work, and they're just very sympathetic and scared that it could have been life-threatening because of his age.\"\n\nSoon after, all spectators were dismissed and the performance was canceled. In particular, fans will not be able to see the play scheduled for Tuesday, June 18. The spokesperson said that this decision was made \"so that Ian could rest.\"\n\n\"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their good wishes following Ian's fall during tonight's performance of Player Kings. After examination, the brilliant team at the National Health Service assured us that he will make a full and speedy recovery and that Ian is in good spirits,\" a representative of the production team McKellen is playing John Falstaff in Player Kings.\n\nDuring the health and news segment, Kelly said the news that the actor had fallen off the stage was \"disturbing\" while holding a conversation with Dr Hilary. Also, the TV host had praise for the acting legend as she sent him her well wishes on her daytime TV show.\n\nKelly: \"This is disturbing. Ian McKellen, when he was on stage, had a bad fall didn't he? He was rushed to hospital.\"\n\nDr Hilary said: \"Belly-flopped apparently. Fell of the stage. Belly-flopped to the floor. Rushed to hospital presumably a precautionary measure. They say he's going to be back next Wednesday. Bruising can take awhile to come out. We wish him well. What a drama.\"\n\nKelly added: \"Thank goodness he is so well and so fit.\"\n\nDr Hilary however shared his concerns because of McKellen's age. He said: \"He's 85. A fall at 85 is potentially quite serious.\"\n\nKelly celebrated the actor for his attitude of \"the show must go on\" and for being a \"total trooper\". She said: \"I know it's not good. But you know what he's like, a total trooper, the show must go on, he's probably sitting this morning in his hospital bed - or hopefully he's back home - we're sending you all our love. We will keep you updated as we hear how he's getting on. Everybody is talking about this, he's so well loved.\"\n\nLater on This Morning, Cat Deeley and Ben Shephard also sent their well wishes to the actor who recently joined them on the sofa. Shephard said: \"We just want to say we are sending lots of love to Sir Ian who fell off the stage last night. He's doing well... Get well soon from all of us.\"\n\nDoctors have reassured everyone that McKellen will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" after a scan at the hospital, the theatre said. The star is expected to return to the stage for Wednesday's matinee performance.\n\nA spokesperson for the theatre said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\n\"Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nA BBC journalist was among the audience and broke the story. Audience member Paul Critchley said the fall was a shock.\n\nMr Critchley, a Methodist minister from Downham Market, Norfolk, told PA: \"It was a shock to witness his fall and I wish him a speedy recovery. His current condition remains unknown.\n\nPer the BBC, McKellen was doing a performance of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward theater in London when the incident occurred. He was taking part in a fight scene when he reportedly lost his footing and fell off the front of the stage. The house lights came up and McKellen called for help, at which point he was rushed to the hospital for treatment. No updates have since been made about the extent of his injuries.\n\nRelated\n\nX-Men: The Last Stand's Biggest Twist Was Never Explained\n\nThe X-Men films leave many questions unanswered, but one unexplained mystery stands out: how did one character return after dying in The Last Stand?\n\nClose\n\nAccording to the report, the audience was evacuated after McKellen's fall and a planned evening show had been canceled. The show, meant to consist of a 12-week run, started in April. It features McKellen in the role of John Falstaff, coming as the latest Shakespearean play to feature the actor. He's also set to play Hamlet in a new movie and previously portrayed other Shakespearean roles like Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago, Richard III, King Lear, and Macbeth.\n\n\"I really hope that he is going to be alright,\" says Sandro Trapani, who was present during the show when McKellen fell. \"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nRelated\n\nX-Men Artist Discusses \"Redefining\" One of Marvel's Most Iconic Mutants\n\nIndustry icon Ryan Stegman opens up about \"redefining\" one of the greatest mutant heroes of all time in his upcoming X-Men run.\n\nMcKellen was once injured ahead of a King Lear showing in 2019. He'd hurt his leg while rushing to board a train, though he still attended to entertain the audience as best he could. The actor sat on stage and answered questions.\n\nWill Ian McKellen Return as Magneto or Gandalf?\n\nA veteran actor, McKellen is known in part for his roles in the Lord of the Rings and X-Men franchises. He could potentially be revisiting either one of his roles as Gandalf or Magneto as well. With the latter, a variety of X-Men characters have been making multiverse cameos in MCU projects, so the door seems to be open for McKellen to return as Magneto. That might even happen in Deadpool & Wolverine, the new film coming this summer that is rumored to feature many exciting cameos, and McKellen's potential comeback would certainly fit the bill.\n\nAndy Serkis directing a new Lord of the Rings film could also mean that Gandalf could make an appearance with McKellen in the role. However, the 85-year-old actor joked that if producer Peter Jackson wants that to happen, then the new movie should be made sooner rather than later.\n\n\"I haven't shaved in months,\" McKellen said of how his Flagstaff role already has him looking like Gandalf, per The Times. \"There is no script, there is no offer, there is no plan. {"uri": "8183918186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "16:01:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T16:01:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T16:00:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/breaking-ian-mckellens-west-end-33057967", "title": "Ian McKellen's West End play's next performance pulled after horror stage fall", "body": "Ian McKellen's next stage performance has been cancelled after his horror fall\n\nSir Ian McKellen's next West End performance has been cancelled after he was rushed to hospital last night following a horror fall on stage.\n\nThe legendary actor, 85, suffered a fall on stage on Monday night and was taken to hospital. Wednesday's performance of the West End show Player Kings has been cancelled. In a statement posted to X, formerly Twitter, the production said he is \"recovering well\" and that they \"look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready\".\n\n\"The performance on Wednesday 19 June will be cancelled following Ian McKellen's fall during the performance of Player Kings on Monday (17 June)\", the statement said. \"Bookers for the affected performance will be contacted by their point of purchase directly. We look forward to welcoming audiences back to the Noel Coward Theatre on Thursday 20 June.\n\n\"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\" Sir Ian lost his footing during an intense fight scene in a performance of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London on Monday night and was rushed to hospital.\n\nHe reportedly let out a \"blood-curdling scream\" and pleaded: \"Help me.\" No serious harm appears to have been done to the Lord of the Rings star, who played Gandalf in the film franchise. Updating fans on Sir Ian's health, a spokesperson for the London theatre said: \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\" The statement also thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nThe audience were evacuated from the theatre on Monday and informed the show would be cancelled. Charlie Johnson, who witnessed the incident, spoke to Good Morning Britain about the impact of Sir Ian's fall. He explained: \"As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on and there were strobe lights and then it all went dark; at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out the wings. The way the stage works at the Noel Coward, there's a step down and that's where the stage meets the audience.\n\n\"I think what happened is he took his foot too far off that initial step and lost his balance and went headfirst into the audience. Within seconds, a blood curling stream arose from the actor and he was clearly in a lot of pain and screaming 'help me.'\" Other audience members shared their experience on X. One said: \"Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage on Monday evening at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.\" Another added: \"Shocking to watch, it was a terrible fall. Hoping he is not badly injured, he seemed to be in great pain.\"\n\nThis is a breaking showbiz news story. According to theatergoers, when the lights turned on after his fall, they could hear the actor cry for help. He lost his footing during an intense fight scene and took a fall after reportedly missing a step.\n\nPeople were then swiftly evacuated from the theatre and informed that the evening's performance would be cancelled. A spokesperson for the theatre later confirmed to The Mirror that the performance on Tuesday, 18 June would be axed so that Sir Ian could focus on his recovery.\n\nThey said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings. Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. Thank you to doctors Rachel and Lee who were on hand in the audience and to all the venue staff for their support.\"\n\nThe Lord of the Rings star theatre legend is expected to appear next in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production. Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, began its 12-week West End run in April.\n\nMeanwhile, an audience member appeared on Good Morning Britain and revealed he believes Sir Ian 'took his foot too far off a step' and 'lost his balance'. Speaking to Susanna Reid, Charlie Johnson said: \"As we approached the interval of the play, there was a fight scene going on and there were strobe lights and then it all went dark, at which point you could see the silhouette of Sir Ian come out the wings and the way the stage works at the Noel Coward, there's a step-down and where the stage meets the audience, I think what happened is he took his foot too far off that initial step and lost his balance and went head first into the audience.\n\n\"Within seconds, a blood-curling stream arose from the actor and he was clearly in a lot of pain and screaming 'help me'.\" Host Susanna answered: \"We wish him the very best and he recovers from the accident. I think it's amazing he's still doing fight scenes on stage at 85. in London since April, and the production has only a few weeks of shows remaining.\n\nHe's been outspoken about turning down lots of roles in his old age, but was open to doing this play, and recently He lost his footing during a fight scene while portraying John Falstaff at the Noel Coward Theatre in London. They cancelled the rest of the play and later cancelled Tuesday and Wednesday's performance as well.\n\nA post on social media confirmed his understudy David Semark will go on instead of him on Thursday. The statement said: \"David Semark will be playing the role of Sir John Falstaff for the final three scheduled performances of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London while Sir Ian McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday (1)8 June.\n\n\"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday July 3, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\nHe also shared his support for the NHS on X, formerly known as Twitter, Sir Ian wrote: \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support. Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nEarlier on Tuesday, the production shared a statement confirming the cancellation of Wednesday's performance. {"uri": "2024-06-392762016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "22:01:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T22:01:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T22:01:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://people.com/ian-mckellen-85-hospitalized-after-falling-off-stage-8665007", "title": "Ian McKellen, 85, Hospitalized After Falling Off London Stage Mid-Performance: Report", "body": "Michelle Tauber is an Executive Editorial Director at PEOPLE, overseeing Lifestyle (Parents, Health, Home, Travel, Food, Pets), Style & Beauty, Royals, Weddings and Politics. She was previously the founding Senior Editor of Royals at PEOPLE and PEOPLE's first and only Head Writer.\n\nActor Ian McKellen was hospitalized on June 17 after falling off stage mid-performance in London, the BBC reports.\n\nThe beloved English actor -- most popularly known for playing Gandalf in the blockbuster Lord of the Rings film trilogy and Magneto in the X-Men films -- fell during a performance of Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, at the No\u00ebl Coward theater in London.\n\nThe star, 85, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing, reports the BBC, and the audience was subsequently evacuated.\n\nMcKellen, who plays the character of John Falstaff in the play, reportedly fell off the front of the stage and cried out in pain as crew members rushed to help, the BBC reports.\n\n\"I really hope that he is going to be all right,\" audience member Sandro Trapani told the BBC.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\n\"As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance,\" Trapani said.\n\nEarlier In the midst of a clash with the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy, Sir Ian accidentally stepped and fell off the edge of the stage.\n\nWhen the house lights were turned on, he was heard shouting in agony as theatre staff hurried to assist him.\n\nThe crowd was quickly ushered out of the venue, and they were told that the night's show would not continue. Wish him all the best,\" posted another concerned theatre-goer.\n\nOne user commented: \"Audience shocked by Sir Ian McKellen's fall off stage on Monday evening at Noel Coward Theatre. Staff working hard to help him. Thoughts with him, cast and crew.\"\n\n\"It was a really bad fall. I hope that he is OK,\" replied another.\n\nA third reacted: \"Shocking to watch, it was a terrible fall. Hoping he is not badly injured, he seemed to be in great pain.\"\n\n\"Wasn't sure if it was part of the play. He sounded in a bad way. Hope he's OK,\" posted one concerned fan.\n\nWhile another expressed: \"It was very shocking indeed. Praying he is OK.\"\n\nSince the fall, Executives at London's Noel Coward Theatre have issued a statement, in which they have said: \"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\"\n\nThe Lord of the Rings superstar had recently ended a relationship with his boyfriend following a year together. {"uri": "8183439235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "10:55:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T10:55:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T10:54:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://phonemantra.com/ian-mckellen-to-make-full-recovery-after-stage-fall-in-london/", "title": "Ian McKellen to Make Full Recovery After Stage Fall in London", "body": "Ian McKellen, the esteemed British actor, is expected to fully recover after suffering a fall during a performance at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London. Here's a detailed look at the incident, his condition, and what the future holds for the veteran actor.\n\nOn a fateful Monday evening, Ian McKellen, 85, encountered an unexpected mishap while portraying John Falstaff in a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two. The incident occurred during a vigorous fight scene, causing McKellen to lose his footing and fall off the stage. The abruptness of the fall prompted the house lights to illuminate, and McKellen's cry was audible to the audience, signaling the need for immediate assistance.\n\nFollowing the incident, McKellen was quickly attended to by medical staff who rushed to his aid. The show, Player Kings, which commenced its 12-week run at London's West End in April, was halted for the evening, and the theater was evacuated as a precautionary measure.\n\nA statement issued by McKellen's representative conveyed gratitude for the outpouring of well-wishes from both the audience and the public. The statement assured fans that after undergoing a thorough medical evaluation, the NHS medical team has affirmed McKellen's prognosis for a speedy and complete recovery. Despite the scare, McKellen remains in high spirits, looking forward to resuming his role in the play.\n\nIn response to McKellen's condition, the production team decided to cancel the scheduled performance for the following day to allow McKellen adequate rest and recovery. Affected ticket holders were assured that they would be promptly notified of any updates regarding rescheduling or refunds.\n\nThe statement also extended heartfelt thanks to the medical professionals, including doctors Rachel and Lee, who were present at the venue and provided immediate assistance. Venue staff were also acknowledged for their swift response and support during the incident.\n\nIan McKellen, known for his illustrious career spanning decades, has been a pillar of the British theatre and film industry. His portrayal of iconic characters such as Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings and Magneto in X-Men has cemented his status as one of the most revered actors of his generation. "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://ca.movies.yahoo.com/sir-ian-mckellen-expected-return-001058937.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen expected to return to West End stage this week after fall", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen is expected to return to the West End stage this week following a fall mid-performance.\n\nThe 85-year-old, who is playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was reassured by NHS staff that he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\nThe remainder of the production was cancelled following the incident, while a spokesperson for the theatre later confirmed that Tuesday evening's performance had also been cancelled \"so Ian can rest\".\n\nSir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations for his work on screen and the recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK and US, Sir Ian is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nThe British star has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage during his career, receiving international acclaim and becoming a household name across the globe.\n\nHis largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nBut he also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, Sir David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nSir Ian, who now lives in Limehouse, is currently performing in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.", "source": {"uri": "ca.movies.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo! {"uri": "8182981221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "05:43:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T05:43:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T05:42:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/style/celebrity/celebrity-news/ian-mckellen-expected-to-return-to-work-this-week-after-fall-from-stage-during-performance/a134764452.html", "title": "Ian McKellen expected to return to work this week after fall from stage during performance", "body": "Even a fall from the West End stage is not expected to keep 85-year-old Sir Ian McKellen from performing for long.\n\nThe British actor has shown little sign of slowing down during his esteemed career, even marking his milestone 80th year with an 80-date nationwide solo tour.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations, McKellen has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage and is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nMost recently, McKellen has been seen playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nDuring Monday's performance, the veteran actor fell from the stage but has since been told he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" and is expected to appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nDuring his career, his largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nThe role won him an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor during the 2002 ceremony.\n\nIt marked his second Oscar nod, having been nominated three years previously for his role as James Whale in Bill Condon's period drama Gods And Monsters.\n\nMcKellen also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, McKellen has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nMcKellen has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nMcKellen acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, Sir David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time McKellen graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, McKellen has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nMcKellen has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nA commanding on-screen actor, McKellen has been widely acclaimed for roles including Bill Kraus in And The Band Played On about the AIDS epidemic, which earned him his first Emmy nod in 1994.\n\nHis role as Tsar Nicholas II in Rasputin won him a Golden Globe in 1997, as well as another Emmy nomination.\n\nHis West End stage credits include No Man's Land, Figures Of Speech, King Lear and Mother Goose, while he also starred in Broadway shows including Amadeus - which scored him a Tony award - Wild Honey and the revival of Waiting For Godot.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Academy_Awards", "type": We look forward to welcoming audiences back to the Noel Coward Theatre on Thursday 20 June.\n\n\"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to move to the He reportedly suffered a fractured wrist and other injuries.\n\nOn Tuesday, Sir Ian said he was looking forward to returning to work, raising hopes that he would return to the production at the Noel Coward Theatre.\n\nHowever, in a new statement he said: \"Thank you for the continued support and well wishes and I am pleased to say I am recovering well, but will not be able to play the remaining shows this week.\"\n\nThe play has three performances left to run and Sir Ian's role as Sir John Falstaff will be taken by his understudy, David Semark.\n\n\"The company, including Toheeb Jimoh, Richard Coyle and my fabulous understudy David Semark, are ready to take you on an epic journey through medieval England and the rise and fall of Henry IV. I urge you all to join them,\" Sir Ian said.\n\nThe producers added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday 3 July, before visiting Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\"\n\n'My recovery will be complete'\n\nIn his earlier statement, Sir Ian thanked fans for their kind messages and support. He said: \"Since the accident... my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nSir Ian also thanked two doctors who were in the audience on Monday and tended to him when he fell.\n\nThe actor is said to have lost his footing during a battle scene, falling off the front of the stage, and was heard to cry out in pain.\n\nThe production began its 12-week West End run in April, to rave reviews. {"uri": "8183267635", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:08:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:08:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:07:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.thehealthsite.com/news/actor-ian-mckellen-in-hospital-after-suffering-from-a-fall-during-london-stage-performance-1100568/", "title": "Actor Ian McKellen In Hospital After Suffering From A Fall During London Stage Performance", "body": "No one seemed to realise the actor had actually fallen during the scene. Since it happened suddenly, everyone assumed it was a part of the act, news reports stated.\n\nEminent actor Ian McKellen has landed in the hospital after suffering from a fall during a performance of 'Player Kings' -- a production of Shakespeare's 'Henry IV' -- at the No l Coward Theater in London on June 17. The English actor, who is most famous for essaying the role of 'Gandalf' in the 'Lord of the Rings' trilogy, and 'Magneto' in the 'X-Men' series, was in the middle of a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell off the stage mid-performance, news reports state. The audience was immediately evacuated and the 85-year-old was rushed to a hospital. According to a BBC report, McKellen continues to be in \"good spirits\", even though he \"cried out in pain\" and called \"for help\" after the nasty fall.\n\nPer the BBC report, a theatre spokesman said McKellen had had a scan, and medics assured he would \"make a speedy and full recovery\". \"Ian is in good spirits,\" the spokesman purportedly said. The actor is expected to return to the stage this week for a matinee performance. Interestingly, no one seemed to realise that the actor had actually fallen during the scene. Since it happened suddenly, everyone assumed it was a part of the act. It was only after the actor cried out that the staff rushed to his aid, and the audience was asked to evacuate.\n\nAge-related falls can be quite dangerous and elderly people have to be careful, especially if they are in their 70s and 80s. According to UK's National Health Service (NHS), older people are more likely to have a fall because they may have 'balance problems and muscle weakness', 'vision loss', or a 'long-term health condition', like heart disease, dementia, low blood pressure, etc., which can lead to dizziness.\n\nIt should be noted that while not all falls result in serious injuries, there is a lingering risk of broken bones. Additionally, older people ought to be careful because osteoporosis is a common problem.\n\nPer the BBC report, around five years ago, McKellen sustained another injury and was 'forced' to cancel a 'King Lear' showing at London's Duke of York Theatre. {"uri": "8182725075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "01:12:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T01:12:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T01:11:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.bridportnews.co.uk/news/national/24393814.sir-ian-mckellen-expected-return-west-end-stage-week-fall/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen expected to return to West End stage this week after fall", "body": "Even a fall from the West End stage is not expected to keep 85-year-old Sir Ian McKellen from performing for long.\n\nThe British actor has shown little sign of slowing down during his esteemed career, even marking his milestone 80th year with a 80-date nationwide solo tour.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations, Sir Ian has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage and is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nMost recently, Sir Ian has been seen playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nDuring Monday's performance, the veteran actor fell from the stage but has since been told he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" and is expected to appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nDuring his career, Sir Ian's largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nThe role won him an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor during the 2002 ceremony.\n\nIt marked his second Oscar nod, having been nominated three years previously for his role as James Whale in Bill Condon's period drama Gods And Monsters.\n\nSir Ian also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, Sir David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nSir Ian, who now lives in Limehouse, is currently performing in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.", "source": {"uri": "bridportnews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bridport and Lyme Regis News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-394426470", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:47:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:47:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:31:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/ian-mckellen-former-understudy-lauds-083150252.html", "title": "Ian McKellen's former understudy lauds actor's work ethic: 'A vanishing breed'", "body": "David Weston, Sir Ian McKellen's former understudy, has opened up about the actor's work ethics and the toll doing theatre can take physically.\n\nIn an essay for The Guardian, he described McKellen's commitment to the job and how he always showed up despite exhaustion or illness.\n\n\"After following him across the world as his understudy in King Lear in 2007, I know his dread of disappointing his audience. No matter how tired he was or how ill he felt, Sir Ian was always there,\" Weston writes.\n\n\"He is of the old school of actors who pride themselves on never missing a performance. A vanishing breed.\"\n\nMcKellen, 85, is currently playing John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of William Shakespeare's Henry IV, at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre.\n\nThe Lord of the Rings star slipped and fell from the stage while enacting a fight scene and was taken to hospital.\n\nMcKellen updated fans about his condition on Tuesday. \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" he said via his publicist Clair Dobbs.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nWeston, whose book Covering McKellen: An Understudy's Tale won the 2012 Theatre Book Prize, went on to describe the specific scene in which McKellen was injured, explaining how it has caused injuries to other actors, including himself.\n\n\"There must be something about that scene. Not only has Sir Ian been injured in it, but in 1961 that fine actor Tony Britton was playing Hotspur at the Old Vic in London, and was conveyed to St Thomas's hospital in full armour having suffered a severe head wound when Prince Hal mistimed a swipe to his head. He bore the scar on his forehead to his dying day,\" he wrote.\n\n\"My Prince Hal lunged at me, I parried with my dagger, swung round and found myself hurtling off the slippery metal stage on to the ancient stones five feet below.\n\n\"I fell on to a rock, still holding my sword tightly in my left hand, and broke my wrist.\"\n\nWeston described the physical demands of doing theatre and highlighted how the challenges intensify for ageing actors as they contend with learning lines, struggling with physical movements like kneeling as well as deteriorating vision and hearing.\n\n\"The craft becomes increasingly difficult for ageing actors. The lines become more difficult to learn, the dread of drying on stage can affect the greatest of actors, although I've never suffered it myself.\n\n\"Shakespeare becomes impossible unless you're playing the king: you spend so much time on your knees and have nothing to grab hold of to help you get up. Your eyesight goes. You find it hard to see steps or the edges of things.\n\n\"You become slightly deaf and have difficulty hearing your cues, especially from young actors who don't project like they did in your youth.\"\n\nIn a statement to The Independent, a representative for Player Kings said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nPlayer Kings is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, production and cast.\n\n\"The many messages of love and support will, I am sure, aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me.\"\n\nThe screen and stage actor, 85, was taken to hospital on McKellen recuperates following his fall on Monday, June 17.\"\n\nIt added: \"We look forward to Ian returning to the production, which begins a national tour in Bristol on Wednesday, July 3, before {"uri": "8182690593", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "00:24:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T00:24:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T00:23:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/uk/sir-ian-mckellen-expected-to-return-to-west-end-stage-this-week-after-fall-IHQCUKYQZVNGDPF4CD2JLO4XZY/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen expected to return to West End stage this week after fall", "body": "The veteran actor was reassured by NHS staff that he will make a 'speedy and full recovery'.\n\nSir Ian McKellen is expected to return to the West End stage this week following a fall mid-performance.\n\nThe 85-year-old, who is playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was reassured by NHS staff that he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\nThe remainder of the production was cancelled following the incident, while a spokesperson for the theatre later confirmed that Tuesday evening's performance had also been cancelled \"so Ian can rest\".\n\nSir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations for his work on screen and the recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK and US, Sir Ian is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nThe British star has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage during his career, receiving international acclaim and becoming a household name across the globe.\n\nHis largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nBut he also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, Sir David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to {"uri": "8182688679", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "00:20:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T00:20:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T00:20:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/uk-news/2024/06/18/sir-ian-mckellen-expected-to-return-to-west-end-stage-this-week-after-fall/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen expected to return to West End stage this week after fall", "body": "The veteran actor was reassured by NHS staff that he will make a 'speedy and full recovery'.\n\nSir Ian McKellen is expected to return to the West End stage this week following a fall mid-performance.\n\nThe 85-year-old, who is playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was reassured by NHS staff that he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\nThe remainder of the production was cancelled following the incident, while a spokesperson for the theatre later confirmed that Tuesday evening's performance had also been cancelled \"so Ian can rest\".\n\nSir Ian is expected to next appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations for his work on screen and the recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK and US, Sir Ian is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nThe British star has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage during his career, receiving international acclaim and becoming a household name across the globe.\n\nHis largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nBut he also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, Sir David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nSir Ian, who now lives in Limehouse, is currently performing in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.", "source": {"uri": "expressandstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Express & Star"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": 85-year-old, who is playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was reassured by NHS staff that he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" after he fell from the stage during Monday evening's performance.\n\nThe remainder of the production was cancelled following the incident, while a spokesperson for the theatre later confirmed that Tuesday evening's performance had also been cancelled \"so Ian can rest\".\n\nWith two Oscar nominations for his work on screen and the recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK and US, Sir Ian is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nThe British star has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage during his career, receiving international acclaim and becoming a household name across the globe.\n\nHis largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nBut he also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and
