{"uri": "8183068348", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "06:53:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T06:53:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T06:52:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41418451.html", "title": "Ian McKellen expected to return to West End stage this week after fall", "body": "The British actor has shown little sign of slowing down during his esteemed career, even marking his milestone 80th year with an 80-date nationwide solo tour.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations, McKellen has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage and is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nMost recently, McKellen has been seen playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nDuring Monday's performance, the veteran actor fell from the stage but has since been told he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" and is expected to appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nDuring his career, McKellen's largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nThe role won him an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor during the 2002 ceremony.\n\nIt marked his second Oscar nod, having been nominated three years previously for his role as James Whale in Bill Condon's period drama Gods And Monsters.\n\nMcKellen also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, McKellen has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nMcKellen has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nMcKellen acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nWhat happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor\n\nBy the time McKellen graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, McKellen has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nMcKellen has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nA commanding on-screen actor, McKellen has been widely acclaimed for roles including Bill Kraus in And The Band Played On about the AIDS epidemic, which earned him his first Emmy nod in 1994.\n\nHis role as Tsar Nicholas II in Rasputin won him a Golden Globe in 1997, as well as another Emmy nomination.\n\nHis West End stage credits include No Man's Land, Figures Of Speech, King Lear and Mother Goose, while he also starred in Broadway shows including Amadeus - which scored him a Tony award - Wild Honey and the revival of {"uri": "8183476581", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:18:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:18:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:17:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/profile-who-is-sir-ian-mckellen-1639414.html", "title": "Profile: Who is Ian McKellen? | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "With two Oscar nominations for his work on screen and the recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK and US, Sir Ian McKellen is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nThe 85-year-old has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage, receiving international acclaim and becoming a household name across the globe.\n\nHis largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nBut he also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, McKellen has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nMcKellen often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12, and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nMcKellen acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Derek Jacobi, David Frost and Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time McKellen graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, McKellen has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nMcKellen has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nMcKellen, who now lives in Limehouse, is currently performing in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, at The theatre quickly clicked into emergency mode and staff members darted to their fallen star.\n\nThe audience - stunned and filled with anxiety - were promptly escorted out of the theatre with news that the rest of the show stood cancelled. In the aftermath of the shocking episode, spectators took to social media platform X (formerly Twitter) to share their thoughts about what they had just seen.\n\nOne audience member unflinchingly described the incident as a \"really bad fall\".\n\nAnother viewer, still under the shock of the spectacle unfailingly recounted: \"Just witnessed Ian McKellan severely injure himself after falling off stage at Noel Coward Theatre. {"uri": "8184948810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:40:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:40:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:40:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/news/ian-mckellen-fall-player-kings-understudy-b2565110.html", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen's former understudy weighs in on actor's shock fall from stage", "body": "{{ #verifyErrors }}{{ message }}{{ /verifyErrors }}{{ ^verifyErrors }}Something went wrong. Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nDavid Weston, Sir Ian McKellen's former understudy, has opened up about the actor's work ethics and the toll doing theatre can take physically.\n\nIn an essay for The Guardian, he described McKellen's commitment to the job and how he always showed up despite exhaustion or illness.\n\n\"After following him across the world as his understudy in King Lear in 2007, I know his dread of disappointing his audience. No matter how tired he was or how ill he felt, Sir Ian was always there,\" Weston writes.\n\n\"He is of the old school of actors who pride themselves on never missing a performance. A vanishing breed.\"\n\nMcKellen, 85, is currently playing John Falstaff in Player Kings, a production of William Shakespeare's Henry IV, at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre.\n\nThe Lord of the Rings star slipped and fell from the stage while enacting a fight scene and was taken to hospital.\n\nMcKellen updated fans about his condition on Tuesday. \"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" he said via his publicist Clair Dobbs.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. To them, of course, I am hugely indebted. They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nWeston, whose book Covering McKellen: An Understudy's Tale won the 2012 Theatre Book Prize, went on to describe the specific scene in which McKellen was injured, explaining how it has caused injuries to other actors, including himself.\n\n\"There must be something about that scene. Not only has Sir Ian been injured in it, but in 1961 that fine actor Tony Britton was playing Hotspur at the Old Vic in London, and was conveyed to St Thomas's hospital in full armour having suffered a severe head wound when Prince Hal mistimed a swipe to his head. He bore the scar on his forehead to his dying day,\" he wrote.\n\n\"My Prince Hal lunged at me, I parried with my dagger, swung round and found myself hurtling off the slippery metal stage on to the ancient stones five feet below.\n\n\"I fell on to a rock, still holding my sword tightly in my left hand, and broke my wrist.\"\n\nWeston described the physical demands of doing theatre and highlighted how the challenges intensify for ageing actors as they contend with learning lines, struggling with physical movements like kneeling as well as deteriorating vision and hearing.\n\n\"The craft becomes increasingly difficult for ageing actors. The lines become more difficult to learn, the dread of drying on stage can affect the greatest of actors, although I've never suffered it myself.\n\n\"Shakespeare becomes impossible unless you're playing the king: you spend so much time on your knees and have nothing to grab hold of to help you get up. Your eyesight goes. You find it hard to see steps or the edges of things.\n\n\"You become slightly deaf and have difficulty hearing your cues, especially from young actors who don't project like they did in your youth.\"\n\nIn a statement to The Independent, a representative for Player Kings said: \"Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n\"Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n\"The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\"\n\nPlayer Kings is due to move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July and will also be staged in Birmingham, {"uri": "8183156186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "07:55:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T07:55:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T07:54:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/showbiz-news/sir-ian-mckellen-taken-hospital-29372742", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen taken to hospital after falling off stage", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen was taken to hospital after he fell from the stage during a West End performance.\n\nThe Lord Of The Rings actor, 85, who is currently playing John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre, was in a fight scene when he lost his footing and fell from the stage on Monday, June 17. The audience were informed the remainder of the performance had been cancelled and were evacuated from the theatre.\n\nDoctors have said the actor will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" and he is expected to appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production. During his career, Sir Ian's biggest role on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nREAD MORE: Doctor told mum 'sit down' after son, 2, began to 'fade before her eyes'\n\nREAD MORE: Liverpool bakery where generations worked making 'cakes to die for'\n\nThe role won him an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor in 2002. It marked his second Oscar nod, having been nominated three years previously for his role as James Whale in Bill Condon's period drama Gods And Monsters.\n\nSir Ian also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage. The actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she [hi mum] said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mum died when he was just 12 and he would lose his dad at the age of 22. Sir Ian acted at all the schools he attended. When at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, Sir David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement. Very few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003. Sir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions. Back in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nA commanding on-screen actor, Sir Ian has been widely acclaimed for roles including Bill Kraus in And The Band Played On about the AIDS epidemic, which earned him his first Emmy nod in 1994.\n\nHis role as Tsar Nicholas II in Rasputin won him a Golden Globe in 1997, as well as another Emmy nomination. His West End stage credits include No Man's Land, Figures Of Speech, King Lear and Mother Goose, while he also starred in Broadway shows including Amadeus which scored him a Tony award Wild Honey and the revival of Waiting For Godot.\n\nIn 1991, Sir Ian was knighted for his services to the performing arts.\n\nDon't miss the biggest and breaking stories by signing up to the Echo Daily newsletter treasure as he goes back on stage", "body": "Even a fall from the West End stage is not expected to keep 85-year-old Sir Ian McKellen from performing for long who is due back on stage today.\n\nThe British actor has shown little sign of slowing down during his esteemed career, even marking his milestone 80th year with an 80-date nationwide solo tour, with his actual birthday being marked at Bolton's Albert Halls.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations, Sir Ian has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage and is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nMost recently, Sir Ian has been seen playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nDuring Monday's performance, the veteran actor fell from the stage but has since been told he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" and is expected to appear in Thursday's performance of the production.\n\nSir Ian said he is \"looking forward to returning to work\" as he thanked the NHS staff who cared for him after he fell from a West End stage earlier this week.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, he said he is \"hugely indebted\" to the medical staff who have assured him his recovery will be \"complete and speedy\".\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" Sir Ian said in the statement posted to X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nSir Ian had been expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance, but it was announced on Tuesday that the show will now not return until Thursday.Sir Ian celebrates his birthday at the Albert Halls in Bolton\n\nDuring his career, Sir Ian's largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nThe role won him an Oscar nomination for best supporting actor during the 2002 ceremony.\n\nIt marked his second Oscar nod, having been nominated three years previously for his role as James Whale in Bill Condon's period drama Gods And Monsters.\n\nSir Ian also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nSir Ian at Bolton School\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, Sir David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nSir Ian\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nSir Ian at the Albert Halls\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nA commanding on-screen actor, Sir Ian has been widely acclaimed for roles including Bill Kraus in And The Band Played On about the AIDS epidemic, which earned him his first Emmy nod in 1994.\n\nHis role as Tsar Nicholas II in Rasputin won him a Golden Globe in 1997, as well as another Emmy nomination.\n\nHis West End stage credits include No Man's Land, Figures Of Speech, King Lear and Mother Goose, while he also starred in Broadway shows including Amadeus - which scored him a Tony award - Wild Honey and the revival of Waiting For Godot.\n\nIn 1991, Sir Ian was knighted for his services to the performing arts.", "source": {"uri": "theboltonnews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Bolton News"}, "authors": [], 'looking forward to returning to work' after falling off stage | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Ian McKellen has said he is \"looking forward to returning to work\" as he thanked the healthcare staff who cared for him after he fell from a London stage earlier this week.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor (85) was portraying John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, he said he is \"hugely indebted\" to the medical staff who have assured him his recovery will be \"complete and speedy\".\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" McKellan said in the statement posted to X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nMcKellan had been expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance, but it was announced on Tuesday that the show will now not return until Thursday.\n\nIn a statement posted to X, the show added: \"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement on Monday night that McKellan was in \"good spirits\" and thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nMcKellan was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nThe Methodist minister from Norfolk recalled how McKellan seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene before falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to end its run at the Noel Coward Theatre on Saturday.\n\nThe play will then move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July before being staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nMcKellan's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is best known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over returning to work' after falling off stage | Connaught Telegraph", "body": "Ian McKellen 'looking forward to returning to work' after falling off stage RSS Syndicated Content Published: Wed 19 Jun 2024, 9:31 AM Last updated: Wed 19 Jun 2024, 9:59 AM\n\nBy Naomi Clarke, PA Senior Entertainment Reporter\n\nIan McKellen has said he is \"looking forward to returning to work\" as he thanked the healthcare staff who cared for him after he fell from a London stage earlier this week.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor (85) was portraying John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, he said he is \"hugely indebted\" to the medical staff who have assured him his recovery will be \"complete and speedy\".\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" McKellan said in the statement posted to X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nMcKellan had been expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance, but it was announced on Tuesday that the show will now not return until Thursday.\n\nIn a statement posted to X, the show added: \"We are delighted that Ian is recovering well, and look forward to him returning to the production as soon as he is ready. We will keep audiences updates regarding remaining performances this week.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the London theatre said in a statement on Monday night that McKellan was in \"good spirits\" and thanked doctors Rachel and Lee who were \"on hand in the audience\" and to the venue staff \"for their support\".\n\nA BBC journalist, who saw the play, said the actor was in a scene involving the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy when he fell off the front of the stage.\n\nMcKellan was heard to cry out in pain as staff rushed to help.\n\nAudience member Paul Critchley told the PA news agency it was a \"shock\" to witness the fall.\n\nThe Methodist minister from Norfolk recalled how McKellan seemed to trip as he moved downstage to take a more active part in the scene before falling off the stage directly in front of the audience.\n\nPlayer Kings, a production of Henry IV, parts one and two, adapted and directed by Robert Icke, is due to end its run at the Noel Coward Theatre on Saturday.\n\nThe play will then move to the Bristol Hippodrome in July before being staged in Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle.\n\nMcKellan's career has spanned more than six decades and seen the actor perform at theatres around the country.\n\nOn screen he is best known for playing Magneto in the X-Men films and Gandalf in Peter Jackson's fantasy trilogy, based on the books from JRR Tolkien.\n\nOn the stage he has played a number of Shakespearean characters including Richard II, Macbeth, Coriolanus, and King Lear.\n\nHis many acting credits have led to a number of accolades over the years including several Olivier Awards.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Wed 19 Jun 2024, 9:31 AM Last updated: Wed 19 Jun 2024, 9:59 AM", "source": {"uri": "con-telegraph.ie", "dataType": {"uri": "8186305928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "04:26:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T04:26:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T04:20:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/news/24397470.sir-ian-mckellen-expected-return-west-end-stage-week/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen, 85,  'hugely indebted' to NHS staff after falling from stage", "body": "Even a fall from the West End stage is not expected to keep 85-year-old Sir Ian McKellen from performing for long as he is due back today (Thursday).\n\nThe Burnley-born actor has shown little sign of slowing down during his esteemed career, even marking his milestone 80th year with an 80-date nationwide solo tour.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations, Sir Ian has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage and is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nMost recently, Sir Ian has been seen playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nDuring Monday's performance, the veteran actor fell from the stage but has since been told he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" and is expected to appear in Thursday's performance of the production.\n\nSir Ian said he is \"looking forward to returning to work\" as he thanked the NHS staff who cared for him after the tumble.\n\nIn a statement on Tuesday evening, he said he is \"hugely indebted\" to the medical staff who have assured him his recovery will be \"complete and speedy\".\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" Sir Ian said in the statement posted to X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAfter the accident, he was taken to hospital to receive treatment and the remainder of Monday and Tuesday's performances were cancelled to allow him to rest.\n\nSir Ian had been expected to return for Wednesday's matinee performance, but it was announced on Tuesday that the show would not return until Thursday.Sir Ian celebrates his birthday at the Albert Halls in Bolton\n\nDuring his career, Sir Ian's largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nThe role won him an Oscar nomination for best-supporting actor during the 2002 ceremony.\n\nIt marked his second Oscar nod, having been nominated three years previously for his role as James Whale in Bill Condon's period drama Gods And Monsters.\n\nSir Ian also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nSir Ian at Bolton School\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he lost his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Sir Derek Jacobi, Sir David Frost and Dame Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nSir Ian\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nSir Ian at the Albert Halls\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nA commanding on-screen actor, Sir Ian has been widely acclaimed for roles including Bill Kraus in And The Band Played On about the AIDS epidemic, which earned him his first Emmy nod in 1994.\n\nHis role as Tsar Nicholas II in Rasputin won him a Golden Globe in 1997, as well as another Emmy nomination.\n\nHis West End stage credits include No Man's Land, Figures Of Speech, King Lear and Mother Goose, while he also starred in Broadway shows including Amadeus - which scored him a Tony award - Wild Honey and the revival of Waiting For Godot.\n\nIn 1991, Sir Ian was knighted for his services to the performing arts.", "source": {"uri": "lancashiretelegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Lancashire Telegraph"}, They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy, and I am looking forward to returning to work,\" he added, sharing a message of thanks for the public's \"kind messages and support.\"\n\nMr. Johnson said Sir McKellen, 85, \"sort of dove head first\" and landed on an audience member, causing the actor to cry out in agony.\n\n\"Within seconds, he was screaming; he was screaming, 'Help me, my arm. Help me,' in a way that I've sort of never heard anyone say before,\" Mr. Johnson continued. \"So it was, it was difficult obviously to hear that and to hear it happen and see it happen to such a fantastic person.\"\n\nAccording to Mr. Johnson, theatergoers seated in the first two rows of the auditorium were quickly ushered out of the theater. \"Within 30 seconds, the rest of the auditorium was emptied,\" he recalled.\n\nActors Toheeb Jimoh, known for his role in \"Ted Lasso,\" and Richard Coyle, star of the British sitcom \"Coupling\" and the 2022 film \"Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore,\" also star in the production, with Mr. Coyle playing King Henry IV.\n\n\"Player Kings\" debuted on April 1, with performances scheduled through June 22. {"uri": "8183520686", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "11:47:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T11:47:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T11:46:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.westmeathindependent.ie/2024/06/18/profile-who-is-ian-mckellen/", "title": "Profile: Who is Ian McKellen? | Westmeath Independent", "body": "Profile: Who is Ian McKellen? RSS Syndicated Content Published: Tue 18 Jun 2024, 12:15 PM Last updated: Tue 18 Jun 2024, 12:43 PM\n\nBy William Warnes, PA\n\nWith two Oscar nominations for his work on screen and the recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK and US, Sir Ian McKellen is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nThe 85-year-old has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage, receiving international acclaim and becoming a household name across the globe.\n\nHis largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nBut he also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, McKellen has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nMcKellen often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12, and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nMcKellen acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Derek Jacobi, David Frost and Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time McKellen graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, McKellen has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nMcKellen has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nMcKellen, who now lives in Limehouse, is currently performing in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Tue 18 Jun 2024, 12:15 PM Last updated: Tue 18 Jun 2024, 12:43 PM", "source": {"uri": "westmeathindependent.ie", "dataType": No matter how tired he was or how bad he felt, Sir Ian was always there, Weston writes.\n\nHe belongs to the old school of actors who pride themselves on never missing a performance. A dying breed.\n\nMcKellen, 85, currently plays John Falstaff in Kings of Gamblersa production by William Shakespeare Henry IVat the Nol Coward Theatre.\n\nTHE the Lord of the Rings The star slipped and fell off stage while performing a fight scene and was taken to hospital.\n\nMcKellen updated fans on his condition on Tuesday. I would like to thank everyone for their kind messages and support, he said via his publicist Clair Dobbs.\n\nSince the accident, during a performance of Kings of Gamblers Last night my injuries were diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service. Of course, I owe them a lot. They assured me that my recovery would be full and speedy and I look forward to returning to work.\n\nWeston, whose book McKellen cover: the story of an understudy won the 2012 Theater Book Prize, then described the specific scene in which McKellen was injured, explaining how it caused injuries to other actors, including himself.\n\nThere must be something in this scene. Not only was Sir Ian injured there, but in 1961 the excellent actor Tony Britton was playing Hotspur at the Old Vic in London and was taken to St Thomass Hospital in full armor after suffering a serious head injury when the Prince Hal mistimed a move. at his head. He carried the scar on his forehead until his death, he wrote.\n\nMy prince Hal rushed at me, I parried with my dagger, turned and found myself tumbling down the slippery metal stage onto the ancient stones five feet below.\n\nI fell on a rock, still holding my sword tightly in my left hand, and broke my wrist.\n\nWeston described the physical demands of theater and highlighted how the challenges intensify for aging actors as they deal with learning lines, physical movements like kneeling as well as deteriorating posture. vision and hearing.\n\nThe job becomes more and more difficult for aging actors. Lines become more difficult to learn, the fear of drying out on stage can affect bigger actors, although I've never experienced it myself.\n\nShakespeare becomes impossible unless you play the king: you spend so much time on your knees and have nothing to hold on to to help you get up. Your vision disappears. You have trouble seeing steps or the edges of things.\n\nYou become slightly deaf and have difficulty hearing your cues, especially from young actors who don't project like they did in your youth.\n\nIn a statement to The independenta representative of Kings of Gamblers said: Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ians' fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\nFollowing a scan, the brilliant NHS team assured us that he would make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in great spirits.\n\nThe production made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday June 18 so that Ian could rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow.\n\nKings of Gamblers is set to move to Bristol Racecourse in July and will also take place in Birmingham, Two doctors in attendance of the London production provided aid for a fractured wrist.\n\n\"After three nights in hospital, the effects of my fall onstage have been fully analysed and I'm now having physiotherapy, light exercise and a lot of essential rest at home,\" McKellen said in a Thursday statement. \"Meanwhile my part in 'Player Kings' is filled by the redoubtable David Semark supported by Robert Icke's amazing production and cast.\"\n\nThe Shakespearian actor thanked fans for their messages of love and support during this time, noting that he is sure it will \"aid the speedy recovery that my doctors have promised me.\" McKellen reportedly will not be available for remaining West End performances, but will return for the beginning of the national tour beginning July 3.\n\nDuring McKellen's six-decade long career, he has played nearly every Shakespearean lead, including King Lear, Richard II, Coriolanus, Iago, Richard III and Macbeth. He most recently starred as the title character in Sean Mathias' film adaptation of \"Hamlet\" released in February of this year.\n\nMcKellan stars alongside Toheeb Jimoh of \"Ted Lasso\" as Hal and Richard Coyle of \"The Chilling Adventures of Sabrina\" as King Henry IV in the limited 12 week run. {"uri": "8183415111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "10:39:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T10:39:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T10:38:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/06/18/sir-ian-mckellen-almost-joined-emmerdale-coronation-street-banned-21056316/", "title": "Sir Ian McKellen almost had Emmerdale role but Coronation Street boss banned him", "body": "Sir Ian McKellen almost appeared on Emmerdale, but unfortunately, Coronation Street's creator prevented the casting.\n\nWhile appearing on This Morning last year, Sir Ian, now 85, spoke about his master plan to appear in every soap playing the same character.\n\nThe idea began to formulate when he appeared in ten episodes of Coronation Street in 2005 as con artist Lionel Hipkiss, who pretended to be an author called Mel Hutchwright.\n\nLionel caused havoc when he tried to trick the street's book club into funding the publishing of his nonexistent novel, but luckily Ken Barlow (William Roache) exposed him in the nick of time.\n\nSir Ian told hosts Dermot O'Leary and Alison Hammond that he has 'happy' memories of his time on the soap, and it inspired him to delve further into the soap world.\n\n'I was playing a conman, and I was found out so I can never go back as that character as they'll know who I am. I had the idea that I might go into other soaps as the same character,' he explained.\n\nFellow ITV soap Emmerdale was on board initially, and he even started the process of convincing BBC's Eastenders to get involved too.\n\n'I got onto Emmerdale and they said: \"Yes, we're up for it\". I was just going to call up Eastenders, and say: \"Can I just be a character sitting in the Queen Vic?\"'\n\nHowever, the late Tony Warren, who created Coronation Street, didn't approve and forced Ian to abandon his idea.\n\n'Tony Warren who invented Coronation Street said \"Absolutely not, the soaps do not recognise each other and you may not be that character anywhere else\".'\n\nIn response to the anecdote, both Dermot and Alison told Ian that it was 'a shame,' and praised him for the unique idea.\n\n'Wouldn't it be good?' Sir Ian concluded. Well, it's never too late!\n\nOn June 17, 2024, it was reported Sir Ian was rushed to hospital after a dramatic fall during a performance of Player Kings at the No\u00ebl Coward Theatre in London.\n\nThe star reportedly stumbled during an intense fight scene, causing him to fall off the stage.\n\nAccording to an update from a representative for the theatre, the actor is expected to make a full and speedy recovery and is not badly injured.\n\nThe incident occurred during a battle sequence between his character, John Falstaff, and the Prince of Wales and Henry Percy.\n\nAfter Sir Ian lost his footing and tumbled from the stage, the house lights quickly came up, and he was heard crying out in pain.\n\nTheatre staff and medical personnel promptly attended to the actor.\n\nFollowing the accident, the audience was evacuated and informed that the evening show was cancelled and their tickets would be refunded.\n\nAn update from a representative for Player Kings sent Metro.co.uk the following statement: 'Thank you to our audience and the general public for their well wishes following Ian's fall during this evening's performance of Player Kings.\n\n'Following a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits.\n\n'The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. The star's representative says that he \" is doing OK .\" A statement released by the producers of the play reveals that McKellen is expected to make a \" speedy and full recovery .\" SCREENRANT VIDEO OF THE DAY SCROLL TO CONTINUE WITH CONTENT\n\nIan McKellen has been hospitalized after a fall during a performance. The multi-talented star of stage and screen is likely most widely known for his performances as Magneto in the X-Men franchise and as the iconic J.R.R. Tolkien character Gandalf in the Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit trilogies. The star has been nominated for two Oscars over the course of his career, for The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King and for 1999's Gods and Monsters, in which he played Frankenstein director James Whale.\n\nPer Deadline, Ian McKellen fell offstage during the first act of a performance of his West End play Player Kings and was taken to the hospital. Claire Dobbs, the representative for the actor, reports that he \"is doing OK.\" At the time of writing, nothing further is known about the injuries sustained by the actor during the performance, the remainder of which was cancelled. WhatsOnStage reports that producers of the show have issued a statement sharing that he is \"in good spirits\" and is expected to make a \"speedy and full recovery.\" Read the full statement below:\n\nFollowing a scan, the brilliant NHS team have assured us that he will make a speedy and full recovery and Ian is in good spirits. The production has made the decision to cancel the performance on Tuesday 18 June so Ian can rest. Those affected will be contacted by their point of purchase as soon as possible tomorrow. {"uri": "8183029909", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "06:24:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T06:24:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T06:23:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/entertainment/2024/0618/1455262-ian-mckellen-expected-back-on-london-stage-after-fall/", "title": "Ian McKellen expected back on London stage after fall", "body": "Ian McKellen is expected to be back performing in London this week after falling from the stage during a show on Monday.\n\nThe 85-year-old has been playing John Falstaff in Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre in London.\n\nDuring Monday's performance, the veteran actor fell from the stage but has since been told he will make a \"speedy and full recovery\" and is expected to appear in Wednesday's matinee performance of the production.\n\nThe British actor has shown little sign of slowing down during his esteemed career, even marking his milestone 80th year with an 80-date solo tour.\n\nWith two Oscar nominations, McKellen has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage and is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nWe need your consent to load this YouTube contentWe use YouTube to manage extra content that can set cookies on your device and collect data about your activity. Please review their details and accept them to load the content.Manage Preferences\n\nHe is best known on the big screen for his role as Gandalf in The Lord of the Rings trilogy.\n\nThe role won him an Oscar nomination for Best Supporting Actor in 2002 for his performance in 2001's The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring.\n\nIt marked his second Oscar nod, having been nominated three years previously for his role as James Whale in Bill Condon's period drama Gods and Monsters.\n\nWe need your consent to load this YouTube contentWe use YouTube to manage extra content that can set cookies on your device and collect data about your activity. Please review their details and accept them to load the content.Manage Preferences\n\nMcKellen also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, he has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars of the Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III, and his one-man show Ian McKellen on Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nHe has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with The Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she (his mother) said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nMcKellen acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWe need your consent to load this YouTube contentWe use YouTube to manage extra content that can set cookies on your device and collect data about your activity. Please review their details and accept them to load the content.Manage Preferences\n\nWhen at Bolton School, he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge, and was soon appearing in regular productions.\n\nBy the time McKellen graduated in 1961, he had decided to become an actor. He secured his first job in a production of A Man for All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, McKellen has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nMcKellen has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nIn July 2000, he wrote in The Independent in the UK: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nA commanding on-screen actor, McKellen has been widely acclaimed for roles including Bill Kraus in And the Band Played On about the AIDS epidemic, which earned him his first Emmy nod in 1994.\n\nHis role as Tsar Nicholas II in Rasputin won him a Golden Globe in 1997 as well as another Emmy nomination.\n\nHe has received five British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) Award nominations: four for his performances in The Dresser, The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring, and Richard III, and also a screenplay nomination for Richard III.\n\nHis West End stage credits include No Man's Land, Figures of Speech, King Lear, and Mother Goose.\n\nHe has also starred in Broadway shows including Amadeus - which earned him a Tony Award - Wild Honey, and the revival of Waiting for Godot.\n\nIn 1991, he was knighted by Britain's Queen Elizabeth II for his services to the performing arts.\n\nSource: Press Association", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTE.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": As far as I saw, he was conscious because he was asking for assistance.\"\n\nMcKellen - who plays John Falstaff in the production - was in the midst of a fight scene when the incident occurred.\n\nThe veteran actor cried out in pain after he fell off stage and theatre staff rushed to help him.\n\n'Player Kings' began its 12-week West End run in April, and McKellen previously admitted that he was relishing the opportunity.\n\nHe told the BBC earlier this year: \"Actors who have taken on the role say it is verbally very challenging - it seems that the role was written for a particular actor and comedian in Shakespeare's time, so it's a bit like being given a script for Michael McIntyre.\"\n\nThe production was due to move to Bristol, Birmingham, Norwich and Newcastle in the coming months, and McKellen was looking forward to touring the country.\n\nHe said: \"The play itself has so many settings across England, from the taverns of the East End to the rural peaceful countryside of {"uri": "2024-06-392817997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:57:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:57:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T22:16:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/celebrity/arid-41418436.html", "title": "Profile: Who is Sir Ian McKellen?", "body": "The 85-year-old has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage, receiving international acclaim and becoming a household name across the globe.\n\nHis largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nBut he also found mainstream success with his performances as Magneto in the X-Men series and as the title character in the film adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III.\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Derek Jacobi, David Frost and Margaret Drabble.\n\nBy the time Sir Ian graduated in 1961 he had decided to become an actor, and landed his first job in a production of A Man For All Seasons at the Belgrade Theatre in Coventry.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nSir Ian, who now lives in Limehouse, is currently performing in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, at {"uri": "2024-06-396321663", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:16:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:16:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:00:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/style/celebrity/celebrity-news/disappointed-theatre-fans-send-get-well-wishes-to-sir-ian-mckellen/a1012064310.html", "title": "'Disappointed' theatre fans send get well wishes to Sir Ian McKellen", "body": "Theatregoers have spoken of their disappointment and sent their good wishes to Sir Ian McKellen as he recuperates following a fall from a West End stage on Monday.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor, 85, was portraying John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nSir Ian revealed on Thursday that he is having physiotherapy while he takes a break from performing following the fall.\n\nThe final London dates of Player Kings will see Sir Ian's understudy, David Semark, take on the role of Falstaff.\n\nRania Margaronis, 56, flew for four hours from Greece specifically to see Sir Ian perform.\n\nShe said: \"It was shocking really because knowing someone so professional and so talented and at his age, it's really scary.\n\n\"I wish him all the best. I'm a great fan, I came all the way from Greece to see him and I was really disappointed. We love him and we're very proud to have him.\"\n\nWendy Geri, 84, travelled from Israel to see him perform, and booked a front row ticket as soon as she saw the play advertised. She said she was \"devastated\" at the news that Sir Ian would not perform, describing it as a \"big disappointment\".\n\nShe said: \"It's a very big disappointment. I've watched him on YouTube, I've watched him in conversations. I'm a student of what he's done. And he slipped up. I'm devastated.\"\n\nSophie Starnes, 34, a teacher who flew from California, said at the news Sir Ian would not perform: \"We were slightly disappointed, but obviously his health has to come first. And I'm sure it's still going to be a wonderful performance.\n\n\"We really hope he gets well soon and he's back on stage as soon as possible. It's still going to be a fantastic performance.\"\n\nCorin Doregger, 61, a retired teacher, flew from Vienna to see Sir Ian.\n\nShe said: \"I'm a bit disappointed because I booked tickets last year, and flew over from Vienna specially. When I heard he'd had a fall, I thought 'that's it'.\"\n\nShe said her message to the actor is: \"Get better soon and I'm sorry to have missed you.\"\n\nShe said: '\"I tried to see him in Keswick some years ago and didn't get to because it was a ballot, so this was my only chance. assured him his recovery will be \"complete and speedy\".\n\n\"I want to thank everyone for their kind messages and support,\" Sir Ian said in the statement posted to X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"Since the accident, during a performance of Player Kings last night, my injuries have been diagnosed and treated by a series of experts, specialists and nurses working for the National Health Service.\n\n\"To them, of course, I am hugely indebted.\n\n\"They have assured me that my recovery will be complete and speedy and I am looking forward to returning to work.\"\n\nAfter the accident, {"uri": "8182601324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "22:29:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T22:29:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T22:27:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/entertainment/2024/06/17/profile-who-is-sir-ian-mckellen/", "title": "Profile: Who is Sir Ian McKellen?", "body": "With two Oscar nominations for his work on screen and the recipient of every major theatrical award in the UK and US, Sir Ian McKellen is widely considered to be one of the greatest actors of all time.\n\nThe 85-year-old has gripped audiences both on screen and on stage, receiving international acclaim and becoming a household name across the globe.\n\nHis largest mark on the big screen may be as Gandalf in The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.\n\nOn the stage, Sir Ian has been nominated for 12 Olivier Awards and won six for his roles in Pillars Of The Community, The Alchemist, Bent, Wild Honey, Richard III and his one-man show Ian McKellen On Stage.\n\nThe actor was born in Burnley, Lancashire, in 1939 and, alongside his sister Jean, was raised by his mother Margery and father Denis.\n\nSir Ian has often credited his parents for encouraging his interest in becoming a performer, previously claiming in a 2017 interview with the Irish Examiner: \"Apparently she said, 'If Ian decides to be an actor, it's a good job, because it brings pleasure to people'.\"\n\nHis mother died when he was just 12 and he would lose his father at the age of 22.\n\nSir Ian acted at all the schools he attended.\n\nWhen at Bolton School he was able to take on his first Shakespeare performance at Hopefield Miniature Theatre when, as a 13-year-old Malvolio, he performed the letter scene from Twelfth Night.\n\nHe then won a scholarship to read English at St Catharine's College, Cambridge and was soon appearing in regular productions, including appearing alongside now famous alumni such as Derek Jacobi, David Frost and Margaret Drabble.\n\nSince then, he has gone on to become a household name for his acclaimed performances in everything from Shakespearean tragedies to Hollywood blockbusters.\n\nOutside of acting, Sir Ian has been active in the gay rights movement.\n\nVery few people knew of his homosexuality at a young age, including his parents.\n\nIn 1988, he publicly came out on a BBC Radio 4 programme while discussing Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation, which made the promotion of homosexuality as a family relationship by local authorities an offence.\n\nHe said of the law: \"I think it's offensive to anyone who is, like myself, homosexual, apart from the whole business of what can or cannot be taught to children.\"\n\nSection 28 was eventually fully repealed in 2003.\n\nSir Ian has spoken about his experiences on coming out on several occasions.\n\nBack in July 2000, he wrote in The Independent: \"The only good thing I can think to say about Section 28 is that it finally encouraged me to come out. A bit late in the day, but it remains the best thing I ever did.\"\n\nThen in 2015, he said that coming out actually made him a better performer, saying: \"What happened immediately, according to friends, is I became not just a happier person, but a better actor.\"\n\nSir Ian, who now lives in Limehouse, is currently performing in Player Kings, a production of Henry IV, Parts One and Two, at {"uri": "8187580851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:04:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:04:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:02:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/entertainment/2024/0620/1455851-disappointed-fans-send-well-wishes-to-ian-mckellen/", "title": "'Disappointed' fans send well wishes to Ian McKellen", "body": "Theatregoers have spoken of their disappointment and sent their good wishes to Ian McKellen as he recuperates following a fall from a West End stage on Monday.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor, 85, was portraying John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nMcKellen revealed on Thursday that he is having physiotherapy while he takes a break from performing following the fall.\n\nThe final London dates of Player Kings will see Ian's understudy, David Semark, take on the role of Falstaff.\n\nRania Margaronis, 56, flew for four hours from Greece specifically to see McKellen perform.\n\nShe said: \"It was shocking really because knowing someone so professional and so talented and at his age, it's really scary.\n\n\"I wish him all the best. I'm a great fan, I came all the way from Greece to see him and I was really disappointed. We love him and we're very proud to have him.\"\n\nWendy Geri, 84, travelled from Israel to see him perform, and booked a front row ticket as soon as she saw the play advertised. She said she was \"devastated\" at the news that McKellen would not perform, describing it as a \"big disappointment\".\n\nShe said: \"It's a very big disappointment. I've watched him on YouTube, I've watched him in conversations. I'm a student of what he's done. And he slipped up. I'm devastated.\"\n\nSophie Starnes, 34, a teacher who flew from California, said at the news McKellen would not perform: \"We were slightly disappointed, but obviously his health has to come first. And I'm sure it's still going to be a wonderful performance.\n\n\"We really hope he gets well soon and he's back on stage as soon as possible. It's still going to be a fantastic performance.\"\n\nCorin Doregger, 61, a retired teacher, flew from Vienna to see the acclaimed actor.\n\nShe said: \"I'm a bit disappointed because I booked tickets last year, and flew over from Vienna specially. When I heard he'd had a fall, I thought 'that's it'.\"\n\nShe said her message to the actor is: \"Get better soon and I'm sorry to have missed you.\"\n\nShe said: '\"I tried to see him in Keswick some years ago and didn't get to because it was a ballot, so this was my only chance. But we really need to cheer on the guy who's the understudy. {"uri": "8187507080", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:01:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:01:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:01:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/news/disappointed-theatre-fans-send-get-well-wishes-to-sir-ian-mckellen/a1175775962.html", "title": "'Disappointed' theatre fans send get well wishes to Sir Ian McKellen", "body": "Theatregoers have spoken of their disappointment and sent their good wishes to Sir Ian McKellen as he recuperates following a fall from a West End stage on Monday.\n\nThe veteran stage and screen actor, 85, was portraying John Falstaff in a production of Player Kings at the Noel Coward Theatre on Monday when he lost his footing in a fight scene and fell from the stage.\n\nSir Ian revealed on Thursday that he is having physiotherapy while he takes a break from performing following the fall.\n\nThe final London dates of Player Kings will see Sir Ian's understudy, David Semark, take on the role of Falstaff.\n\nRania Margaronis, 56, flew for four hours from Greece specifically to see Sir Ian perform.\n\nShe said: \"It was shocking really because knowing someone so professional and so talented and at his age, it's really scary.\n\n\"I wish him all the best. I'm a great fan, I came all the way from Greece to see him and I was really disappointed. We love him and we're very proud to have him.\"\n\nWendy Geri, 84, travelled from Israel to see him perform, and booked a front row ticket as soon as she saw the play advertised. She said she was \"devastated\" at the news that Sir Ian would not perform, describing it as a \"big disappointment\".\n\nShe said: \"It's a very big disappointment. I've watched him on YouTube, I've watched him in conversations. I'm a student of what he's done. And he slipped up. I'm devastated.\"\n\nSophie Starnes, 34, a teacher who flew from California, said at the news Sir Ian would not perform: \"We were slightly disappointed, but obviously his health has to come first. And I'm sure it's still going to be a wonderful performance.\n\n\"We really hope he gets well soon and he's back on stage as soon as possible. It's still going to be a fantastic performance.\"\n\nCorin Doregger, 61, a retired teacher, flew from Vienna to see Sir Ian.\n\nShe said: \"I'm a bit disappointed because I booked tickets last year, and flew over from Vienna specially. When I heard he'd had a fall, I thought 'that's it'.\"\n\nShe said her message to the actor is: \"Get better soon and I'm sorry to have missed you.\"\n\nShe said: '\"I tried to see him in Keswick some years ago and didn't get to because it was a ballot, so this was my only chance. But we really need to cheer on the guy who's the understudy.
